words: It's OK.

speaker: LORELAI
words: A crazy evil spirit obsessed with bra size took over my body.

speaker: RORY
words: It happens.

speaker: LORELAI
words: She's gone now.

speaker: RORY
words: Good to know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, I'm glad you're bonding with your grandparents.

speaker: RORY
words: No you're not.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes I am. It's just weird for me is all. I just can't relate to it.

speaker: RORY
words: You could if you tried.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, we're too -- too much has happened and I'm glad you are anyway.

speaker: RORY
words: OK.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I didn't mean to cut you off from them so completely, you know. It just happened. Not having them in my life just felt so right. I just never thought -- I'm sorry.

speaker: IRATE MOTHER
words: (to her daughter) I did not pay $500 for this dress so you could run around and mess it up. Now you sit and be still. Cross your legs. You're a lady.

speaker: LORELAI
words: God, I must have had a million dresses like that when I was a kid.

speaker: RORY
words: It doesn't really scream "you."

speaker: LORELAI
words: No. I did all the screaming.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you for not putting me in a dress like that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're welcome. Of course wearing those dresses -- not all bad.

speaker: RORY
words: No?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh no. They really fly up when you twirl around.

speaker: RORY
words: Huh.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And if you're wearing that ruffled underwear -- big crowd pleaser.

speaker: RORY
words: If it makes you feel better, I think I got a fungus from the steam room.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It does. Thank you.
(Cut to Emily and Richard's house. Rory and Lorelai are just arriving.)

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, good, you're here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey.

speaker: RORY
words: Hi, Grandma.

speaker: EMILY
words: My goodnes, what is that?

speaker: LORELAI
words: We brought dessert.

speaker: EMILY
words: Really? How thoughtful. What is it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Blueberry shortcake.

speaker: EMILY
words: I've never heard of blueberry shortcake.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, it's a Stars Hollow specialty.

speaker: EMILY
words: Why is it already cut?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's left over. From the wedding. At the inn.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, I know where the wedding was.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, sorry. You were just doing that staring thing.

speaker: EMILY
words: You brought us used dessert?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's not used. It's left over.

speaker: EMILY
words: How nice. I'll just put it in the kitchen next to my half-empty box of Cheer.

speaker: LORELAI
words: (whispers to Rory) She's in a good mood tonight.

speaker: EMILY
words: Can I get you a drink?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Uh, white wine would be nice.

speaker: RORY
words: Coke.

speaker: EMILY
words: So, Lorelai, did Rory tell you all about the wonderful time she had at the club?

speaker: LORELAI
words: She sure did.

speaker: EMILY
words: Your father was simply flying all week. She really charmed him.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah, well, if anybody could, it would be her.

speaker: EMILY
words: I mean, in this age of MTV and 100 television channels who would've imagined that a young girl coul still get a thrill spending a simple afternoon with her grandfather?

speaker: LORELAI
words: That wine would be real good right now, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: I think we should consider getting her a membership at the club, don't you?

speaker: LORELAI
words: If she wants, sure.

speaker: EMILY
words: I mean, to have a place to go where she can socialize, that's very important to a young girl.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, now especially that the crack den is closed down on the corner all her really good friends are gone. What do you think, Mom, should I pursue the career in comedy?

speaker: EMILY
words: It's just very interesting the way things turn out, isn't it?
(Richard comes in.)

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, you're here. Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Dad.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Rory, I have a surprise. Not only did I find that copy of Mencken's "Chrestomathy" we discussed, I also found a first edition of his memoirs as well.

speaker: RORY
words: You're kidding?

speaker: RICHARD
words: It's in my office if you'd like to see them.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh my God, I totally would.

speaker: EMIL
words: Y I'd like to take a look at those myself.
(They leave Lorelai sitting alone in the room.)

speaker: The End
words: The End
CUT TO RORY AND LORELAI WALKING ACROSS THE STREET.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Shopping for school supplies - party.

speaker: RORY
words: Nobody demanded that you come.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are you kidding? How of ten do you get to do things like this? I was thinking, while we’re going crazy, we should get some toilet paper and a plunger next.

speaker: RORY
words: I’ll just do this later.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I’m teasing. Come on, get that list of your.

speaker: RORY
words: Ok [puts out a list] I need legal pads,

speaker: LORELAI
words: Got it.

speaker: RORY
words: Tons of pens,

speaker: LORELAI
words: Right.

speaker: RORY
words: Some number 2 pencils, three highlighters, an eraser a staple remover and a folder.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You need 3 highlighters?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Three?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s a very random number.

speaker: RORY
words: Three is not a random number.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No but I mean how did you get to the number 3?

speaker: RORY
words: One dries up, one gets lost, I have one left.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You have really thought this out.

speaker: RORY
words: Yes, I have.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What came first - the chicken or the egg.

speaker: RORY
words: Can we get back to this list please.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Alright. Ooh, hey, legal pads.

speaker: RORY
words: No. Those are purple.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, purple is festive.

speaker: RORY
words: I can’t have purple

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes you can, they’re on sale.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m going to a serious school now, I need serious paper.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Paper’s paper.

speaker: RORY
words: Not at Chilton.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Alright, fine. Here is your serious paper.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh and here are you somber highlighters, your maudlin pencils, your manic-depressive pens.

speaker: RORY
words: Mom

speaker: LORELAI
words: Now these erasers are on lithium so they may seem cheerful but we actually caught them trying to shove themselves in the pencil sharpener earlier.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m going home now.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No wait! We’re going to stage an intervention with the neon post-its and make them give up their wacky crazy ways.

speaker: RORY
words: You’re never coming shopping with me again.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh here’s a card tray - [fades into intro]
CUT TO BUS OUTSIDE CHILTON

speaker: [Rory gets off the bus with bags, runs back into the bus for two more bags, then runs back into the bus a third time for another two.
words: [Rory gets off the bus with bags, runs back into the bus for two more bags, then runs back into the bus a third time for another two.
CUT TO MR. MEDINA’S CLASSROOM

speaker: MAX
words: Decent effort by most [handing back tests] Good effort by some, exceptional effort by two. Miss Geller, Miss Grant. Ms. Graham. Miss Gilmore [ hands Rory her paper with a ‘D’] Take these home, learn from your mistakes. Look at the large red circles around various parts of your paper as friendly reminders that to err is human. And that here at Chilton we try to beat that humanity right outta ya! Ok, next up. The test - the dreaded test. Shakespeare! The man we’ve been droning on about for the last three weeks, finally comes back to haunt us on Friday. This is a big one my friends - multiple choice with an essay section that will count for 20% of your grade for this semester. And don’t be fooled by my kind face and charming personality. This test will be hard, and there will be no makeups. [bell rings] Refer to the study materials that I gave you at the beginning of the month and those extensive notes I know you’ve been taking.

words: You should’ve told me.

words: I couldn’t.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You couldn’t tell me? You tell me everything.

speaker: RORY
words: It was too humiliating.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, honey, you once told me that you loved ‘Saved by the Bell’. What could be more humiliating than that.?

speaker: RORY
words: I couldn’t form the words. I couldn’t even say it. I couldn’t even comprehend it. It was…a ‘D’. I got a ‘D’, I’ve never gotten a ‘D’ - ever.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know.

speaker: RORY
words: Even when I broke my arm and couldn’t write for a month, I still got an ‘A-‘

speaker: LORELAI
words: That was a different school.

speaker: RORY
words: I know. It was Stars Hollow High. A ‘D’ at Stars Hollow is like an ‘F’ at Chilton. It’s worse, it’s like a ‘G’ or a ‘W’.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So I’m guessing the spelling test didn’t go well either?

speaker: RORY
words: A ‘D’. I suck.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You don’t suck.

speaker: RORY
words: I can’t do this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Listen, a ‘D’ is bad, ok. But all this talk about ‘I suck’ and ‘I can’t do this’ and self pity - that’s worse. That’s not you. You didn’t feel sorry for yourself when it took you three months to learn how to ride a bike, and you won’t now.

speaker: RORY
words: Four months.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Huh?

speaker: RORY
words: It took me four months

speaker: LORELAI
words: Really? Four months?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, you wanna belabor the conversation?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Alright, forget about the bike. Listen, a ‘D’ is one grade. It’s not the end of the world. You’ll catch up, you’ll do better. You are of hardy stubborn stock, my dear. If there’s one thing I gave you, it’s my stubbornness.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m not stubborn.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes you are.

speaker: RORY
words: No I’m not.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Fine you’re not.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re welcome. You can do this Rory and I will help you. I will get you through this, now put that ‘D’ behind you. Now what’s next?

speaker: RORY
words: I have a test on Friday.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh a test! Great!

speaker: RORY
words: It’s on Shakespeare.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Bard with a beard - love it!

speaker: RORY
words: It’s worth 20% of my grade.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Just makes life interesting. Now what do we have to do to get you an ‘A’ on that test.

speaker: RORY
words: Do you really think I can do this?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I bet you a dollar.

speaker: RORY
words: That’s it? That’s all my future’s worth - one dollar.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well you did get a ‘D’.
[Rory chuckles]
CUT TO CHILTON
[Rory is sitting on a bench reading. Paris comes up behind her]

words: ‘Let me not to the marriage of true minds admit impediments, love is not love which alters when it alterations finds or bends with the remover to remove - oh no! It is an ever-fixed mark that looks on tempests and is never shaken. It is the star to every wandering bark who worth’s unknown although his height be taken’ You’re going down.
CUT TO INN KITCHEN.

[Pan to later that night, Rory goes into the living room and finds Lorelai asleep on the couch. She covers her with a blanket and goes back to the kitchen. Later that night, Lorelai wakes up and goes into the kitchen to find Rory asleep at the table. She sits down and puts the blanket around Rory as well and falls asleep as well.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Excuse me. Hello.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Ms. Gilmore. Please come in.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Have a seat.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Um, I think there’s been a terrible mistake. Rory told me that she wasn’t allowed to take her test.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: She was late.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Right, well, see there were circumstances beyond her control. Rory is never late. She’s almost annoyingly on time. I think if you checked your records -

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Past performance has nothing to do with today’s situation.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ok, but see, she was up all night studying, I was there, she has a witness.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: She’s not on trial here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well your honor [pause] just a little trial humor, that won’t happen again. Um, see, she got up late, she broke her neck to get here. We don’t like locally as you know.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: The dog at my homework -

speaker: LORELAI
words: Excuse me?

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: My computer crashed and I lost my midterm.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I wasn’t making excuses.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: My grandmother and 1st cousin died. My sister took my report to school instead of hers, my religion prohibits studying after sundown. I went blind last night but I’m fine now.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s not Rory.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: [getting up] Ms. Gilmore, rules are rules. When you’re late, you forfeit the right to take the test.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Where are you going? [to Max] Where is he going?

speaker: MAX
words: Lorelai please, believe me if I could do anything I would.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, you could let her take the test.

speaker: MAX
words: I’m afraid I can’t.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well that’s not fair.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Ms. Gilmore, we are not here to be fair, we are here to educate.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes and I’m asking you to please educate my kid.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: We will, when she’s on time. Have a nice day.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are you holding that door open for a reason?

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Our meeting is over.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Like hell it is.

speaker: MAX
words: Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Do you have any idea what we have gone through this week? We have been up all night every night studying. We haven’t slept. We haven’t talked about anything else except this school and this test for seven days. We have stretched ourselves as thin as humanly possible without going completely postal. My God! We’re only one person!

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Why don’t we narrow our field conversation down to Rory.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ok, yeah, why don’t we. You sit up here in your snotty little school that’s in desperate need of some extra heating vents and you nurture horrible kids who treat each other like mortal enemies. You set impossible standards that make normal people feel less than everyone else. And you take a great kid like Rory and you tear her apart!

speaker: MAX
words: I don’t think that’s completely fair.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [to Max] And you! You say she’s smart and she’ll be fine and this rotting stodgy rathole could use somebody like her and then you completely shut her out of a test that she’s crammed for, that she’s ready for, that she completely deserves to take!

speaker: MAX
words: I didn’t call this place a ‘rathole’

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh no that’s true. I added that. Wouldn’t want you to get in trouble with ‘Il duce’ here. I thought this place was going to be so great! And now I guess this goes on the ‘Boy was I wrong’ list, right above gauchos but just below the ‘Flashdance’ phase.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: My goodness you do like to throw fits in your family.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Your daughter threw a similar if not as manic fit of her own this morning.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Please. Rory doesn’t throw fits. She’s the most even tempered person I know.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Well then, she did a lovely impression of you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well I don’t -

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: Ms. Gilmore, everything you said in your rant was absolutely true - without the colorful embellishments of course. We do set impossible standards, and such standards do foster highly competitive children. However that is life and that is Chilton.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rules can change, you can change them.

speaker: CHARLESTON
words: I told your daughter when she came here that this place was not for everyone and might not be for her. I will now tell you the same thing. She doesn’t have to be here. She doesn’t have to go to Harvard, maybe she shouldn’t if she can’t handle the pressure, she should leave. Now you can take your daughter home now and decide what it is you intend to do. However, another outburst from either of you will not be on the options list. Thank you for coming in. That will be all.
CUT TO HALLWAY
