words: Yeah, great.
CUT TO LUKE’S APARTMENT
[Jess is reading and listening to music as Luke walks in and takes a sledgehammer out of the closet. He walks across the room and swings the sledgehammer through the wall, then hands it to Jess.]

speaker: LUKE
words: That’s your room. Finish up. We’ll hold hands and skip afterwards.
THE END
OPEN IN LUKE’S DINER
[Luke’s apartment is under construction. Luke delivers food to some customers, a chunk of the ceiling falls onto the table.]

speaker: LUKE
words: Here you go. Geez, uh, sorry folks. Uh, here. . .there we go. Free coffee all around. You might wanna put your hand over that. There we go. [walks over to construction worker] Tom, what the hell is going on up there?

speaker: TOM
words: We’re redoing your apartment. What do you think is going on up there?

speaker: LUKE
words: The ceiling’s falling in. I’ve got customers eating drywall here.

speaker: TOM
words: Oh, well, that can’t be good.

speaker: LUKE
words: You said minimal disruptions.

speaker: TOM
words: Hey, this is minimal disruptions. Look, I need you to sign this change order.

speaker: LUKE
words: What happened now?

speaker: TOM
words: Well, we broke through this wall and we found some pipes that shouldn’t be there. We gotta move ‘em.

speaker: LUKE
words: Move ‘em where?

speaker: TOM
words: Not sure. We gotta find out what they do first.

speaker: LUKE
words: You’re kidding?

speaker: TOM
words: Oh yeah. There’s nothing I like more than a good ‘moving a pipe’ joke.

speaker: LUKE
words: Fine, one more week, that’s it.

speaker: TOM
words: Oh, sure, construction ultimatum. Ha, that’s even funnier than my moving pipe joke.
[Lorelai and Rory walk in]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey.

speaker: LUKE
words: Hey.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Geez, look at this place.

speaker: RORY
words: It’s a mess.

speaker: LORELAI
words: How long – .

speaker: LUKE
words: Nope – can’t sit here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Why not?

speaker: LUKE
words: Three people got nailed in the head here earlier.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But their food was okay, right?

speaker: LUKE
words: Will you just move? [Lorelai’s cell phone rings] Outside.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, if I sit here one more second, I just might be outside. Order me some coffee.
[Lorelai walks away; Jess walks over to the table and hands Rory an open umbrella]

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh, you are really funny. You and Tom should put an act together. I’d leave it open.
[cut to outside]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Go ahead Mom, I can hear you now.

speaker: EMILY
words: I wanted to know if you’d like a gift certificate for a weekend at the Birch Grove Spa.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are you serious?

speaker: EMILY
words: I bid on it at the DAR Symphony Fundraiser and I won.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Birch Grove? That’s supposed to be an amazing place, why don’t you go?

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, I’ve never had any real desire to go to a spa.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Why’d you bid on it then?

speaker: EMILY
words: It was for charity, I had to bid on something. And I certainly didn’t want another portrait of George Washington. I’ve got four in the attic already.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, I’d love it.

speaker: EMILY
words: Good.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Two days of total mind-numbing pampering. Massages, facials, aromatherapy.

speaker: EMILY
words: My goodness, you make it sound like heaven.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s as close as you’ll ever come to being a dog.

speaker: EMILY
words: I beg your pardon?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, a whole life of nothing but eating, sleeping, lying on your back and getting rubbed.

speaker: EMILY
words: I’d love the comparison to stop there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Deal. Um, hey, when’s it for?

speaker: EMILY
words: This weekend, actually.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, well, I’ll be there.

speaker: EMILY
words: So will I.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Excuse me?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, the certificate is for two, and since you make it sound like the most wonderful place in the world, I might as well try it with you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, but - .

speaker: EMILY
words: That’s all right, isn’t it, if I join you? You don’t mind?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I don’t mind at all.

speaker: EMILY
words: Wonderful. I’ll pick you up tomorrow morning. You know, I’m actually looking forward to this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh yeah, me too. Thanks Mom. Buh bye.
CUT TO INSIDE LUKE’S
[Rory is sitting at the table holding the umbrella over her head. Lorelai walks in and sits down]

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m going to a spa with my mother.

speaker: RORY
words: Lean forward.
[opening credits]
CUT TO LORELAI’S BEDROOM
[Lorelai is sitting on the bed as Rory walks around packing a suitcase]

speaker: LORELAI
words: [on phone] So, then we’re all confirmed. Uh, great. Thanks so much for your help. Okay, bye. [hangs up] Yeeessss!

speaker: RORY
words: That was an evil yes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Not an evil yes. It’s a ‘yes, I’m pretty, but hello, I’m smart’ kind of a yes.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, my mistake.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So here’s the deal – I go into my facial just as my mother is finishing her salt glow, which will end ten minutes after I’ve hit my scalp treatment which puts me in the watsu massage pool at least six minutes into her back facial. Uh, in fact, the day is so well planned, I won’t see her until dinner which will be cut tragically short by the food poisoning I plan to contract.

speaker: RORY
words: You are twelve and disgusting.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am trapped and desperate.

speaker: RORY
words: You really think you can avoid Grandma the entire weekend?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, I’m nothing if not a great organizer. Now, let's talk about what you're gonna do tonight. Throwing a party, I hope? Inviting hundreds of bikers and lowlifes who are gonna trash the place?

speaker: RORY
words: I am going to do laundry, watch TV, order Indian food and go to bed early.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And then come the bikers and lowlifes who are gonna trash the place?

speaker: RORY
words: I may even fall asleep on the couch with the TV on.

speaker: LORELAI
words: When do the bikers and lowlifes get to trash the place?

speaker: RORY
words: You're all packed.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory, you have to do something bad when Mommy’s out of town. It's the law. You're seen Risky Business, right? Now I'm not asking for a prostitution ring, but how about a floating craps game or something?

speaker: RORY
words: I'll see what I can do.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I would greatly appreciate it.
[a car honks from outside]

speaker: RORY
words: I think Grandma’s here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What’s she honking for? She hates honking. She calls it a mechanical bodily function. [looks out window] Ugh, geez.

speaker: RORY
words: [looks out window] Oh, cool!
CUT TO OUTSIDE
[Emily is standing in front of a limousine as Rory and Lorelai walk out of the house]

speaker: EMILY
words: Hello, hello, hello!

speaker: LORELAI
words: What, are we going to the prom?

speaker: EMILY
words: I just thought since this weekend is all about relaxing, we should start with the ride.

speaker: RORY
words: This is cool, Grandma.

speaker: EMILY
words: Thank you, Rory. So, are we all ready to go?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I guess so, Miss Daisy. Bye sweets.

speaker: RORY
words: Bye. Bye Grandma.

speaker: EMILY
words: Goodbye Rory.

speaker: RORY
words: Have a good time.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Bikers and lowlifes.

speaker: RORY
words: I’ll get right on it.
CUT TO CHILTON CLASSROOM

speaker: TEACHER
words: In general, the lab reports weren’t bad – but they weren’t great either, which leads me to question whether everyone has the grasp of electrochemistry I prefer before we move on. To that end, I will be giving another test on Tuesday covering chapters fourteen through eighteen in your textbooks, as well as the material from lab. Now please proceed with the assignment we all started yesterday, as that too will be included on the test.

speaker: PARIS
words: Madeline?

speaker: MADELINE
words: What?

speaker: PARIS
words: What are you guys doing tonight?

speaker: MADELINE
words: It’s Friday night.

speaker: PARIS
words: So you’ve got dates?

speaker: MADELINE
words: Well, yeah, why?

speaker: PARIS
words: I was kind of hoping you could study with me.

speaker: MADELINE
words: On a Friday night?

speaker: PARIS
words: Yes.

speaker: MADELINE
words: But we’ve got dates.

speaker: LOUISE
words: What is she saying?

speaker: MADELINE
words: She wants us to study with her.

speaker: LOUISE
words: On a Friday night?

speaker: MADELINE
words: Yeah.

speaker: LOUISE
words: But we’ve got dates.

speaker: PARIS
words: I know you have dates, I was hoping maybe you’d cancel them.

speaker: MADELINE
words: To study?

speaker: PARIS
words: Yes.

speaker: MADELINE
words: On a Friday night?

speaker: LOUISE
words: What’d she say?

speaker: MADELINE
words: She wants us to cancel our dates to study.

speaker: LOUISE
words: On a Friday night?

speaker: MADELINE
words: That’s what she said.

speaker: LOUISE
words: But we have - .

speaker: PARIS
words: Oh my God, forget it! [walks over to Rory] So, I suppose that you have big Friday night plans also?

speaker: RORY
words: Well, kind of.

speaker: PARIS
words: So the fact that I’m seeing my entire Harvard career slip away apparently is of no interest to anyone?

speaker: RORY
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: PARIS
words: I got an A-minus, okay?

speaker: RORY
words: So?

speaker: PARIS
words: What do you mean, so? I got an A-minus. I have never gotten an A-minus. I just can’t focus lately. Things are so weird at my house. My dad finally figured out exactly how much it was gonna cost him to divorce my mom, so now he’s back and it’s bad enough that I wasted all that time crunching the numbers with him, but now that he’s back, they’re fighting and redecorating. The place is a mess. I need help.

speaker: RORY
words: Look, I can’t tonight, but if you’re still freaked out after the quiz on Tuesday, I will spend everyday next week helping you prepare for the final, okay?

speaker: PARIS
words: I guess.

speaker: RORY
words: Relax. It will be fine, I promise.

speaker: PARIS
words: All I had to do was move a decimal point and none of this would’ve happened.
CUT TO BIRCH GROVE SPA
[Emily and Lorelai walk into the lobby]

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, look at this place. It’s lovely. And that smell – what is that, eucalyptus?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don’t know.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, it’s lovely. Oh Lorelai, come over here, look. They have cucumber slices in the water.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh wow! Now if they have ranch dressing in the soap dispensers, this place is great.

speaker: EMILY
words: You know what? I love it here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hm. Careful Mom, that’s how they get you in the Moonies.

speaker: EMILY
words: I feel more relaxed already. Mm, that’s the most delicious water I’ve ever had. Have a sip.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Let’s just check in, shall we?

speaker: EMILY
words: Okay. [they walk to the front desk] Hello, I’m Emily Gilmore. This is my daughter, Lorelai.

speaker: BOBBY
words: Ah, yes, welcome to Birch Grove. My name is Bobby. I have everything all set for you. Do you have luggage?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, it’s in the Luca Brasi mobile out front.

speaker: BOBBY
words: Okay, well, we can take care of that for you. Here are your room keys and a copy of all of your spa activities. You ladies are booked solid, I see.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, we intend to leave here completely different people.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, I’m going to be Ted Nugent.

speaker: BOBBY
words: Anyhow, your rooms are right down this hall. Fruit and yogurt is served by the pool in the mornings, and your lunch and dinner seatings are on that itinerary. Any questions?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, where can one get a cup of coffee around here?

speaker: BOBBY
words: Ah, we don’t serve anything with caffeine here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And you think that’s safe?

speaker: EMILY
words: Thank you, Bobby. We’re sure we’re going to have a wonderful time.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, there’s no coffee.

speaker: EMILY
words: It won’t kill you to go two days without coffee, Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I think it will.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai, just focus on all the pampering we’re going to have. Look at all the wonderful things we have to look forward to.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh no.

speaker: EMILY
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, um, I’ll be right back. They screwed up our appointments.

speaker: EMILY
words: Again?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What do you mean, again?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, on the way to your house I called to confirm our schedule and found out they had us booked separately for every single one of our treatments. Luckily, I insisted on speaking to a manager and was able to straighten everything out. Yes, those are right.

speaker: LORELAI
words: They are?

speaker: EMILY
words: I even had them move the pedicure tubs together in the same room so we can talk during it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, I’m really gonna need a cup of coffee.

speaker: EMILY
words: Have some cucumber water.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, see, that’s not gonna do it because it’s – .

speaker: EMILY
words: Drink, Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: – cucumber water. Yuck.

[Rory and Dean are kissing by a tree]

speaker: RORY
words: Wow, your lung capacity certainly has improved.

words: Well, I’ve been playing a lot more basketball lately.

speaker: RORY
words: Yet another reason to continue the fight to keep physical education in schools.

words: So, tonight.

words: Yes?

words: I was thinking.

words: Yes?

words: Mm hmm.

speaker: DEAN
words: Maybe I’d come over.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh.

speaker: DEAN
words: What?

speaker: RORY
words: Actually, I was thinking of pulling kind of a hermit thing tonight.

speaker: DEAN
words: Why?

speaker: RORY
words: I don’t know. J.D. Salinger seems to dig it.

speaker: DEAN
words: You don’t want me to come over?

speaker: RORY
words: No, I just. . .I almost never get the house all to myself and I thought with my mom gone, I can finally do my laundry exactly the way I like it. You know, not just separated into whites and colors, but the colors separated into darks, mediums, and lights, with a separate pile for white T-shirts and T-shirts with some kind of writing on them, like, you know, Rock Star, Evil, or Kafka was here.

speaker: DEAN
words: You wanna be alone to do laundry?

speaker: RORY
words: And watch TV and eat the Indian food that I love but my mom hates the smell of and go to bed early and. . .are you mad?

speaker: DEAN
words: Why would I be mad? You wanna spend tonight alone.

speaker: RORY
words: But hey, tomorrow, the whole day is all about you. I mean it, from morning ‘til night. You plan it, or I’ll plan it, or we can get a professional to plan it, whatever you want. Just don’t be mad.

speaker: DEAN
words: I’m not. I’m not mad.

speaker: RORY
words: Good.

speaker: DEAN
words: I’m confused, but I’m not mad.

speaker: RORY
words: Fine

speaker: DEAN
words: I’m a saint, but I’m not mad.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you.

speaker: DEAN
words: You’re welcome.

speaker: RORY
words: So, deep breath and. . .

[Lorelai is in her room unpacking. She hears knocking and opens the door to the hallway. No one’s there, so she opens another door. Emily walks in wearing a bathrobe.]

speaker: EMILY
words: How do I look?

words: Like a landlady. What is this?

speaker: EMILY
words: I got adjoining rooms so we don’t have to go out in the hallway to get to each other.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Great thinking!

speaker: EMILY
words: God, this robe is fabulous. How do they get it so soft?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, I think having about forty other people wear it first is part of the secret.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, stop it. So are you all ready for our skin rejuvenating and revitalizing collagen facial and eye treatment?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Almost.

speaker: EMILY
words: It has vitamin C and plant extracts in it, which is the hottest thing in skin care these days. And the eye treatment is supposed to reduce puffiness and minimize the appearance of fine lines.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, no more brochures for you. All right, I’m ready, let’s go.

words: Your robe, you’re supposed to wear your robe.

words: Oh, well, I’m sure they’ll give me one when I get there.

speaker: EMILY
words: But these robes are wonderful.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom.

words: They help you relax.

words: We’re late, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: They’re wonderful, relaxing robes.

words: Oh my God.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [from bathroom] You’re kidding me, right?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, hurry up, we’re gonna be late.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [opens bathroom door] Happy?

speaker: FACIALIST
words: So, how are we doing?

speaker: LORELAI
words: So good.

words: Okay. Well, I’m gonna leave you to sit for a few minutes, so just relax and enjoy, and I’ll be right back.

words: Thanks.
[As the facialist leaves, Lorelai closes her eyes. Emily quietly enters the room and sits down next to Lorelai.]

speaker: EMILY
words: Are your feet sweating?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom?

speaker: EMILY
words: Those booties make my feet sweat. Don’t they make your feet sweat?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What are you doing in my room?

speaker: EMILY
words: Magda left me sitting for twenty minutes. Fine time to take a coffee break.

speaker: LORELAI
words: She’s not taking a coffee break. Your skin is supposed to be absorbing the moisture in your mask – in your room.

speaker: EMILY
words: Let’s see what’s next on our agenda, shall we? Stop moving Lorelai, you’ll electrocute yourself. Ooh, the Egyptian mud bath. I wonder if the mud bath is one of those things you see in brochures where they wrap you in towels like you’re in a cocoon of some sort. That might be nice. Especially if their towels are as good as their robes because I just love these robes. I wonder where they get these robes. Shouldn’t be so hard to find the manufacturer. I could order a few of them. One for me, one for you and one for Rory.
CUT TO HALLWAY
[Lorelai and Emily walk down the hallway in their robes]

speaker: EMILY
words: I still can’t get over it, it really was mud. I mean, I know it said mud bath but I didn’t really think they meant a real mud bath. And the odd thing is I should’ve been more repulsed by it. Sitting in a tub of hot dirt, which is basically what mud is, should’ve made me ill, and yet I really enjoyed it. Did yours have twigs? Mine had twigs, and when I asked the woman about them, she told me they were there because of the healing qualities. . .
[they walk through a door marked ‘Quiet Room.’ A few seconds later, the door opens and Lorelai ushers Emily out into the hall]

speaker: EMILY
words: What are you doing? Lorelai, stop it! You’re pushing me!
[Lorelai bangs on the door, showing Emily the ‘Quiet Room’ sign, then they walk back into the room]

speaker: MASSEUR
words: How’s the pressure – too much?

words: Yup.

words: Sorry, I’ll go lighter.

words: Your hands are amazing. Compliment your masseur’s hands, Lorelai.

words: Oh my God.

speaker: EMILY
words: Excuse me?

words: Nothing.

words: You were muttering under your breath. Years of experience have taught me that when you do that, it’s usually about me.

words: Mom, you signed us up for a couple's massage.

words: So?

words: A couple's massage is for a couple – not a couple of people.

words: It's more efficient this way. We'll both be finished at the same time.

words: Mom, do you know what most people who get these massages do about five minutes after it's over? They have sex, together, probably while wearing their robes.

speaker: EMILY
words: Could the two of you excuse us for a moment please? Thank you. [the masseurs leave] Well, that was appalling!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, that was true!

speaker: EMILY
words: You're just determined to spoil this, aren't you, Lorelai?

words: Why, because I want a quiet, private massage?

words: You've been pouting and sulking and sighing.

words: Oh, I have not been sighing.

speaker: EMILY
words: Rolling your eyes, mumbling.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, that's how I detox.

speaker: EMILY
words: Ever since we got here, you've made it your mission to be as miserable as possible.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That's not true.

speaker: EMILY
words: It's completely true. And if you don't care that you're hurting my feelings, maybe you care that you're wasting all your relaxing time acting like a petulant four-year-old.

words: Well, I'm sorry.

speaker: EMILY
words: Do you want me to try to get myself another room?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No.

speaker: EMILY
words: I saw a supply closet down the hall. Maybe my masseur could finish me in there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: Or perhaps I could just roll myself against a stucco wall, eliminate the need for a masseur altogether.

words: Lie down Mom, please.

speaker: EMILY
words: If you say so. Lorelai?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, Mom?

speaker: EMILY
words: Would you go get the boys, please?

[Rory, while on the phone, is sitting on the living room floor surrounded by piles of clothes]

speaker: RORY
words: No, that’s two orders of garlic gnon, three simosas, and a chicken vindiloo. And rice, and the green sauce, and no salad, and. . . oh wait, sorry. Can you hold on a sec? [answers the call waiting] Hello?

words: Hi, this is Phil’s Liquor. I’m supposed to be delivering a keg there tonight.

words: I wasn’t done. Tranquilizers, uh, will be required if I have to spend one more minute with my mother.

words: Please tell me you’re at least trying to get along with her?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, hey, I’m being a peach.

words: Really?

words: Well, I smell like a peach. Was that the doorbell?

words: Yeah, I’ll call you later.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh wait, I wanna find out who it is.

speaker: RORY
words: The sooner you get back to your weekend, the sooner it’ll be over.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, but before you go, can you get out my address book and count how many friends I have? I’ll wait.

speaker: RORY
words: Bye.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mean!

speaker: RORY
words: Steal me soap! [hangs up the phone, then opens the front door] Paris. What -.

speaker: PARIS
words: I tried to stay home and study myself but I can't. I don't know what anything means anymore. I mean, I can't even read my own handwriting. What does this say? The person who wrote this should be dressed in a clown suit stuffing bodies under their porch. You're in your pajamas.

speaker: RORY
words: I know.

speaker: PARIS
words: This was the big night you had planned – a rendezvous with Mr. Peanut?

speaker: RORY
words: Well...

speaker: PARIS
words: You're doing laundry.

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: PARIS
words: You're doing laundry in your pajamas.

speaker: RORY
words: My mom is out of town and I never get the house all to myself.

speaker: PARIS
words: You mean you never get to go months on end without seeing your parents, just getting an occasional postcard that doesn’t even have a courtesy "Wish you were here" written on it? That does suck. Don't let me stand in your way.

speaker: RORY
words: Paris, wait.

words: No, forget it, I don't want to get in the way of your big night. I hear there's gonna be some hot knitting going on later.

speaker: RORY

speaker: RORY

words: Deal.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, so, go sit on the couch. I’ll be out in the minute.

words: Where are you going?

words: I’m going to go change.

words: Okay, but my hour doesn’t start until you get back out here, right?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I like it.

speaker: EMILY
words: You do? I like it too.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good, let’s go then, I’m starving.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, me too. What are they serving for dinner tonight?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, let’s see. [looks at menu] Hmm.

speaker: EMILY
words: They certainly do like their tofu here, don’t they?

speaker: LORELAI
words: And the word steamed. Well, they have dessert at least. Cookies sweetened with sprouted mungbean.

speaker: EMILY
words: That sounds dreadful.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, it does.

speaker: EMILY
words: Where are you going? You aren’t going to change, are you? Our seating’s in ten minutes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Get your coat.

speaker: EMILY
words: I don’t need a coat to go to the dining room.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We’re not going to the dining room.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, where are we going?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Out.

speaker: EMILY
words: Out where?

speaker: LORELAI
words: We’re gonna leave the spa, find a restaurant, and have a steak.

speaker: EMILY
words: A steak?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Who’s gonna stop us?

speaker: EMILY
words: A steak.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Come on, Mom. What’s it gonna be – vicious trollop or the wide world of mungbeans?

speaker: EMILY
words: Let’s go.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m right behind you.
CUT TO LORELAI’S HOUSE
[Rory and Paris are studying in the living room]

speaker: RORY
words: So, given that those are the reactions occurring in the two half-cells, what do you do next?

speaker: PARIS
words: Well, if we add them together, doubling the coefficients of the silver half equation but not the voltage, we get the equation for the complete reaction.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, you’re in much better shape than you wanna think you are.

speaker: PARIS
words: Impossible. [doorbell rings; Rory walks toward the door] Where are you going?

speaker: RORY
words: That’s my food.

speaker: PARIS
words: Another half hour, please!

speaker: RORY
words: No, you got your hour. You need to go.

speaker: PARIS
words: But – .

speaker: RORY
words: Go!

speaker: PARIS
words: Fine.
[Rory opens the door. Jess is holding a box of food]

speaker: JESS
words: Delivery.

speaker: RORY
words: What are you doing here?

speaker: JESS
words: Well, Luke figured since you’re along tonight that maybe you wouldn’t have any food in the house, so he sent over a care package.

speaker: RORY
words: I don’t need a care package. I ordered food from Sandeep’s.

speaker: JESS
words: Really? Planning on burning down the house afterwards?

speaker: RORY
words: Jess.

speaker: JESS
words: The only way to kill the smell. Where should I put this? [walks into house]

speaker: RORY
words: Well. . .

speaker: JESS
words: Kitchen?

speaker: RORY
words: Um. . .sure.
[cut to kitchen]

speaker: RORY
words: God, how much food is in there? This could feed twelve.

speaker: JESS
words: Excuse me, I’ve seen you eat.

speaker: RORY
words: Fine, six.

speaker: JESS
words: Yeah, well, he wanted you taken care of. He wasn’t sure how long your mom was gonna be gone for.

speaker: RORY
words: Just tonight.

speaker: JESS
words: Oh, he didn’t know that.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, now you can tell him.

speaker: JESS
words: I will.

speaker: RORY
words: So how come Caesar didn’t bring this over?

speaker: JESS
words: I volunteered.

speaker: RORY
words: Why?

speaker: JESS
words: Just wanted to get out of the construction zone. There’s nothing but banging and yelling. That place gives me a headache.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh.

speaker: JESS
words: Why – did you think I wanted to come over here and see you?

speaker: RORY
words: No.

speaker: JESS
words: Just needed some quiet.

speaker: RORY
words: Fine.

speaker: JESS
words: That is all.

speaker: RORY
words: Got it.

speaker: JESS
words: Clear my head.

speaker: RORY
words: I understand.

speaker: JESS
words: So, aren’t you gonna eat?

speaker: RORY
words: Eventually.

speaker: JESS
words: It gets cold fast.

speaker: RORY
words: I can heat it up.

speaker: JESS
words: Reheated French fries really suck.

speaker: RORY
words: Hm, they do suck.

speaker: JESS
words: Yeah, so, eat.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, I will. You’re still standing there.

speaker: JESS
words: I know. You didn’t give me a tip.

speaker: RORY
words: You want money?

speaker: JESS
words: No, I’ll take a fry though.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, yeah, have as much as you want.

speaker: JESS
words: Okay, great. [takes off jacket]

speaker: RORY
words: What are you doing?

speaker: JESS
words: Getting ready to eat.

speaker: RORY
words: You’re staying?

speaker: JESS
words: Didn’t you just invite me?

speaker: RORY
words: No, I -.

speaker: JESS
words: No, you told me to have all I wanted. That sounded invitation-like.

speaker: RORY
words: You wanna stay here and eat?

speaker: JESS
words: Beats being at Luke’s.

speaker: RORY
words: But – .

speaker: PARIS
words: [walks in from living room] I can’t find my flashcards.

speaker: JESS
words: I didn’t know you had company.

speaker: RORY
words: This is Paris. We were just studying.

speaker: JESS
words: Huh.

speaker: PARIS
words: Don’t worry, I was just leaving. If you find my flashcards, call me, okay?

speaker: RORY
words: No.

speaker: PARIS
words: What?

speaker: RORY
words: Stay for dinner.

speaker: PARIS
words: But I thought. . .

speaker: RORY
words: We have a ton of food, and we can go over the notes more later.

speaker: PARIS
words: You’re sure?

speaker: RORY
words: Positive.

speaker: PARIS
words: Is that mac and cheese?

speaker: RORY
words: It sure is.

speaker: PARIS
words: I love mac and cheese.

speaker: RORY
words: Great.

speaker: PARIS
words: I’m not allowed to have mac and cheese.

speaker: RORY
words: Splurge. Come on Paris, stay.

speaker: PARIS
words: Do you have a twenty-four hour pharmacy just in case I have an allergic reaction to something?

speaker: RORY
words: Believe it or not, we do.

speaker: PARIS
words: Okay, can I borrow your phone?

speaker: RORY
words: It’s by the door.
[Paris walks away]

speaker: JESS
words: Interesting.

speaker: RORY
words: What is?

speaker: JESS
words: You think we need a chaperone?

speaker: RORY
words: No, I don’t.

speaker: JESS
words: You just invited one.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m just being polite. Paris is alone tonight and you yourself just said we have enough food for six.

speaker: JESS
words: With me around, it’s down to four.

speaker: RORY
words: With Paris around, it’s down to two.

speaker: JESS
words: Works out well.

speaker: RORY
words: I think so.

speaker: PARIS
words: [on phone] Hola, es Paris. Voy a comer la cena de cas de Rory. Hay mucho mac and cheese!
CUT TO RESTAURANT
[Emily and Lorelai check their coats, then walk toward the hostess]

speaker: EMILY
words: My goodness, look at this place.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I bet there’s no cucumber slices in the water here. [to hostess] Hi there, party of two.

speaker: HOSTESS
words: Okay. Uh, well, I can take your name, but I probably won’t have a table for about an hour.

speaker: LORELAI
words: An hour!

speaker: EMILY
words: I can’t wait an hour.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Me either.

speaker: EMILY
words: I’ll pass out.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Go first, you can break my fall.

speaker: EMILY
words: Can we bribe you?

speaker: HOSTESS
words: Sorry.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Please? She’s loaded.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai!

speaker: HOSTESS
words: You know, a couple of stools just opened up at the bar, and we do serve our entire menu there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That is a great idea. Thanks. Come on.

speaker: EMILY
words: We cannot eat dinner at a bar.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don’t wanna wait an hour, and I’m wearing the wrong shoes for a drive thru.

speaker: EMILY
words: But what are people going to think?

speaker: LORELAI
words: That we’re loose women with questionable morals.
[they sit down at the bar]

speaker: EMILY
words: Doesn’t seem right to eat dinner when your feet aren’t touching the floor.

speaker: BARTENDER
words: What can I get you ladies?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hi Steve, nice to meet you. We will have two. . .martinis?

speaker: EMILY
words: Why not?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Two vodka martinis, straight up with a twist, very dry, very cold, and a couple of menus, please.

speaker: EMILY
words: And some peanuts.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah, peanuts, good idea.

speaker: BARTENDER
words: Here you go, I’ll get your drinks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you. You’re a good man, Steve. Okay, I’m thinking steak and Caesar salad if it’s not too anchovy-y, and hey – do you wanna split a shrimp cocktail to start?

speaker: EMILY
words: That sounds fine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah, I just love the idea of shrimp cocktail with a steak dinner, you know? It’s so Casino, Big Joe, steak and shrimp – hey, save some for winter, there.

speaker: EMILY
words: I never realized how wonderful peanuts were before.

speaker: BARTENDER
words: Want a refill?

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, yes, please.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Cheers, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: Cheers. I must tell you, I never expected this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: EMILY
words: Me inhaling peanuts at a singles bar.

speaker: LORELAI
words: This isn’t a singles bar, Mom. It’s a sixty-forty bar.

speaker: EMILY
words: A what?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sixty-year-old men hitting on forty-year-old women, divorcees mostly.

speaker: EMILY
words: Really?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Look around.

speaker: EMILY
words: Hm. Oh, now, she can do better than that. What does she see in him?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Big will, short life span, the usual draw. Hey Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: I wonder if they have pretzels, too.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Don’t look now, but I think you’re passing for a forty-year-old woman.

speaker: EMILY
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Two o’clock, silver fox, totally checking you out.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, he is not.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, he’s not staring at Steve.

speaker: EMILY
words: You’re being ridiculous. He’s definitely not looking at me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He’s still looking.

speaker: EMILY
words: Drink your martini, Lorelai.
CUT TO LORELAI’S HOUSE
[Rory, Paris, and Jess are eating at the kitchen table]

speaker: PARIS
words: A tragic waste of paper.

speaker: JESS
words: I can’t believe you just said that.

speaker: PARIS
words: Well, it’s true, the Beat’s writing was completely self-indulgent. I have one word for Jack Kerouac – edit.

speaker: JESS
words: It was not self-indulgent. The Beats believed in shocking people, stirring things up.

speaker: PARIS
words: They believed in drugs, booze, and petty crime.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, then you can say that they exposed you to a world you wouldn’t have otherwise known. Isn’t that what great writing’s all about?

speaker: PARIS
words: That was not great writing. That was the National Enquirer of the fifties.

speaker: JESS
words: You’re cracked.

speaker: PARIS
words: Typical guy response. Worship Kerouac and Bukowski, God forbid you’d pick up anything by Jane Austen.

speaker: JESS
words: Hey, I’ve read Jane Austen.

speaker: PARIS
words: You have?

speaker: JESS
words: Yeah, and I think she would’ve liked Bukowski.

speaker: PARIS
words: What are you doing?

speaker: JESS
words: Salt and pepper dip. Only way to eat a fry.

speaker: PARIS
words: Really?

speaker: RORY
words: It’s fast food gospel.

speaker: PARIS
words: Mm. That’s good. That’s really, really good.
[phone rings]

speaker: JESS
words: You like hot sauce?

speaker: PARIS
words: I don’t know. Should I?

speaker: JESS
words: I think it’s wise.

speaker: RORY
words: [answers phone] Hello?

speaker: DEAN
words: Hey.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, hey. Where are you?

speaker: DEAN
words: On my way to see you – if that’s okay?

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, well -

speaker: DEAN
words: I know you wanna be alone, so I’ll only stay a minute. I just wanna say hi.

speaker: RORY
words: We just said hi.

speaker: DEAN
words: Well, I wanna say hi a little closer.

speaker: RORY
words: But, I’m a mess, really. It’s not pretty. You won’t recognize me.

speaker: DEAN
words: Well, then put a name tag on ‘cause I miss you.

speaker: RORY
words: I miss you too, but –

speaker: DEAN
words: But what?

speaker: RORY
words: But. . .Paris is here.

speaker: DEAN
words: Why?

speaker: RORY
words: She freaked out about a grade and she wanted to go over some notes, and you know Paris – she will not be denied.

speaker: DEAN
words: Okay, then I’m not really ruining your alone night, someone else did that.

speaker: RORY
words: Yes, but –

speaker: DEAN
words: I’ll see you in a sec. [hangs up]

speaker: JESS
words: I can’t get into poetry. It’s kind of like, geez, just say it already, we’re dying here.

speaker: RORY
words: Wow, you know, I just noticed the time, and it’s getting really late.

speaker: JESS
words: It’s seven o’clock.

speaker: RORY
words: I know, but Paris and I still have a lot more studying to do. Jess, please thank Luke for me. It was really nice of him.

speaker: JESS
words: Who was on the phone?

speaker: RORY
words: No one.

speaker: JESS
words: No one wouldn’t happen to be heading over here now, would he?

speaker: RORY
words: Jess.

speaker: PARIS
words: What’s going on?

speaker: RORY
words: Nothing.

speaker: JESS
words: Dean’s on his way over and Rory doesn’t want him to find me here.

speaker: RORY
words: Why?

speaker: JESS
words: Yeah, why?

speaker: RORY
words: You know why.

speaker: JESS
words: We’re just eating dinner.

speaker: RORY
words: Jess, I’m asking you as a friend, just please leave now.

speaker: JESS
words: You really want me to go?

speaker: RORY
words: I really wanna avoid a fight with Dean.

speaker: JESS
words: Okay, I’m going.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you.

speaker: JESS
words: Ow!

speaker: RORY
words: What?

speaker: JESS
words: Ooh! I just twisted my ankle. I better go lie down.

speaker: RORY
words: Jess!

speaker: JESS
words: God, you’re no fun when you’re tense. Are you sure you want me to go? ‘Cause maybe this whole thing can be solved between me and Dean if we just sat down and had a little heart to heart. He can tell me his issues, I’ll tell him mine.

speaker: RORY
words: Jess!

speaker: JESS
words: I promise I’ll speak slowly.

speaker: RORY
words: Bye! [pushes him out the front door]

speaker: JESS
words: Okay, well, give him my best, would ya? [sees Dean in the front yard] Actually, I guess I could do that myself.

speaker: RORY
words: Dean, Jess just came by to bring me some food.

speaker: JESS
words: From Luke’s.

speaker: RORY
words: He wanted to make sure I ate.

speaker: JESS
words: Luke did.

speaker: RORY
words: Right, Luke did.

speaker: JESS
words: Personally, I could care less if she eats.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, true, he could care less.

speaker: JESS
words: I see you brought a little something, too. Is that ice cream? That’s so nice. A tiny little ice cream package just big enough for two. Hey, are you guys gonna feed each other ‘cause that’s just so darn cute. Oops. You’re doing that towering over me thing. Huh. I tell you, you’ve really got that down. It helps that you’re twelve feet tall, but this Frankenstein scowl really adds to the whole – .

speaker: RORY
words: Jess.

speaker: JESS
words: Okay, I’m going. Look, man, I really was just dropping off some food, so don’t get all West Side Story on me, okay? [leaves]

speaker: RORY
words: So, do you wanna. . . [Dean walks into the house] . . .come in?
[cut to kitchen]

speaker: DEAN
words: What the hell is going on?

speaker: PARIS
words: Hi.

speaker: RORY
words: Dean, you remember Paris, right?

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, hi. So Jess just dropped this off, huh?

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, well. . .

speaker: DEAN
words: Now I know you eat fast, but this is a lot of food to put away that quickly, even on your best day.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, so he didn’t just drop it off but - .

speaker: DEAN
words: You told me you were doing laundry tonight.

speaker: RORY
words: I was.

speaker: DEAN
words: And now you are here with Jess.

speaker: RORY
words: And Paris!

speaker: DEAN
words: Jess, Rory!

speaker: RORY
words: Ah, well, I swear, I didn’t –

speaker: DEAN
words: You didn’t what? You didn’t know he was coming over?

speaker: RORY
words: I didn’t.

speaker: DEAN
words: And you also didn’t know he was gonna stay, right?

speaker: RORY
words: It just happened.

speaker: DEAN
words: How does that just happen?

speaker: RORY
words: Well, he was. . .and the diner, the diner was. . .and I. . .

speaker: DEAN
words: And you what? What? Say something!

speaker: RORY
words: Stop yelling!

speaker: DEAN
words: You totally lied to me!

speaker: RORY
words: I didn’t!

speaker: DEAN
words: Turn the situation around, Rory! How’s it looking?

speaker: RORY
words: It’s looking complicated and I’m trying to explain it to you.

speaker: DEAN
words: Ugh, that’s crap.

speaker: PARIS
words: It’s my fault.

speaker: DEAN
words: What?

speaker: PARIS
words: It’s my fault that Jess was here. I saw him in the diner the day I came to Stars Hollow and I thought he was cute and since I’m not great at the whole ‘batting the eyelashes, look at my belly shirt’ kind of thing, I asked Rory to help me. I thought if she could maybe get him over here, we’d have a chance to talk and. . .I don’t know, it seems totally stupid now and it obviously didn’t work – shock, but that’s why he was here. Thanks for trying to cover for me.

speaker: RORY
words: That’s okay.

speaker: PARIS
words: Anyway, I should get going. I’m probably gonna break out in some sort of rash any second now. [leaves kitchen]

speaker: DEAN
words: So Paris likes Jess?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah.

speaker: DEAN
words: Rory, is this true?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes it is.

speaker: DEAN
words: Paris and Jess?

speaker: RORY
words: I know. There’s no explaining attraction. Dean, listen to me, if I was going to have anyone over tonight, it definitely would’ve been you.

speaker: DEAN
words: Okay.

speaker: RORY
words: Really?

speaker: DEAN
words: Well, if you say so, then I have to believe it, don’t I?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: DEAN
words: Well, okay then. I’m sorry that I yelled.

speaker: RORY
words: Completely justified under the circumstances.

speaker: DEAN
words: I’m gonna get going.

speaker: RORY
words: No, wait, don’t you wanna stay for ice cream? We could hang out.

speaker: DEAN
words: Nah, I’m just gonna go.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m still seeing you tomorrow, right?

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, sure.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey.

speaker: DEAN
words: See you tomorrow. [leaves]
[Rory walks into the living room]

speaker: RORY
words: What was that?

speaker: PARIS
words: What?

speaker: RORY
words: That, the story, the save? You helped me. Why would you do that?

speaker: PARIS
words: I don’t know, it just came out.

speaker: RORY
words: You have no idea what you did.

speaker: PARIS
words: It was no big deal.

speaker: RORY
words: No, it was a very big deal. It was a huge deal.

speaker: PARIS
words: Well, you helped me tonight when you didn’t want to, so I owed you.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you.

speaker: PARIS
words: You’re welcome. Okay, well, I’ll let you get back to your alone night.

speaker: RORY
words: You should stay.

speaker: PARIS
words: Stay?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah. We could hang out, maybe watch some TV. You can even spend the night if you don’t wanna drive all the way back to Hartford.

speaker: PARIS
words: Spend the night, like a slumber party?

speaker: RORY
words: Sort of.

speaker: PARIS
words: You’re just doing this because I lied to Dean for you, right?

speaker: RORY
words: I’m doing this because it’s what you do with friends.

speaker: PARIS
words: We’re friends?

speaker: RORY
words: I’m not sure if there is an exact definition for what we are, but I do think it falls somewhere in the bizarro friends-ish realm. Come on, stay.

speaker: PARIS
words: Okay. But if you’re doing all this so you can freeze my bra, I’ll kill you.

speaker: RORY
words: Duly noted.
CUT TO RESTAURANT
[Lorelai and Emily are eating dinner.]

speaker: EMILY
words: This is either the greatest steak I’ve ever eaten, or I’m so hungry, I’m delirious. Pass the horseradish, please.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I never knew you were a spicy girl.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, believe me, I can handle my heat. One summer when we were first married, your father and I stayed at this little village in Thailand where we spent two weeks eating viciously hot chilies and skinny-dipping.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah, Mom!

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, you certainly couldn’t put your clothes on after eating those things.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stop it! I like to think of parents the old fashioned way – separate bedrooms.

speaker: FEMALE SINGER
words: And now it’s time for my favorite part of the evening – our salute to the Chairman of the Board.

speaker: MALE SINGER
words: I sure hope that’s not b-o-r-e-d.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Uh, uh, Mom?

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Remember the man who wasn’t staring at you?

speaker: EMILY
words: He wasn’t staring at me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, well, he’s coming over.

speaker: EMILY
words: What?

speaker: CHAD
words: Excuse me, I hope I’m not interrupting, but I couldn’t help but notice that you two are having more fun than anyone at the bar.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, that’s true, we are.

speaker: CHAD
words: Well, good, I’ve come to the right place. Hi, I’m Chad.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hi Chad. I’m Lorelai. This is my mother, Emily.

speaker: CHAD
words: Your mother?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Chad, if the next words out of your mouth are, ‘you can’t possibly be old enough to be her mother,’ I’m gonna have to cause you severe physical pain.

speaker: CHAD
words: Emily, do you share this rather extreme opinion?

speaker: EMILY
words: I think I’ll stay out of it.

speaker: CHAD
words: In that case, let me just say that I think you look more like sisters than mother and daughter. Yeah, I went for a variation.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’ll let it slide this time.

speaker: CHAD
words: So, are you two, uh, local or just visiting?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Visiting. Mom’s from Hartford and I’m from a town, uh –

speaker: CHAD
words: Hartford? Great town, great town. A little of the old, little of the new. You like living there?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, yes, I do.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And how about you, Chad – where do you live?

speaker: CHAD
words: Here – and by here, I mean this very bar stool.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow, admitting right off the bat that you spend your life at a bar. Do you find that people are impressed by that?

speaker: CHAD
words: Until now.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, I love this song.

speaker: CHAD
words: It’s a great song for dancing.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, it is.

speaker: CHAD
words: Help me out here, will ya?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I think he’s asking you to dance, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: What? Oh, no, I, uh, I couldn’t.

speaker: CHAD
words: Rumor has it you love this song.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, well, yes, but I don’t dance.

speaker: CHAD
words: Oh, come on. I can’t believe that.

speaker: EMILY
words: And I shouldn’t leave my daughter alone.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s okay. The sitter’ll be here any minute.

speaker: EMILY
words: Really, I’m serious, you should ask someone else.

speaker: CHAD
words: Is it my dancing? Because you two could work out some kind of ‘save me’ signal in case I really embarrass you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Go ahead, Mom. It’ll be fun.

speaker: CHAD
words: Come on, the song’s almost over. You’ll hardly have to spend any time at all with me.

speaker: EMILY
words: All right.
[they start dancing]

speaker: BARTENDER
words: Hey, your mom looks good out there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yup, she sure does.
[When the song ends, Emily starts to walk away but Chad pulls her closer for another dance. After a few seconds, Emily breaks away from him.]

speaker: EMILY
words: I’m sorry, I have to go.
[She quickly walks over to the coat check area. Lorelai gets up and follows her]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, what’s wrong?

speaker: EMILY
words: We’re leaving.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What happened?

speaker: EMILY
words: I shouldn’t have been doing this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Doing what?

speaker: EMILY
words: Fraternizing with other men.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, what are you talking about?

speaker: EMILY
words: I practically cheated on your father.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You did not cheat on Dad.

speaker: EMILY
words: I danced with another man.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’ve danced with other men before.

speaker: EMILY
words: Not like that, not without your father present.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, Mom, it was just a dance. You were having fun.

speaker: EMILY
words: I need to get out of here. How hard is it to find a coat?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, you didn’t do anything wrong.

speaker: EMILY
words: I don’t know why I let you take me to this chop house in the first place. I don’t go to chop houses. What were you thinking?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Need food now.

speaker: EMILY
words: And I certainly don’t eat at bars. Hookers eat at bars.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Only if they can’t get a table.

speaker: EMILY
words: You’re not funny. You knew this whole evening made me uncomfortable and yet you kept pushing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I was trying to do everything right. You manipulated me into taking this trip and still I came. You told me I was acting like a teenager, so I tried to be nicer. You said you needed to eat, so I made that happen.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, by sitting me at a bar where you practically forced me to engage in inappropriate behavior.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: EMILY
words: You let me get sixty-fortied!

speaker: LORELAI
words: You are crazy! Do you know that? We were having dinner, Mom, a nice dinner. We were talking. Hell, we were having fun.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, so watching your mother make an ass of herself was fun for you?

speaker: LORELAI
words: God, you know, you don’t have any right to complain about this relationship if you’re not willing to let your guard down once in awhile and just be normal.

speaker: EMILY
words: There’s a way for a mother to behave in front of her daughter. I’m sorry if you don’t like it, but that’s how it is.
CUT TO BIRCH GROVE SPA
[Lorelai is in her room, packing. There’s a knock on the door.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Come in.

speaker: EMILY
words: I called the bellman to get the bags. He said it would be around ten minutes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay.

speaker: EMILY
words: Thank you for agreeing to leave early.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No problem.

speaker: EMILY
words: I guess this whole thing was a silly idea anyway. I don’t know why I pushed it. We can’t even get through a dinner without a fight. What was I thinking putting us together for a weekend?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It was a nice thought, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, well, I guess it’s the thought that counts, isn’t it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, if you want, um, I can just bring our bags down. I mean, they’re not that heavy, and then we don’t have to wait.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, that sounds fine. Why can’t we have what you and Rory have?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory and I are different mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: We’re mother and daughter, you’re mother and daughter. It shouldn’t be that different.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s completely different. It couldn’t be more different.

speaker: EMILY
words: But why?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I grew up in a different environment.

speaker: EMILY
words: You mean an oppressive environment.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, Mom, I mean a different environment. And plus, I was so young when I had Rory.

speaker: EMILY
words: So because I waited until I was grown and married, I can’t have a relationship with my daughter?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, then, why?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory and I are best friends, Mom. We are best friends first and mother and daughter second, and you and I are mother and daughter always.

speaker: EMILY
words: I wasn’t taught to be best friends with my daughter.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know.

speaker: EMILY
words: I was taught to be a role model for my daughter.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know that, too.

speaker: EMILY
words: I did what I thought was right. I did what I thought I had to do to protect you, and because of this we have no relationship.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, Mom, we have a relationship.

speaker: EMILY
words: We do? What? What is our relationship?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, we. . .

speaker: EMILY
words: Exactly.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Maybe an intense weekend together was not the best idea for us. Maybe we need to start with something simpler.

speaker: EMILY
words: Like what, a brisk walk around the block?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I hate exercise.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, well, as long as you find this amusing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, come on. There has to be something else. Something small.

speaker: EMILY
words: Like what? Where are you going? Lorelai, you just don’t walk out on a person. That’s rude. That’s a robe.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, this is my robe. And I want you to go into your room and get your robe. And then, exactly at the same time, we are gonna shove these robes in our suitcases and we are gonna walk out that door and leave with them.

speaker: EMILY
words: That’s stealing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, it is.

speaker: EMILY
words: You want me to steal a robe? That’s how we’re going to bond?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, you love this robe. You’ve talked about nothing else except this robe since we got here, so this robe will be symbolic of our trip together.

speaker: EMILY
words: But that’s crazy. As soon as they check the rooms, they’re going to know the robes are gone and then they’re going to charge our credit card.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, how do you know?

speaker: EMILY
words: Because that’s what the little tag on the hanger says.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, the little tag on the hanger could be right, or the little tag on the hanger could just be there trying to scare us away from trying. Either way, whether we get away with it or not, it’s something we did, you and I.

speaker: EMILY
words: You’re serious.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am folding this robe up.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am putting this robe in my bag.

speaker: EMILY
words: That’s lunacy.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am zipping up the bag that contains the robe.

speaker: EMILY
words: I have a perfectly good robe at home.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Now the only question is, am I doing it alone?

speaker: EMILY
words: Did you ever steal a robe with Rory?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, Rory would never steal. She’s far too moral for that. You, however, vicious trollop – what’s it gonna be?

speaker: EMILY
words: I should have my head examined.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We’ll make an appointment when we get back.

speaker: EMILY
words: You do know, in the course of one night, you’ve turned me into an adulterer and a thief.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’ll have you working at the chicken ranch by the end of the month.

speaker: EMILY
words: I cannot believe I’m doing this.
CUT TO LUKE’S DINER
[Lorelai and Rory are sitting at a table.]

speaker: RORY
words: You actually got Grandma to steal a bathrobe?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Although I did catch her trying to return it while I was getting the car.

speaker: RORY
words: Still.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know, life with my mother, one step forward, five thousand steps back. It’s kinda like the spastic polka.

speaker: KIRK
words: Excuse me, are you done?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, uh, sorry, not yet.

speaker: KIRK
words: So, you’re gonna eat that half a piece of bacon that’s been sitting there for ten minutes?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Kirk.

speaker: KIRK
words: I mean, of course, you must be if you’re saying you’re not done because that’s the only thing left in front on you, unless you eat plates.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Go away.

speaker: KIRK
words: You are hogging the table.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You keep it up, I’m ordering seconds.

speaker: KIRK
words: Fine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, Paris looked a little green this morning.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, she had a sugar/carb hangover of monumental proportions.

speaker: LORELAI
words: People don’t realize it, but it takes years of training to be able to eat the way we do.

speaker: RORY
words: Don’t I know it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, what’s on the agenda for today?

speaker: RORY
words: Let’s see. Dean, Dean, and uh. . .oh, did I mention Dean?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow, he must’ve been crazy mad last night.

speaker: RORY
words: I’d say that was a fair assessment.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, I gotta get to the inn.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. Well, I’m probably gonna have dinner with Dean, so. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’ll have the house to myself tonight. Life’s funny, isn’t it?

speaker: RORY
words: I simply cannot stop laughing. I’ll get the check.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thanks hon.

speaker: RORY
words: [walks to the counter] Hey Luke.

speaker: LUKE
words: What, you find a nail in your food? I swear to God, Tom, you are dead! You hear me? Dead!

speaker: RORY
words: There’s nothing wrong with the food, Luke.

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh, sorry Tom.

speaker: RORY
words: I just wanted to thank you.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, for what?

speaker: RORY
words: For the care package. It was really sweet of you.

speaker: LUKE
words: What care package?

speaker: JESS
words: Hey Luke, I think they hit the water line again.

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh, what? [walks away] Tom, you are dead! You hear me? Dead!

speaker: RORY
words: Huh, interesting.

speaker: JESS
words: Hey, you wanna pay?

speaker: RORY
words: I don’t think Luke knew anything about the food last night.

speaker: JESS
words: That’ll be twelve-fifty.

speaker: RORY
words: Which means you lied about why you came over.

speaker: JESS
words: I don’t have any quarters. I’m gonna have to give you nickels.

speaker: RORY
words: Now why would you lie about something like that?

speaker: JESS
words: Here’s your change. Come again soon.

speaker: RORY
words: You wanted to come over.

speaker: JESS
words: I have to get back to work.

speaker: RORY
words: You’re squirming. I’ve never seen you squirm. It’s entertaining.

speaker: JESS
words: Oh yeah?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah.
CUT TO OUTSIDE
[Lorelai walks out of the diner. Dean is standing out front.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Dean, hey.

speaker: DEAN
words: Hey.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory’s just inside paying. She’s coming out to meet you after.

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, we’re gonna spend the day together.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s great.

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, it is.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, listen, Rory told me everything that happened last night. She feels just terrible about it.

speaker: DEAN
words: I know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good, you should. It’s just one of those freaky unfortunate things that happens.

speaker: DEAN
words: Freaky and unfortunate, yeah.

speaker: LORELAI
words: She had nothing to do with Jess coming over. Believe me, she did not want him there.

speaker: DEAN
words: That’s what she told me. And Rory wouldn’t lie, right?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, Rory wouldn’t lie.
THE END
OPEN AT LORELAI’S HOUSE
[The phone is ringing. Lorelai rushes down the steps to answer it, but the machine picks up before she can get it.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: [on answering machine] Hey, we’re not in, so – ah, bashed my thumb! Leave a message.

speaker: EMILY
words: I am so tired of this ridiculous machine. I get it every time I call. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, that was close.

speaker: EMILY
words: You are Rory are always out. What is it that you do? Is your house that awful you can’t be in it? It’s too much excitement, if you ask me. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, what isn’t in Emily’s rules of conduct?

speaker: EMILY
words: I don’t want to talk to a machine, I’ll just call you later. [hangs up]

speaker: LORELAI
words: If you had your way, Mother, you’d lock us up like veal. That’s what she wants, veal children.
[phone rings again]

speaker: LORELAI
words: [on answering machine] Hey, we’re not in, so – ah, bashed my thumb! Leave a message.

speaker: EMILY
words: It’s me again. Listen. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re talking into the machine.

speaker: EMILY
words: Don’t forget that my DAR meeting is on Tuesday. Please. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s burned into my brain. It’s there forever.

speaker: EMILY
words: . . . it’s at three o’clock and all the women are all extremely punctual.

speaker: LORELAI
words: When I’m senile and ga-ga and drooling into a cup, and yet I can’t remember my name, I’ll still remember that your DAR meeting is that Tuesday.

speaker: EMILY
words: . . . this Tuesday. I’ll talk to you about some other things later. [hangs up]

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’d have to be deprogrammed by cult deprogrammers to get that Tuesday out of my brain.
[phone rings again]

speaker: LORELAI
words: [on answering machine] Hey, we’re not in, so – ah, bashed my thumb! Leave a message.

speaker: EMILY
words: Your phone message is annoying. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: Unbelievable.

speaker: EMILY
words: Do you know how annoying it is?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I think I have a standard against which to measure it.

speaker: EMILY
words: . . .to it yourself. Have you heard it lately?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I can’t because I’m amputating my ears.

speaker: EMILY
words: . . .and that thumb bashing thing, is that a joke? Why is it that your jokes are always. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah, an earless world, what a dream!
[opening credits]
CUT TO INDEPENDENCE INN
[In the dining room, Emily is sitting at a table tasting soups as Lorelai and Sookie stand by watching.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Haven’t you already tasted that one, Mom?

speaker: EMILY
words: Mm.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Twice, you’ve tasted that soup twice.

speaker: EMILY
words: You’re keeping a running count?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m morbidly fascinated.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, Lorelai, when you’re tasting anything, the first taste acclimates the palate, the second establishes the foundation, and the third is to make your decision.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, there’s going to be a third taste.

speaker: EMILY
words: Isn’t that what this is for – to taste the soups?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Taste them, yes, not to orally deduce their chemical structures.

speaker: EMILY
words: Everything has to be at your pace.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Or at a pace that can’t be measured by the number of times the earth circles the sun.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: You know, actually, I’ve heard that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: One is to acclimate, two is for foundation, and three to judge.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Traitor.

speaker: EMILY
words: The women in my DAR group are very picky. My God, when the pate at the meeting Heddy Cubbington organized was slightly less chilled than appropriate, she was ostracized for a month.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, that hussy Heddy had it coming.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [to employee] Oh, gosh, they’re on time for once, good. Hey, do me a favor and, uh, tell Michel that on Wednesday. . .

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai, please.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thanks. Um, Mom, I got a lot of other things happening here that can’t come to a grinding halt for this.

speaker: EMILY
words: So your full attention for a short period is too much to ask for?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, I’m already giving you more attention than I would someone in these circumstances. No one else would get eight separate soups to taste for a lousy DAR. . .sorry, a not lousy DAR meeting. We only do this for weddings.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, would you like me to pay for the tasting?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, Mom, just decide in this calendar year.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Hey, can I. . .I’m sorry. The mushroom is a great choice. It’s super popular, and it’s my Jackson’s favorite.

speaker: EMILY
words: Whose?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Jackson, my fiancé.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, you’re getting married?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: To the best man in the world.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh hey, while we’re on the subject, um, bridesmaids outfits?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Ooh, I’m way ahead of you. I’ve already got a couple of ideas.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Is one of them having me design and make them so I don’t secretly hate what you pick and then harbor a secret grudge against you for the rest of our lives?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It is now.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’ll do it!

speaker: SOOKIE
words: We’re a good team.

speaker: MICHEL
words: That fellow’s on the phone from the restaurant.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Who?

speaker: MICHEL
words: The flannel man with the protruding ankles.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, Luke?

speaker: MICHEL
words: I forgot his name from the desk to here, that’s how memorable he is.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, thank you.

speaker: EMILY
words: Where are you going?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, to talk to Luke.

speaker: EMILY
words: Can’t you call him back?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Have your third taste, Mom. [leaves]

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai! Is she always this scattered?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: She’s the stablest person I know.

speaker: EMILY
words: That’s very sad. Well, I think you’re right, mushroom.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Great.

speaker: EMILY
words: So, tell me more about your wedding.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, I’ve just started planning so there’s not that much to tell.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, have you decided on anything yet? The location or the music for the ceremony, maybe?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, we’ll probably just, you know, wind up playing something off a CD.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, CD’s can be very unreliable. They break sometimes, or they skip, or the person assigned to turn them on and off gets distracted and the whole ceremony is ruined.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I hadn’t thought of that.

speaker: EMILY
words: Have you thought about live music?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Well. . .

speaker: EMILY
words: A nice string ensemble.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Ooh, that sounds nice.

speaker: EMILY
words: There are a couple of wonderful groups I could recommend.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Sure. I mean, I guess it doesn’t hurt to check ‘em out.

speaker: EMILY
words: No, it doesn’t. Mushroom soup.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: String quartet.
CUT TO FRONT DESK
[Lorelai walks over and picks up the phone]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, hi.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hello.

speaker: LUKE
words: How’s it going?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Pretty good, pretty good. How’s things with you?

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh, not bad. Dropped some eggs.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Bummer.

speaker: LUKE
words: Hazard of the business. Am I catching you at a bad time?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, no, it’s kind of slow here. So slow, in fact, that Michel and I were about to get the tetherball out.

speaker: LUKE
words: That’s the thing with a ball tethered to a rope?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, I never knew that’s where the tether comes from.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, it’s tethered. It’s tied, like an anchor is tethered to a rope on a boat.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Neat, neat.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, most people probably don’t put that together.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Probably not.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, anything else?

speaker: LUKE
words: Uh, yeah, actually – if I needed a room or two for a couple of days, would that be possible?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You need rooms?

speaker: LUKE
words: Like nine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You need nine rooms?

speaker: LUKE
words: Just for a couple of days, Wednesday and Thursday.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Uh, well, I can take care of that. What’s it for?

speaker: LUKE
words: Uh, just got some family coming in.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Reunion? ‘Cause we can get the tetherball out.

speaker: LUKE
words: Nah, funeral.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, my Uncle Louie died last night and I’m arranging the funeral for him.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, Luke, I’m so sorry. Here I was babbling about tetherball.

speaker: LUKE
words: And you weren’t babbling.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, you’ve got nine rooms, Wednesday and Thursday.

speaker: LUKE
words: You sure?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s a done deal.

speaker: LUKE
words: Thanks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke, I’m so, so sorry.

speaker: LUKE
words: It’s okay. It sounds like he went peaceful. He was eighty-five.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But it’s always hard. Um, are you okay?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, I’m okay.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Can I help you with anything else?

speaker: LUKE
words: No, the rooms are help enough.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are you sure, ‘cause I’m dealing with my mom now and I’d be happy to rush over and help with whatever. You’d be doing me a favor.

speaker: LUKE
words: The rooms are all I need, thanks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re welcome.

speaker: LUKE
words: Well, I gotta go.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Call if you need anything.

speaker: LUKE
words: I will. By the way, that French guy’s a putz.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh yeah, he knows.

speaker: LUKE
words: All right, see ya.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Bye.
CUT TO SIDEWALK
[Lorelai and Rory are walking down the street towards the diner]

speaker: RORY
words: It’s so sad.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know.

speaker: RORY
words: Was Luke, like, shaken over his uncle dying?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don’t know. He’s so unflappable. It’s hard to tell.

speaker: RORY
words: The man definitely can’t be flapped.
CUT TO INSIDE LUKE’S DINER
[Lorelai and Rory walk through the door. Luke is on the phone while several customers try to get his attention.]

speaker: WOMAN
words: Can I get another cup of coffee?

speaker: LUKE
words: In a minute.

speaker: SY
words: Hey, is that my food?

speaker: MAN
words: More coffee here, too, please.

speaker: LUKE
words: In a minute.

speaker: SY
words: Is that my food?

speaker: KIRK
words: More coffee for me, too.

speaker: LUKE
words: Shut up, Kirk.

speaker: SY
words: Is that my food?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yes, Sy, that’s your food.

speaker: SY
words: Well, can I have it?

speaker: LUKE
words: I’m doing all I can here, folks.

speaker: KIRK
words: I asked nicely.

speaker: MAN
words: Hey, hey, watch the cord!

speaker: LUKE
words: Try ducking.

speaker: KIRK
words: You should update to a cordless.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, whatcha doing? Watch, watch it.

speaker: LUKE
words: Ah, buh buh buh. . .thanks, thanks, I’m on the phone.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We noticed.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, I can’t serve and be on the phone.

speaker: RORY
words: We noticed that, too.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But your reenactment of Jerry Lewis in The Diner Guy is gonna wow the critics.

speaker: RORY
words: Where should the poached eggs go?

speaker: LUKE
words: Crank in the hat.

speaker: SY
words: Hey, I’m not a crank! You’re a crank, crank!

speaker: RORY
words: He is a crank.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And the French toast?

speaker: LUKE
words: Lady with the giant purse. Ah, yup.

speaker: MAN
words: This is not good.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, fall back cowboy.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yo, whoa, whoa, whoa – what are you doing?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Come here. Just stay on the phone and give me these. Where do they go?

speaker: LUKE
words: Table by the window.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Don’t you number your tables?

speaker: LUKE
words: No.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You should number your tables.

speaker: LUKE
words: What good would that do? If I said a number, you wouldn’t know what table was what number.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But all restaurants number their table. You should number your tables.

speaker: LUKE
words: Table five, they go to table five.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Cool. Which one is that?

speaker: LUKE
words: Table by the window.

speaker: LORELAI
words: By the window, Elma.

speaker: RORY
words: Got it, Gertie.

speaker: KIRK
words: Hello? How 'bout that coffee?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I got it.

speaker: LUKE
words: Thanks.

speaker: KIRK
words: But, but – mine's a quarter caf.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Huh?

speaker: KIRK
words: Three-fourths decaf, one-fourth caffeinated.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I four-fourths don't care.

speaker: KIRK
words: Fill it up.

speaker: LUKE
words: Sorry about this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's okay.

speaker: LUKE
words: Sometimes you get the world’s full of people who micromanage their lives to the point where they can't wait an extra second for anything.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We're running out of coffee.

speaker: LUKE
words: I'll make some more.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I got it.

speaker: LUKE
words: Do you know how?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Do I . . . ugh. . .I am Cathy Coffee, mister, the bastard offspring of Mrs. Folger and Juan Valdez.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey Luke, where's Jess?

speaker: LUKE
words: I don't know.

speaker: RORY
words: School?

speaker: LUKE
words: Please. He’s probably upstairs.

speaker: RORY
words: Really? Excuse me.

speaker: LUKE
words: It's too strong.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, it's not.

speaker: LUKE
words: No, it's too strong.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're on the phone.

speaker: LUKE
words: Not everybody likes it that strong.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, then I shall convert them. I am the Jehovah's coffee girl.
CUT TO UPSTAIRS
[Rory knocks on Luke’s apartment door]

speaker: RORY
words: Jess, open up! I know you're in there.

speaker: JESS
words: My, aren't we bright eyed and bushy tailed.

speaker: RORY
words: Luke needs you downstairs.

speaker: JESS
words: Why?

speaker: RORY
words: Because he's on the phone with someone and Caesar's off today and the place is packed and he needs help.

speaker: JESS
words: I'll be down in a minute.

speaker: RORY
words: No, now.

speaker: JESS
words: I'm in the middle of something.

speaker: RORY
words: Just assume that Jeannie’s gonna get Major Healey out of whatever scrape he's in.

speaker: JESS
words: Gee, thanks for spoiling it for me.
CUT TO THE DINER

speaker: KIRK
words: I need some more Equal.

speaker: LORELAI
words: There’s one right there.

speaker: KIRK
words: I need seven

speaker: LORELAI
words: Seven? You’re not squirreling these away in your pocket for home use, are you, Kirk?

speaker: KIRK
words: No, I use seven in my coffee.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, good, then allow me. [pours seven Equals into his cup] There you go. Go ahead and give that a taste, see if it’s to your liking.

speaker: KIRK
words: Okay. [takes sip] Perfection.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good.
[Jess stumbles into the diner, followed by Rory]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, you’re very graceful.

speaker: JESS
words: She pushed me.

speaker: RORY
words: Sue me.

speaker: JESS
words: I could’ve broken my neck.

speaker: RORY
words: As long as it’s not your arm. We need your arm.

speaker: JESS
words: Despot.

speaker: LUKE
words: Took me twenty minutes to get pass this place’s stupid busy signal, then they put me on hold forever.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Who’s keeping you on hold?

speaker: LUKE
words: That mortuary in Florida where my uncle’s at.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Florida? I thought he was in the area.

speaker: LUKE
words: No no, he spent most of his life here but retired to Orlando, so I gotta ship the body back here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Aw, he wanted to be buried in Stars Hollow?

speaker: LUKE
words: Nah, my dad wanted my uncle buried in Stars Hollow right next to him.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s nice.

speaker: LUKE
words: Well, they were really close, and Louie didn’t have any wife or kids to look out for things and before my dad died, he asked me if I’d look out for him.

speaker: LORELAI
words: For Louie?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, he just wanted me to make sure he got a proper funeral. You know, respectful, dignified.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No horseshoe carnation wreaths, got it. Good man, that dad of yours.

speaker: LUKE
words: And since Louie’s a war veteran, the town Revolutionary War reenactors will attend the service, do the salute thing, you know. I mean, it makes me nauseous, but my dad wanted it. [on phone] Yeah, hi, I’m still here. . .Yes, the deceased is Louie Danes. . .Right. . .No, Hartford’s not too far, I can do that. Thanks. [hangs up] Great, that’s done. Uh, okay, I should probably go pick out a coffin before he gets here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Great, go.

speaker: LUKE
words: I have to close up.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, you don’t. You’re covered.

speaker: LUKE
words: You don’t have to do this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We don’t mind. Go. It’ll give me a chance to number all the tables.

speaker: LUKE
words: Be my guest.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Also, are they arranged like this for any particular reason?

speaker: LUKE
words: Don’t change anything.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s totally not feng shui.

speaker: LUKE
words: Gertie.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Go.
CUT TO DOOSE’S MARKET
[A customer walks up to Taylor]

speaker: MRS. CASSINI
words: Excuse me, Taylor, where are your Brussels sprouts?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: My supplier was out of them this week, Mrs. Cassini. Maybe next week.

speaker: MRS. CASSINI
words: Oh, I wanted to make them tonight.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Sorry.

speaker: MRS. CASSINI
words: Okay, I’ll just try across the street. Thank you.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: You’re welcome. Across the street? [goes outside] What is that?

speaker: MRS. CASSINI
words: It’s a farmer’s market. Isn’t it wonderful? It just opened this morning and. . .I see sprouts!
[Taylor walks over to the farmer’s market]

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Who’s the proprietor here?

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: That would be me. What can I do for you?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Wait a minute, I know you. You’re that long-haired freak that wanted to be town troubadour even though that weird brown-corduroy-jacket-wearing freak was already it.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: That’s right, good memory! How are ya? [hugs him]

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Let go of me!

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Don’t like to be touched, that’s cool. Got a little David and Lisa thing happening? Made a mental note, no problem. Can I help you find something?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I just want to know what inspired you to open a produce stand right across the street from my market.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Oh, is that your market?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Yes, that’s my market.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Well, it’s real nice, homey. Bought a box of tissues there – good stuff, good stuff.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Excuse me? Your parsley – is it priced per bunch or per pound?

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Per pound, beautiful.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Mmm, good deal.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Patty!

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Oh, hi Taylor, how are you?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: You mean not counting the knife sticking in my back?

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Oh, sure honey, whatever.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: There must be some mistake – this just isn’t right.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: It’s all approved by the proper authorities. I followed the rules, it’s what my father taught me. Cop for twenty years, got shot in the butt. Good man – tips over sometimes when he sits – but good man.

speaker: MRS. CASSINI
words: Beautiful sprouts.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: For a beautiful lady.
