speaker: MRS. CASSINI
words: Thank you.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I feel sick.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: That’ll be four dollars. See ya, Mr. Doose.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I wanna lie down.
CUT TO INDEPENDENCE INN
[Michel is at the front desk as Lorelai walks over]

speaker: MICHEL
words: Ah, Lorelai, good – tell me about the nine rooms set aside here. There’s no name anywhere that I can see, and no credit card to hold them. Mistake?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, it’s for Luke.

speaker: MICHEL
words: For who?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke from Luke’s Diner.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Nine rooms for Luke from Luke’s Diner?

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s right.

speaker: MICHEL
words: French fry convention?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, just personal.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Milkshake symposium?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No Michel, it’s something personal and I’m vouching for him.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Soda pop seminar?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stop!

speaker: MICHEL
words: Pickle party?

speaker: LORELAI
words: He’s got nine rooms, now stifle.
[Lorelai walks away as Emily enters the inn]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, Mom, hi there.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai, hello.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m sorry, did we get our signals crossed? I don’t remember making an appointment with you.

speaker: EMILY
words: We have to make appointments to see each other?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, but – good one.

speaker: EMILY
words: I’m not here to see you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, this isn’t about the DAR meeting?

speaker: EMILY
words: No, that’s all ready to go. I’m here to meet with Sookie.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie?

speaker: EMILY
words: I’m a little late, traffic was awful. Excuse me, would you?
CUT TO DINING ROOM
[The tables are set with fancy place settings and flowers.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh my God.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Aren’t they beautiful?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Gorgeous. What are they for?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: My wedding.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Your wedding?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Emily, hi!

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, is this everything I said it was?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: And more.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What do you mean they’re for your wedding?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, it’s this company’s sample place setting. Emily set me up with them. They did Celine Dion’s wedding, and Steven Spielberg’s daughter’s Jack Russell Terrier’s Bark Mitzvah.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re putting me on.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I couldn’t make that up.

speaker: EMILY
words: Excuse me, this one’s slightly asymmetrical. Fix these.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, um, what is with the fancy place settings? I thought you were just gonna keep it simple.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It is simple.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It lights up.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Just flip a switch, simple.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Tell me how my mother got so involved in all of this.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: She’s not that involved. She just mentioned the other day when she was here that she knew some people that could make some samples of stuff for us, like table settings and flower arrangements.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But we were gonna do the flowers ourselves.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I know, but what a hassle that would be.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s to save money – flowers cost a fortune.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Yeah, but, the sampling of – what they’re doing today – it’s free. I’m not committed to any of this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I hope not.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It’s true – I say no, it all goes away. Not a penny is spent.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: And it’s fun.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don’t wanna take away your fun, I just want you to be careful. See, you’ve entered Emilyland.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Emilyland?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s an upside down world where the Horchow House is considered low-rent and diamonds less than twenty-four carats are Cracker Jack trinkets and Bentleys are for losers who can’t afford a Rolls.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: But I’m okay, really.

speaker: LORELAI
words: All right. I have to help Luke with the lunch rush today, so I gotta go.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Go, we’re fine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay. Bye Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: [picks up a glass] Is that a fingerprint? My God, that’s a fingerprint! Who touched this? Let me see your hands!
CUT TO LUKE’S DINER
[Taylor is sitting at a table mumbling to himself as Rory walks by]

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Turnips, turnips, turnips. . .

speaker: RORY
words: What?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Huh?

speaker: RORY
words: What about turnips?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Why did you say turnips?

speaker: RORY
words: Because you said turnips.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: No, I didn’t.

speaker: RORY
words: I think you did.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Nope.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: But I’ve got turnips – good ones, too. They’re not as big as that crinite freak’s turnips, but who needs bloated turnips? Mine are unassuming. I have nice, humble turnips.

speaker: RORY
words: Okie dokie. [walks to the counter] Taylor’s wigging.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know. He’s been sitting there like the final days of Dick Nixon for almost an hour.

speaker: RORY
words: Keep an eye on him.
[a customer walks in and sits at the counter]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hello there, how’s it going?

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: Very good, young lady. You’re still serving breakfast?

speaker: LORELAI
words: We serve it all day. What’ll you have?

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: Two eggs up on toast.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Up, huh?

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: Yup.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wouldn’t you rather have ‘em scrambled?

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: Nope, up’s how I like ‘em.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Come on, scrambled’s better. Give it a shot. Say you want two scrambled eggs on toast, please?

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: Okay, young lady, two scrambled eggs on toast.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Adam and Eve on a raft and wreck ‘em! That’s real live diner talk, see? The wreck ‘em is the scrambled part.

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: I deduced that.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I don’t believe it, I don’t believe it!

speaker: LORELAI
words: What’s the matter?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: That’s Babette with an armload of rutabagas, and there’s Miss Patty again – since when does she eat so much fruit?
[Kirk enters the diner]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey Kirk.

speaker: KIRK
words: Hello. Where’s Luke?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, he’s busy with some stuff so Rory and I are helping out. What can I get you?

speaker: KIRK
words: I don’t know. I want lunch, but I’m not sure what to get.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I have a suggestion. How about a hamburger with some strawberry ice cream with chocolate sauce for dessert?

speaker: KIRK
words: Sounds good.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yo, burn one, then pass me a pink stick and throw some mud on it! God, I love this business.
[The proprietor of the farmer’s market enters the diner]

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Boy, it’s freezing out there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, it’s quite a cold snap. How ‘bout a hot blonde with sand?

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Coffee with cream and sugar would be great, thanks. Make sure its’ foot’s out the door.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Put it in a cup to go, got it.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: This icy weather hasn’t kept customers away, though. They just keep coming. A lot of vegetable soup being eaten tonight, yesiree. Hope I don’t put the good people at Campbell’s out of business. Oh, hey Taylor. Didn’t notice you there.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Hello.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Taking a little break? I don’t see how if you’re anywhere near as busy as I am. Keep waiting for a lull, I never get one. I say to the people, ‘hey, I’ll be back in a jif’ and they’re – look at ‘em – they’re lining up out there already.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Well, FYI, Van Halen hair, I’m plenty busy, but a good well-groomed businessman with properly prepared staff can take a break now and then.

speaker: KIRK
words: It probably helped that your store was completely dead, too.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: It was not dead.

speaker: KIRK
words: I thought it was closed when I walked by, but then I saw Gabby sitting at the cash register reading a tabloid.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Shut up, Kirk.

speaker: KIRK
words: Tapping on the counter with one of those little astrological scrolls.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Enough.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Here you go.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Gracias. Oh boy, it’s a mob scene. [leaves]
CUT TO UPSTAIRS
[Lorelai knocks on Luke’s apartment door]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke, it’s me.
[Luke opens the door]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey. I brought you a wimpy with a rose pinned on it.

speaker: LUKE
words: A what?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Turkey burger with onions.

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh, thanks. Come on in.

speaker: LORELAI
words: How’s the money pit coming?

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh, just uh. . .that’s it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What’s the matter?

speaker: LUKE
words: Nothing. None of them are coming – not a one.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Who?

speaker: LUKE
words: My relatives – the ones I booked all the rooms for – not one is coming to Louie’s funeral.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re kidding – why?

speaker: LUKE
words: I don’t know, which lame-o excuse do you wanna hear first? A bunch of ‘em claimed they can’t get outta work.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s not so lame-o.

speaker: LUKE
words: Randy and Barbara don’t wanna miss their brat kid’s rugby semifinal.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rugby has semifinals?

speaker: LUKE
words: My sister never even called back. My cousins Paul and Jim, who my dad helped put through college, said they were too exhausted from a fishing trip. And slightly disturbed cousin Franny said she can’t leave because her Petey’s sick.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Son?

speaker: LUKE
words: Parrot.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Petey the parrot?

speaker: LUKE
words: I saw the stupid thing once on a visit, flapping its wings like crazy, banging around, squawking the only two words it knows over and over – Petey and gorgeous. Gorgeous, Petey, gorgeous, Petey!

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s disturbing.

speaker: LUKE
words: My family’s disturbing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m so sorry.

speaker: LUKE
words: This is wrong, this is not how it’s done. A family member dies, you pay your respects – period.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Look at it this way – if they don’t wanna be there, you don’t want them there.

speaker: LUKE
words: My dad wanted ‘em to be there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know. But hey, Louie lived in Stars Hollow most of his life, so a lot of people from here will be there, right?

speaker: LUKE
words: Right.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know it’s upsetting, but maybe it’s better this way.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, I guess. I really hate that bird.
[Rory walks into the apartment]

speaker: RORY
words: Hey Mom?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What’s up, honey? You got a herd of bulls shopping for China?

speaker: LUKE
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Customers – how long have you owned a diner?

speaker: RORY
words: Sorry. Jackson’s outside, he wants to talk to you, he says it’s important.

speaker: LORELAI
words: About what?

speaker: RORY
words: I don’t know. He seems upset.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah. All right. You okay?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, thanks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You might wanna study up on that diner talk.

speaker: LUKE
words: I’ll do that tonight.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey Luke, where’s Jess?

speaker: LUKE
words: I don’t know, he’s probably out playing basketball or something.

speaker: RORY
words: That little punk.
CUT TO DINER
[Lorelai walks down from upstairs and stops at the counter to help a customer]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, hey, uh, can I take your order?

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: Yes, uh, bacon, lettuce and tomato sandwich, no mayo.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yo, uh, I need a piggy piggy with a green bla. . .uh, green bed, green blanket. . . BLT, no mayo! Rats.
CUT TO OUTSIDE
[Lorelai walks out of the diner over to Jackson]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Jackson?

speaker: JACKSON
words: I’m a miserable man.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What’s up?

speaker: JACKSON
words: Remember that sweet, simple, affordable little wedding Sookie and I agreed on with minimal disagreement – no disagreement, in fact – perhaps the first time in the history of wedding planning that a couple agreed one hundred percent on everything?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Gone. Ancient history. It’s the Library of Alexandria, it’s the Colossus of Roads, it’s Pop Rocks, it’s over, and do you know why?

speaker: LORELAI
words: My mother?

speaker: JACKSON
words: Look! [points to Sookie and Emily near the gazebo]

speaker: LORELAI
words: What are they doing?

speaker: JACKSON
words: They’re measuring the town.

speaker: LORELAI
words: They’re what?

speaker: JACKSON
words: They’re measuring the entire town with tape measures.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh my God.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Your mother got hers at Neiman Marcus. It’s platinum with gold leaf – it costs more than my car!

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am so sorry.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Look, I love Sookie and I want her to have what she wants, but . . . you see what they’re doing now?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah.

speaker: JACKSON
words: According to their diagrams, that’s where the sixteen-piece orchestra goes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: How are they gonna fit a sixteen-piece orchestra in the gazebo?

speaker: JACKSON
words: Oh, they wanna move the gazebo.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: JACKSON
words: A gazebo that’s been there for a hundred years and they wanna move it. Who moves a gazebo? What kind of twisted mind even thinks about moving a gazebo?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, I’ll take care of this.

speaker: JACKSON
words: She’s so excited.

speaker: LORELAI
words: She’s brainwashed. She’s Patricia Hearst and my mother is the SLA.

speaker: JACKSON
words: I just hope it’s not too late.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I hope so, too.
[Rory walks by, pulling Jess behind her]

speaker: JESS
words: Watch the shirt!

speaker: RORY
words: Cork it!
CUT TO THE DANCE STUDIO
[Taylor is at the podium leading a town meeting]

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Well, it seems the right thing to do, Taylor.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I concur. When one gazes at Stars Hollow, one can easily overlook a vital component of its beauty and that’s the humble yet spunky twinkle light.

speaker: JESS
words: Holy cow.

speaker: LUKE
words: It doesn’t get fruitier.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Harry’s House of Twinkle Lights has been an integral part of this time for twenty years, so it’s only right that we honor his retirement. So I hereby designate next Tuesday, Harry the Twinkle Light Man from Harry’s House of Twinkle Lights Day.

speaker: JESS
words: Well, that just trips off the tongue.
[Lorelai and Rory walk in]

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Late again, are we?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, I hope I’m not pregnant!

speaker: TAYLOR
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are these seats taken?

speaker: LUKE
words: Don’t drag me into this.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: You really have to work on your punctuality, Lorelai. I banged the meeting in a half an hour ago.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Uh, dirty!

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I’m gonna take advantage of this unexpected pause in our proceedings to confer with Miss Patty about the next item on our agenda.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What’d we miss?

speaker: LUKE
words: Harry’s retiring.

speaker: RORY
words: The twinkle light man?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What do we do for twinkle lights?

speaker: LUKE
words: Go to any discount store?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Blasphemy.

speaker: RORY
words: What are you doing here anyhow? This is a town meeting for people who participate in and care about the town.

speaker: JESS
words: Well, Corky’s Country Cavalcade on public access was pre-empted, so I thought I’d check out the next best thing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m surprised you have time to be here.

speaker: LUKE
words: I don’t, but I haven’t been able to get any of the war reenactors on the phone and I have to confirm them for Louie’s funeral.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: All right now, the last order of business is a matter relating personally to me, therefore I'm going to give Miss Patty my gavel.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Again, dirty!

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Stop that. Now don’t go power mad.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Oh, all right, gee. Now the chair recognizes Taylor Doose. Taylor, you have the floor.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Thank you, Patty. My issue, ladies and gentlemen, is in the form of a grievance against this hirsute hippie who opened a produce stand in the park.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh yeah, killer veggies.

speaker: SY
words: Tasty.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: The squash is beautiful.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Sexy – it’s sexy squash.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Sexy or not, I demand that this man produce his permit post haste.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Got it right here.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Mm hmm, just what I thought. This is not the proper permit for this kind of business. This is a type twenty-four B, otherwise known as a cart, kiosk, cart, kiosk permit. This is not valid for your business.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Why’d you say it twice?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Hmm?

speaker: BABETTE
words: You said cart, kiosk, cart, kiosk.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s repetitive.

speaker: RORY
words: And redundant.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s repetitive.

speaker: RORY
words: And redundant.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We certainly are entertaining, Mac.

speaker: RORY
words: Indubitably, Tosh.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: It’s not redundant. It’s three separate things. It’s a cart, a kiosk, and a mechanical hybrid referred to as a cart-slash-kiosk, hence cart, kiosk, cart/kiosk.

speaker: BABETTE
words: He did it again.

speaker: KIRK
words: He’s been stressed lately. His store is deserted.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I’ll make it simple. This is for businesses that roll in in the morning and roll out at night. Emphasis on the word roll – rolling businesses, businesses that roll.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: But I carry my tables out at night.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: But you’re supposed to roll them, Rapunzel, and carrying isn’t rolling, is it? I mean, did anyone hear the word rolling come out of his mouth? Check the transcript, I think you’ll find one word missing – rolling!

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Transcript?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, Taylor, this isn’t Charlie Rose.

speaker: BABETTE
words: He’s losing his marbles.

speaker: ANDREW
words: It’s just a personal vendetta.

speaker: KIRK
words: His store is deserted.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: I think that we should end the meeting right here, Taylor.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Wait a second, wait a second! You there, when Lady Godiva here wanted to be town troubadour over you, I stood by your side. Why aren’t you backing me now?

speaker: TROUBADOUR
words: ‘Cause you left me twistin’ for a long time before you did, Taylor, and it didn’t feel good. I even wrote a song about the experience.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, I heard it. It’s called "Taylor Left Me Twistin’."

speaker: RORY
words: Oh yeah, it’s really good.

speaker: TROUBADOUR
words: You think? Because I’m having a little trouble with the chorus. Taylor left me twistin’, he set my eyes a mistin’. I’m just not sure if it has that thing, though, you know?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, no, I love that part. I actually thought that maybe at the end you could do more about the sweater. We’ll talk.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: I’m gonna wrap this up.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Now, Patty, how would you feel if this guy decided to open the long-haired freak school of dance or the long-haired freak diner, Luke? Or the long-haired freak bookstore? It’s not good, right?

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: All right, everybody who agrees that we would not feel good about that, say aye.

speaker: ALL
words: Aye!

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Meeting adjourned, goodnight.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Another fun one!

speaker: LUKE
words: Taylor, hold on a sec!

speaker: RORY
words: [to Jess] Don’t you have some cleaning up to do over at the diner?
CUT TO OUTSIDE
[As people exit the meeting, Luke runs over to Taylor and the other reenactors]

speaker: LUKE
words: Guys, hold it, come on, you heard me calling you, stop!

speaker: TAYLOR
words: What is it, Luke?

speaker: LUKE
words: What do you mean, what is it? My Uncle Louie’s funeral is tomorrow afternoon and I haven’t heard from any of you. The man was a World War II veteran, that’s what you reenactor freaks do – you go to vet’s funerals, so you’re gonna be there, right? Hello?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: You said you were gonna talk to him, Sy.

speaker: SY
words: Bert said he was gonna do it.

speaker: BERT
words: It’s Taylor’s job.

speaker: SY
words: You always pass the buck.

speaker: LUKE
words: Talk to me about what, guys?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: You might as well know, Luke. We don’t wanna go to Louie’s funeral.

speaker: LUKE
words: What?

speaker: ANDREW
words: We all hated Louie.

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh, come on, that’s not true.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: He always had a scowl on his face, not a kind word for anybody. He would light those hideous cigars, blow smoke in people’s faces and then spit after each puff.

speaker: SY
words: He was disgusting.

speaker: ANDREW
words: And mean.

speaker: KIRK
words: He kicked my dog when I was a kid.

speaker: SY
words: He hit on my wife repeatedly.

speaker: KIRK
words: Toto was always different after that.

speaker: SY
words: My wife was much affected as well.

speaker: KIRK
words: I’d toss her something to fetch and she’d start to run after it and halfway there she’d forget what she was doing.

speaker: SY
words: She never enjoyed her soap operas the same after that.

speaker: KIRK
words: She’d just lie down and go to sleep.

speaker: LUKE
words: This is an exaggeration.

speaker: BERT
words: We’re not exaggerating. We threw a big party when he left town!

speaker: SY
words: I made love to my life that night like I never have.

speaker: KIRK
words: My Toto barked a happy bark, then quietly stopped breathing. She was old.

speaker: LUKE
words: I don’t believe this.

speaker: ANDREW
words: Come on, Luke. You knew the guy.

speaker: LUKE
words: This man was my uncle, okay, and a war veteran. He deserves a veteran’s funeral, but hey, if you guys are too lazy to show up, then. . .

speaker: TAYLOR
words: He’s the lazy one. Never once did he participate in a town function. In fact, when we reenactors gathered, he’d throw things at us.

speaker: SY
words: And not soft things, hard things.

speaker: BERT
words: Rocks, and small tools.

speaker: LUKE
words: Okay, I’ve heard enough.

speaker: SY
words: And he got meaner as he got older. Never married, never had kids.

speaker: BERT
words: A real loner.

speaker: LUKE
words: To hell with you guys, who needs you! I might just throw rocks and small tools at you myself next time I see ya!

speaker: TAYLOR
words: A defensive hothead, just like Louie!

speaker: BERT
words: They’re practically clones.
CUT TO INDEPENDENCE INN KITCHEN
[Sookie is sitting in front of a computer and Michel is looking over her shoulder as Lorelai walks in]

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh my God, this is so hi-tech.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey. What’s going on?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I’m downloading wedding stuff from Prague.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, you’re kidding.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It’s streaming in right now. That’s Internet talk – streaming. Did you know that? And did you know it’s not called Czechoslovakia anymore? It’s just Czech Republic. Slovakia is its own separate thing. It’s weird, isn’t it? It’s like if we just suddenly started saying there’s no more Connecticut, it’s just Connec. . . Ticut.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie, what are you downloading from Prague?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Oh, this will much amuse you.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Color samples for the big ceramic stands.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Big ceramic stands for what?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: For the giant papier-mâché mushrooms.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What are the papier-mâché mushrooms for?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: For the midgets dressed like angels to dance under, silly.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh my God.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Emily found the best papier-mâché mushroom maker in Paris. He’s much better than the guy that makes them in Belgium – what a hack.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie, honey, I need you stop staring and streaming for one second. We need to talk.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Please, please do not talk her out of these things. I do not want to die without seeing midgets dancing with a mushroom.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stay out of this.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Oh, you’re no fun.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What is it honey?

speaker: LORELAI
words: The danger of Emilyworld is that you don’t always know you’re in it, when actually you are.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Aw, not this Emilyworld stuff again

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie, have you run the numbers on any of this? What is this costing you?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I don’t know the full cost but your mother is getting me fifty percent off everything. She is so connected.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, but fifty percent off a load of money is still half a load of money. You don’t have half a load to spend.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Well, if I scrimp I can afford a quarter load.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s still too much.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Well, your mother said she’d chip in a little.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie, that is way, way, way inappropriate.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I didn’t take her up on it but it was nice.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie, this isn’t you, the midgets and the mushrooms and God knows what else. And it isn’t Jackson either.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What do you mean?

speaker: LORELAI
words: We talked.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: You and Jackson talked?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m sorry but he came to me all upset, and I love you Sookie and I love him too and it just seemed like it was time for me to meddle.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: He was upset?

speaker: LORELAI
words: He was pretty upset.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Why didn’t he just talk to me?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Because he’s Jackson, he wants you to be happy and to give you everything you want. So what it comes down to is – is this what you want?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Well, maybe the midgets are a little over the top. And the mushrooms. . . oh my God, it’s all sounding so silly now.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re coming out of it, keep going.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: No, no, it’s not what I want! We were supposed to keep this nice and simple. God, we had it all worked out.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So go back.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I will go back. That is, if Jackson still wants to marry me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Of course he still wants to marry you.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I’m gonna call him and I’m gonna tell him it’s all changing back.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good.
[Lorelai’s cell phone rings]

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Ooh, I should call and cancel some stuff first. I’ve gotta call Belgium and Oslo and, uh, oh, Copenhagen, Bora Bora.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What did you order from there?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I’m gonna shield you from that one.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thanks. [answers phone] Hello?. . .Luke!. . . Slow down, slow down. . . Okay, I’ll come right over. [hangs up] I gotta go. Call, call, and welcome back, friend.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Thanks. Ooh, I’m gonna start with Hong Kong. I’m hoping those acrobats can get another gig.
CUT TO FUNERAL HOME
[Luke is waiting impatiently near a casket as Lorelai walks in]

speaker: LORELAI
words: There you are. What – .

speaker: LUKE
words: It won’t close.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: LUKE
words: The lid.

speaker: LORELAI
words: To what? [sees casket] Oh, hello. . . Louie.

speaker: LUKE
words: That’s Louie.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Nice tan. So, now, you say the lid won’t close?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yes, the lid won’t close.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Did you buy the right size?

speaker: LUKE
words: Of course I bought the right size.

speaker: FUNERAL DIRECTOR
words: It’s the model we recommend for those of medium height and weight.

speaker: LUKE
words: And he’s of medium height and weight.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So then why won’t it close?

speaker: LUKE
words: Because of the stuff.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What stuff?

speaker: LUKE
words: The stuff. He left a list of stuff he wanted buried with him.

speaker: FUNERAL DIRECTOR
words: It’s not uncommon.

speaker: LUKE
words: It’s a very long list. His fishing reel, bowling trophy, a flask, his antique dueling pistols, his copy of Sherman’s Memoirs.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So is all the stuff in there now?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yes, it is. I shoved it in the best I could but now it won’t close which defeats the entire purpose of having a damn casket in the first place.

speaker: LORELAI
words: May I?

speaker: LUKE
words: Give it a shot.
[Lorelai tries to push the lid close, but it pops back up]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Whoa!

speaker: LUKE
words: The football signed by Johnny Unitas gives it that bounce.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What if we moved the gas mask and the pith helmet down towards the feet?

speaker: LUKE
words: That end already has every baseball card he ever bought, thousands of them.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, bungee cord! No. Um, what if we got some people from the office here, you know, accounting or whatever, to sit on the lid and then we could latch it? Do you have anybody you could spring. . .hm. I’m out of ideas.

speaker: LUKE
words: So am I. You know what, to hell with this. To hell with this!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke, now come on.

speaker: LUKE
words: I can’t deal with this anymore!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, it has to be dealt with.

speaker: LUKE
words: No, it doesn’t. It’s not as if he deserves my help or my respect.

speaker: LORELAI
words: The man was your uncle.

speaker: LUKE
words: He was a jerk!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Don’t say that.

speaker: LUKE
words: No, no, Taylor and the guys were right. I was cutting Louie slack out of respect for my dad, but the man was rotten and mean and selfish all his life. For God’s sake, he’s even selfish in death. Other people would’ve loved to have had those baseball cards. I would’ve loved to have those baseball cards. He’s got Lou Gehrig’s rookie card, Joe DiMaggio, Willie Mays, tons of others – but no! My uncle, King Tut, has to take all of them to the afterlife with him!

speaker: FUNERAL DIRECTOR
words: Sir, your voice.

speaker: LUKE
words: I’m done, I’ve had it. From now on, it’s just the bare minimum and that’s it. Dig a big hole and just dump the casket in unlatched. If stuff falls out, fine. Just pile on enough dirt and make sure nothing’s showing! [leaves]

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m assuming that wouldn’t be appropriate either?

speaker: FUNERAL DIRECTOR
words: No.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I didn’t think so.
CUT TO LUKE’S DINER
[Jess is walking around the tables refilling coffee]

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: Young man, where’s the young lady we’ve heard so much about who’s using those delightful old diner phrases to place people’s orders? It sounds so fun. Could you point her out for us?

speaker: JESS
words: No. [walks to counter] That’s everyone. I’ll be upstairs.

speaker: RORY
words: Thanks for doing the very least you could possibly do.

speaker: JESS
words: You’re welcome.
[Luke enters the diner]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke, there you are. I was worried.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, sorry, I should’ve called. Thanks for covering again. This’ll be the last time, I promise.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s okay. Where were you?

speaker: LUKE
words: Well, at first, I walked around a bunch, ya know, just trying to clear my head. Saw a lot of Hartford – and what a cesspool.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, you’re not a city man.

speaker: LUKE
words: Then I calmed down after awhile and I figured dumping Louie’s body in an open grave with all his stuff probably would be a little cold.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Just a tad.

speaker: LUKE
words: So I got a Yellow Pages and I found the Big and Tall Casket Shop in Hartford.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re kidding.

speaker: LUKE
words: Nope, I found a casket that would fit my hundred and sixty pound uncle and his hundred and forty pounds of stuff, got the lid to shut the first time we tried it, so the funeral’s on as scheduled.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good.

speaker: LUKE
words: I still don’t know why I’m doing this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re doing it for your dad.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, I guess. Although he’s dead so he’d never know if I was doing it any different.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He knows. He’s got the big Luke picture screen on twenty four hours a day and he watches and smiles. And you’re doing it ‘cause you’re you.

speaker: LUKE
words: Hey, I’m gonna change real fast and you can retire from your diner career forever.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh no, it’s fun. I came up with some new diner phrases. Do you know what a Lucky Duck Cluck is?

speaker: LUKE
words: Not offhand.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s foie gras with chicken and green shamrock frosting.

speaker: LUKE
words: Why would anyone ever order that?

speaker: LORELAI
words: If they’re high. [sees Emily enter the diner] Ugh, good grief.

speaker: LUKE
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Bad vibe sandwich just came in, better retreat.

speaker: LUKE
words: I won’t be long. [goes upstairs]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hi Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: Since when do you work here?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m just lending a hand. What’s going on?

speaker: EMILY
words: I went by the inn to work with Sookie on her wedding.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah?

speaker: EMILY
words: And she fired me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m sure she didn’t fire you.

speaker: EMILY
words: She claims to have changed her mind on all the things we had planned.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, maybe she did.

speaker: EMILY
words: No, she didn’t. I know what’s behind this. That is, who’s behind this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, it was getting to be too much for her and too much for her fiancé.

speaker: EMILY
words: I knew it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, these are not wealthy people, do you understand that? They’re saving for a home and your midgets were dancing between them and their dreams.

speaker: EMILY
words: You say midgets like it’s so absurd.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Do you hear yourself?

speaker: EMILY
words: I don’t see what was so wrong with my just helping Sookie plan her wedding.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, come on.

speaker: EMILY
words: What, come on?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You weren’t planning Sookie’s wedding.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, then, whose wedding was I planning?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mine.

speaker: EMILY
words: Don’t be ridiculous.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, your vision for this wedding and all the over the top stuff and the gazillion dollar flowers and bunting and champagne fountain and the Haute Couture dress – who’s wearing that wedding dress in your mind’s eye, Mom? Is it Sookie or is it me?

speaker: EMILY
words: I wasn’t planning your wedding, Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Right.

speaker: EMILY
words: The wedding I was planning was for Sookie. The mushrooms and colors, they all seemed like fun. A little crazy, just like she is. It definitely was not for you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: I know that in a million years, you would never let me plan your wedding. I gave up on that dream a long time ago. Yours was going to be a Russian winter theme – the Romanovs.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Before the firing squad, I assume?

speaker: EMILY
words: Snow white roses, trees with white lights and candles, snow everywhere, you arriving in a silver sleigh with white horses.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow.

speaker: EMILY
words: You hate the idea.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, no, I just – .

speaker: EMILY
words: You just hate it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, it just doesn’t seem like me.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, well, it would’ve been beautiful.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m sure it would’ve been.

speaker: EMILY
words: Anyhow, it’s obvious that wouldn’t even be appropriate anymore being as I’m probably standing in your reception hall.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Excuse me?

speaker: EMILY
words: Burgers and fries for the dinner? The bride walks down the aisle with a ketchup dispenser in her hand.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Please tell me what you’re talking about.

speaker: EMILY
words: I’m talking about Luke.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke? Mom!

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, it’s obvious, Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, it’s not, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: You’re with him constantly.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He feeds me.

speaker: EMILY
words: You bring up his name constantly.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Once again, he feeds me.

speaker: EMILY
words: The moment he calls, you run to his side.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He’s my friend, he needed me, I had to be there.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, I know you did.
[Luke comes down the stairs and walks over to them]

speaker: LUKE
words: Hi.

speaker: EMILY
words: Hello. I have to go. I’ll see you for dinner tonight, Lorelai. And Luke, I’m sure I’ll see you again soon. What do you think of the Romanovs?

speaker: LUKE
words: They probably had it coming.

speaker: EMILY
words: A match made in heaven.
CUT TO CEMETERY
[Lorelai and Luke are alone at the funeral]

speaker: REVEREND
words: We’re here, of course, to honor Louie, to pay our respects and to bid him a sorrowful goodbye.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are you okay?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah. I’m not big on funerals in general.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Nobody is.

speaker: REVEREND
words: He passed away in his sleep, so the end came peacefully for Louie, which I’m sure is a great comfort to all who knew him.

speaker: LUKE
words: The passing away part was a great comfort for all who knew him.

speaker: REVEREND
words: I didn’t know him.

speaker: LUKE
words: Good thing.

speaker: REVEREND
words: But I understand he was a fine man, destined to be missed by many.

speaker: LUKE
words: Especially ones that were suing him.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stop. Sorry father.

speaker: REVEREND
words: Reverend.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Right.

speaker: REVEREND
words: Now let us witness Louie Danes as he is interred and brought to the Lord.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It was a nice service. Nice and, um, intimate.

speaker: LUKE
words: I guess everybody deserves something at the end. Thanks for coming.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I wouldn’t have missed it.

speaker: LUKE
words: That ain’t me, is it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: LUKE
words: What Taylor said about me being like Louie, a loner, never being married and stuff. I mean, I am getting crankier as I get older, he’s not so far off.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You are not your uncle. I mean, would Louie ever build someone a chuppah, or help fix things around someone’s house without being asked, or make a special coffee cake with balloons for a girl’s sixteenth birthday?

speaker: LUKE
words: Rory told you about that?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes. And would Louie have taken in his sister’s kid without hesitating and without asking for anything in return?

speaker: LUKE
words: No one would’ve trusted Louie with their kid. He probably would’ve forgotten to feed him or something.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You get my point?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, I get it. [he hears drumming] What’s that? [he sees one of the reenactors walking onto the cemetery] Is that Andrew?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I believe it is.
[the other reenactors arrive]

speaker: LUKE
words: That’s all of them.
[The reenactors start doing their salute]

speaker: LUKE
words: Thanks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s what your dad wanted.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah. Oh, I know Louie would’ve hated this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s just a fringe benefit.
CUT TO SIDEWALK
[Luke and Lorelai are walking toward the diner]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Do you think he’s in heaven?

speaker: LUKE
words: I hope so, just so my dad can kick his butt around the place.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Can you kick when you’re in heaven?

speaker: LUKE
words: It’s probably frowned upon.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, plus you’re all see-through and gauzy and your dad’s foot could go right through him.

speaker: LUKE
words: This is a silly conversation. What’s all this?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I have no idea.
CUT TO INSIDE LUKE’S DINER
[Luke and Lorelai walk into the diner, which is packed with people]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hi.

speaker: LUKE
words: What’s going on?

speaker: RORY
words: It’s kind of like a wake.

speaker: LUKE
words: A wake?

speaker: LORELAI
words: For Louie?

speaker: RORY
words: I thought you set it up

speaker: LORELAI
words: I didn’t set it up.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, it’s going well, anyway. People brought a ton of food if you’re hungry.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Huh.

speaker: LUKE
words: This is unexpected.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Very.

speaker: LUKE
words: Don’t you have wakes for people you like?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I think it might be for you.

speaker: LUKE
words: Am I dead?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Face it, Luke, people like you.

speaker: LUKE
words: Shut up.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And with charm like that, how can they resist?
[The farmer’s market proprietor walks up to Taylor]

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Hey Taylor, cool threads. Very "One if By Land."

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Mm hmm.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: I see you’re digging into the vegetables.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Thanks for the play by play.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Brought those myself. Hey, how was the funeral?

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Shouldn’t you be tending to your little stand out there, friend?

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Oh, the stand’s gone.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: What?

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: It’s gone, I’m all packed up, I’m outta here.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: I don’t get it.

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: I just grow all that stuff in my back yard and as of yesterday, sold it all.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: You sold it all?

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Sold it all, made enough money to do some traveling. Have you ever been to Israel? Turbulent, I know, but I thought I’d go down and try to plant some peace down there, know what I mean? See if it grows and see if it spreads.

speaker: TAYLOR
words: Shut up. Why did you put me through all that hoohah at the town meeting if your vegetable business was just temporary?

speaker: PROPRIETOR
words: Actually, you put yourself through it, Taylor. You put yourself through it.
[Rory walks over to Jess]

speaker: RORY
words: Nice spread.

speaker: JESS
words: People have too much free time in this town.

speaker: RORY
words: You did a good thing.

speaker: JESS
words: What do you mean?

speaker: RORY
words: I thought my mom set this up. Turns out she didn’t.

speaker: JESS
words: So? Wasn’t me.

speaker: RORY
words: It wasn’t?

speaker: JESS
words: Nah, no way. It wasn’t me.

speaker: RORY
words: If you say so.

speaker: JESS
words: Look, the crazy ballet teacher called and asked when Luke was getting back from the funeral, if I could unlock the door. I came down, I unlocked the door, then went back upstairs and back to sleep.

speaker: RORY
words: So you did do a little something.

speaker: JESS
words: I unlocked the door.

speaker: RORY
words: So that people could come in here and put this together. Nice.

speaker: JESS
words: Nice for them, not for me.

speaker: RORY
words: You facilitated it, you made it happen, so I guess that means that you’re officially apart of our town now.

speaker: JESS
words: Hey, wait a minute.

speaker: RORY
words: Welcome.

speaker: JESS
words: I am not part of this town.

speaker: RORY
words: See you for some tree planting over at the Arbor Day Festival, buddy.

speaker: JESS
words: Yeah, well maybe I can knock over a liquor store while everyone else is planting those stupid trees.

speaker: RORY
words: As long as it’s a liquor store in town, neighbor.
[Rory walks over to a table where people are telling stories about Louie]

speaker: SY
words: So, like I say, it’s Halloween, right, and we’re lucky Louie doesn’t have razor wire around his yard, you know how he is. So finally one of the neighborhood kids, he gets all courageous and he goes sauntering up to the door and he goes ‘trick or treat!’ Louie finally throws the door open, looks at him and says, ‘Did you get a Reese’s cup tonight?’ And the kid looks in his bag and he says, ‘Yes sir, I did.’ So Louie grabs it, says ‘thank you very much!,’ then slams the door in his face.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m sorry I never met him.

speaker: LUKE
words: He was colorful.

speaker: KIRK
words: I never trick or treated again.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: So one day I’m at the post office, I’m in line when Louie just about knocks me over and he cuts in line. I said, ‘Louie, there’s a line!’ So he says, ‘Kiss my butt!’ and I said, ‘You mind your manners!’ and he says, ‘Please kiss my butt!’ and drops his pants!

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, I got one, I got one. Louie was parked outside Al’s Pancake World, and I was trying to pull in the space behind him, when all of a sudden, he starts to back up, so I honk my horn and he – it was just a little honk, no big deal – but he . . .
THE END
OPEN AT ELDER GILMORE RESIDENCE
[Lorelai, Rory and Emily are sitting at the table staring at the food.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: No.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We’re starving.

speaker: EMILY
words: We’re waiting for your father.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s gonna get cold.

speaker: EMILY
words: We are waiting for your father.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We’ve been waiting forever.

speaker: EMILY
words: We have not been waiting forever.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Forever. Godot was just here. He said ‘I ain’t waiting for Richard,’ grabbed a roll, and left. It’s been forever.

speaker: EMILY
words: When we gather as a family, we eat as a family. We don’t eat in shifts – you know that and Richard certainly knows that.

speaker: RORY
words: When did he get that antique car anyhow?

speaker: EMILY
words: A couple of horrible weeks ago.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What happened to the oil painting hobby of his?

speaker: EMILY
words: Ah, you know your father. When he couldn’t foresee rivaling Cezanne, he lost interest so he bought that car. Lorelai!
[Lorelai spits out the piece of candy she was about to eat]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, it’s not dinner, it’s just my private stash.

speaker: EMILY
words: It’s eating and we’re not eating.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, you’re bound by the rules of the Geneva Convention, Mother, just like everyone else. Hey, no one told me it was casual Friday.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Hello everyone. You haven’t started?

speaker: EMILY
words: Of course we haven’t started, we were waiting for you. I thought you were almost done.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, I was but this car has a mind of its own. As I turned to leave it began spraying some sort of green solution at me.

speaker: RORY
words: Yuck.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Yuck, indeed. Well, go on, start.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh!

speaker: RICHARD
words: No sense in waiting for me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Coolness!

speaker: EMILY
words: Stop!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Gomer said!

speaker: EMILY
words: We are waiting for you, Richard. In thirty–five years, I have never ever started a dinner without you unless you were out of town or seriously ill. Elsa, take everything away and keep it warm! Now please go upstairs and get ready so we can all enjoy a nice family dinner. . .together.

speaker: RICHARD
words: I’ll be right back.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Right back, Dad, like right back. In fact, change on the way upstairs. And make it a Navy shower – quick soap, quick rinse and no excessive posing! Hungry.
CUT TO LUKE’S DINER
[Rory and Lorelai walk through the door]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey there. Anywhere?

speaker: LUKE
words: Anywhere you want.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Could you move please?

speaker: CUSTOMER
words: What?

speaker: LUKE
words: Anywhere where there’s not people.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, well, like I’m a mind reader. I was just joking. Hmm, that’s funny.

speaker: RORY
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Something’s different here, something’s changed.

speaker: RORY
words: Impossible.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I swear, there’s something.

speaker: RORY
words: You know, I’d be very disappointed if something changed in here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Why are you so anti-change?

speaker: RORY
words: Because most change sucks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s true, it does. Uh! The chalkboard!

speaker: RORY
words: What about it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Luke’s special omelet. That is brand new.

speaker: RORY
words: A new special? His four-slice French toast has been up there since I was born!

speaker: LORELAI
words: You just gotta let that go, baby.

speaker: LUKE
words: What can I get you?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You have a new special.

speaker: LUKE
words: I sure do.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Nice. What is the special omelet?

speaker: LUKE
words: You won’t like it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: How do you know?

speaker: LUKE
words: Because you’ve been eating here for years and I know what you like, and you won’t like it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Can I at least hear what it is?

speaker: LUKE
words: Fine. It’s three eggs with bits of bacon.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I like bacon.

speaker: LUKE
words: Cubed tomatoes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sounds good.

speaker: LUKE
words: Swiss cheese and a dash of oregano.

speaker: LORELAI
words: A dash, he says.

speaker: LUKE
words: I’ve got other customers here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m gonna go with the special omelet.

speaker: LUKE
words: Okay.

speaker: LORELAI
words: With a side of bacon.

speaker: LUKE
words: There’s bacon in the omelet.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, then skip the bacon.

speaker: LUKE
words: The side of bacon?

speaker: LORELAI
words: The bacon in the omelet.

speaker: LUKE
words: Hold the bacon.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Can I get Jack cheese?

speaker: LUKE
words: On the side?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Instead of Swiss, Swiss is so stringy.

speaker: LUKE
words: Fine, Jack cheese.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Also, I think I’m allergic to oregano so hold that, too, and some coffee.

speaker: LUKE
words: So, just the eggs, tomatoes, and Jack cheese.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Not too many tomatoes.

speaker: LUKE
words: Light on the tomatoes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Very light, just a teeny-tiny amount, practically none.

speaker: LUKE
words: I’m skipping the tomatoes. It’s an omelet with Jack cheese.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Perfect.

speaker: LUKE
words: You did this on purpose.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Did what?

speaker: RORY
words: French toast for me. That was cruel.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know. Look how hard he worked on that sign and everything. Look at the handwriting, it’s so precise, so determined. It’s focused-Luke.

speaker: RORY
words: That’s Jess’ handwriting.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Really? How do you know Jess’ writing?

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, well, I lent him a book and he wrote some stuff in it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He vandalized one of your books?

speaker: RORY
words: No, he didn’t vandalize it. He wrote in the margins, thoughts and stuff.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Like what, like play basketball, eat a sandwich – stuff like that?

speaker: RORY
words: No, stuff, like margin stuff. People like Mark Twain wrote in margins.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Pilot a steamboat, write Huckleberry Finn?

speaker: RORY
words: Forget it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, no, I’m sure margin writing is very common. Oh, hey, you didn’t tell me Dean was joining us.

speaker: RORY
words: Dean?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey.

speaker: DEAN
words: Hi.

speaker: RORY
words: What are you doing here?

speaker: DEAN
words: I just dropped by to say hello.

speaker: RORY
words: How’d you know we were here?

speaker: DEAN
words: ‘Cause you’re always here.

speaker: RORY
words: We’re not always here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Uh, do you wanna eat with us, Dean?

speaker: DEAN
words: Rory?

speaker: RORY
words: Huh?

speaker: DEAN
words: Is that okay?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes. Oh, yes, you don’t have to ask.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, we’re three.

speaker: LUKE
words: I did the math. You gonna eat something?

speaker: DEAN
words: Sure, yeah, I’ll take the special omelet, I guess.

speaker: LUKE
words: You put him up to this?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I did not!

speaker: LUKE
words: Sure. You don’t even know what’s in it.

speaker: DEAN
words: I’m not picky.

speaker: LUKE
words: So you’ll send it back after I make it?

speaker: DEAN
words: No.

speaker: LUKE
words: Right. I’ll come back when I’ve got time for this.

speaker: DEAN
words: What was that all about?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I think it was a little something in your attitude, mister.
CUT TO CHILTON CLASSROOM
[The students are sitting in several separate groups around the classroom]

speaker: RORY
words: So is everything in the materials clear to everyone?

speaker: CHIP
words: Pretty much.

speaker: LOUISE
words: Oh, were we reading these now?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, that’s why we’ve all been kind of quiet for the past ten minutes.

speaker: LOUISE
words: I thought it was, like, prayer time or something.

speaker: PARIS
words: Good grief.

speaker: MADELINE
words: I’m still reading mine.

speaker: PARIS
words: What?

speaker: MADELINE
words: I read slow so I don’t miss anything.

speaker: PARIS
words: It’s not the Bhagavad Gita, Madeline. It’s simple instructions for the business fair.

speaker: LOUISE
words: Someone’s not taking to Elba too kindly.

speaker: PARIS
words: What does that mean?

speaker: LOUISE
words: Just that Rory’s the leader of this group, Napoleon, and you’re not.

speaker: PARIS
words: Excuse me, leader? You wanna lead here, you’ve got anarchy.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m just enjoying the show.

speaker: BRAD
words: Hi, I think this is my group.

speaker: RORY
words: Brad, hey.

speaker: BRAD
words: Oh, you remember me.

speaker: RORY
words: Of course I do.

speaker: BRAD
words: Cool.

speaker: RORY
words: So you’re back at Chilton now?

speaker: BRAD
words: Oh, yeah. My psychiatrist convinced my parents that I should face my fears instead of running away from them and my rabbi agreed, so here I am.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, nice to have you back. Take a seat.

speaker: BRAD
words: Paris. Her name is Paris, right?

speaker: RORY
words: Brad, let me catch you up here. There’s going to be an intra-school business fair in three weeks. Each group has to come up with a consumer product that’s geared toward high school kids.

speaker: BRAD
words: Neat.

speaker: RORY
words: So we pick our product and we make a prototype of it, then we use our imaginary million dollar budget to mass produce, market, and distribute it, and we’ll present all of this at the fair.

speaker: BRAD
words: Cool.

speaker: PARIS
words: Hey Brad? Your festive interjections are a real kick in the pants, but we’re low on time, so can it.

speaker: RORY
words: That’s it. In two days we’re going to reconvene and pitch product ideas.

speaker: LOUISE
words: Class dismissed?

speaker: PARIS
words: Whoa whoa whoa, we haven’t even discussed business advisors.

speaker: RORY
words: Right. We’re supposed to get a parent who’s in business to advise us. Anyone score?

speaker: CHIP
words: My dad’s got scheduling conflicts up the wazoo.

speaker: RORY
words: No for Chip.

speaker: PARIS
words: My dad’s in Hong Kong for the month but he can video-conference in if need be.

speaker: RORY
words: No for Paris.

speaker: MADELINE
words: My dad’s traveling.

speaker: LOUISE
words: My dad’s in court for the next six weeks.

speaker: RORY
words: Lawyer?

speaker: LOUISE
words: Defendant.

speaker: RORY
words: We won’t pry.

speaker: LOUISE
words: I have no idea what he’s up on anyway.

speaker: RORY
words: And no one’s mom works?

speaker: MADELINE
words: Working moms are so nineties.

speaker: BRAD
words: My mom works. She’s a curator at the Hartford Natural Museum.

speaker: PARIS
words: We need experienced business advisors, Brad – not someone who poses animal carcasses.

speaker: MADELINE
words: What about your mom?

speaker: RORY
words: My mom?

speaker: PARIS
words: Yeah, that’s right. She runs a hotel.

speaker: RORY
words: It’s just an inn, a small inn.

speaker: MADELINE
words: It’s still a business.

speaker: CHIP
words: She must keep books and stuff, right?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, but they’re really small books.

speaker: PARIS
words: Look, it’s not perfect but it’s a better option than Brad’s mom, the buffalo stuffer.

speaker: BRAD
words: She doesn’t stuff the animals. That’s taxidermy.

speaker: PARIS
words: Who is this rabbi that encouraged you to come back here? Give me his address, I’m gonna go over there and pop him one.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, hold it. Now, I don’t think my mom is right for this.

speaker: PARIS
words: Well, she’s all we’ve got so you need to do whatever it takes to make it happen, otherwise maybe you shouldn’t be the group leader.

speaker: LOUISE
words: A coup d'état, how exciting.

speaker: RORY
words: There’s no coup d'état. I’ll ask her.

speaker: PARIS
words: Good.
CUT TO INDEPENDENCE INN KITCHEN
[Sookie is stirring a bowl of meringue as Lorelai walks in with a box]

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Thirty, thirty-one, thirty-two. . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie, look!

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Thirty-three, thirty-four, thirty-five, can’t look, I’m making meringue, thirty-seven, fine science.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You got a package!

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Thirty-nine, gotta count, forty, can’t over-whip.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I think it’s your wedding invitations!

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Whoooooo! Gimme it! Ohh, I wanna see ‘em! Oh, you’re gonna love these. They’re pearly white with this beautiful lavender stripe - . . .

speaker: LORELAI
words: Aw.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I’m gonna choke somebody by the neck until brains ooze out of their ears.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What, they’re beautiful.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: The name, look at the name.

speaker: LORELAI
words: The marriage of his daughter. . .

speaker: BOTH
words: Susie St. James.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Who is Susie St. James?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I think it’s you.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What am I gonna do?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It can be changed.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: No, and these have to go out in a week.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We’re calling right now.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I am so not a Susie.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Good morning, beautiful morning.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It sucks from where I’m sitting.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Heartbreak. Lorelai, do you remember I have tomorrow afternoon off?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I remember, big plans?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Yes, my mother is coming to visit.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [on phone] Hello, yes, customer service please, thanks. [To Michel] Sorry.

speaker: MICHEL
words: About what?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You said your mother’s coming for a visit.

speaker: MICHEL
words: But I’m excited, I never get to see her.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, I must be projecting. Your mother’s coming for a visit!

speaker: MICHEL
words: She’s coming down for three days.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Is she staying here?

speaker: MICHEL
words: No. She stays with me, of course.

speaker: LORELAI
words: In your tiny place?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Oh, she’s fine with it. I mean, we stay up all night gabbing and watching movies. We have a ball.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow, I can’t wait to meet her. [on phone] Oh, hello. Yes, we have a problem with some wedding invitations we ordered. Okay. [to Sookie] They’re transferring me.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I heard that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He’s really happy about his mother coming to visit.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I heard that, too.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Totally foreign to me. [on phone] Hi. Oh great, I’m gonna pass you over to my friend who has a problem with some merchandise she ordered. Hold on one sec. [to Sookie] Listen to me, I’ve had a lot of experience dealing with people who have screwed something up. You have a better chance of getting them to help you if you don’t get all hysterical.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Okay.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: [on phone] How dare you do this to me! You’re ruining my wedding! It’s the most important day of my life! It’s my life, it’s not Susie St. James, are you listening to me?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good girl.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: You better be listening to me! Do you – look, no, you be quiet, listen!
CUT TO LOBBY
[Lorelai walks out of the kitchen as Rory walks into the inn]

speaker: RORY
words: Hey.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, hi. Thought you couldn’t get here ‘til later.

speaker: RORY
words: Our Franklin meeting didn’t go as long as I thought it would.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, lucky for me, more work for you. Here, chronological order, please. So how was your day?

speaker: RORY
words: I got an A on my physics test.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Aw.

speaker: RORY
words: And I finished Candide and I convinced a boy that Paris would probably never attack his rabbi.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So uneventful, huh?

speaker: RORY
words: Pretty much. Mom, um, I know you’re probably not gonna wanna do this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, I will. . .unless it’s something that I don’t wanna do.

speaker: RORY
words: Do you wanna be the parent advisor on my economics project?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh, Rory, gosh.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m kind of in a spot.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No one else can do it?

speaker: RORY
words: Nope.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You checked?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You double checked?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And no one else can do it so you came slumming after me and I’m your last choice?

speaker: RORY
words: Of course.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I appreciate that.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m totally stuck.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, if you’re stuck, I’ll do it.

speaker: RORY
words: Thanks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But – ooh, hey, what about your grandfather, retired business titan?

speaker: RORY
words: What about him?

speaker: LORELAI
words: He’d be perfect.

speaker: RORY
words: But this is a business project and the word business has been kind of taboo in that house since he left the firm. Asking him might remind him of that and upset him.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Or he’ll be thrilled that you thought of him.

speaker: RORY
words: Hm, you’re not just saying that because you don’t wanna do it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I really think he would enjoy helping you. You would be doing me a big favor ‘cause then I wouldn’t have to feel guilty about being so reluctant to help you out myself.

speaker: RORY
words: All right, I’ll give it a shot.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good girl.

speaker: RORY
words: Would you really have felt guilty?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, but I would’ve felt guilty about not feeling guilty and you can see how that could just go on forever.

speaker: RORY
words: Miss Gilmore and the vicious circle.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mm hmm.
CUT TO ELDER GILMORE RESIDENCE
[Richard is outside working on his antique car as Rory walks up to him]

speaker: RORY
words: Hey Grandpa.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Rory, this is a surprise.

speaker: RORY
words: I was just in the area and I thought I’d pay a call.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, how very continental of you. I would hug you, but I have various forms of viscous fluid on my clothing.

speaker: RORY
words: I’ll take a rain check.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Very good.

speaker: RORY
words: How’s she running?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Ah, she’s a bit, oh, obstinate today.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, girls can get that way.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Mm, indeed. So you were in the neighborhood?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, and I actually have a little favor to ask you, if it’s okay.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, ask away.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. There’s this project at school and, uh, it’s for my economics class.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Good subject, pragmatic.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, and we have to come up with a consumer product, all make believe, and there’s sort of a contest at the end and we sort of need an advisor.

speaker: RICHARD
words: An advisor?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, someone who’s experienced in business who can come to a few meetings, make suggestions. I mean, I totally understand if you can’t do it, but I just thought I would ask.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, I’m not sure how much help I could be. I’ve never actually created a consumer product.

speaker: RORY
words: That’s okay, we kids haven’t either.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Yes, I suppose you haven’t.

speaker: RORY
words: If you can’t do it or if you don’t wanna do it, I totally understand.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, things are a little bit hectic right now.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, yeah, I know.

speaker: RICHARD
words: And it is short notice, after all.

speaker: RORY
words: Very short, very short. Um, you know what, forget I even asked.

speaker: EMILY
words: Rory, I didn’t know you were here!

speaker: RORY
words: Hi Grandma.

speaker: EMILY
words: You didn’t hug your grandfather, did you?

speaker: RORY
words: I took a rain check. Well, I better go.

speaker: EMILY
words: But you just got here. We have cookies, would you like cookies?

speaker: RORY
words: No, thank you. Mom’s expecting me at the inn. And Grandpa, really, don’t worry about it. I just thought I would ask.

speaker: RICHARD
words: I’m fine, Rory. Thank you for asking.

speaker: RORY
words: Bye. [leaves]

speaker: EMILY
words: Ask what, what did she ask?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, something for her economics class. It’s nothing really.

speaker: EMILY
words: That doesn’t sound like nothing. What about her economics class? Is she having trouble?

speaker: RICHARD
words: No, Emily. She merely asked me to participate in some, uh, project at school and I respectfully declined.

speaker: EMILY
words: You declined?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Leave it, Emily.

speaker: EMILY
words: Why did you decline?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Let’s talk about it later, Emily. I’m busy.

speaker: EMILY
words: Busy? You’ve been poking around that stupid engine for the last three weeks and all it does is spray at you. You’re not too busy.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Emily, I am in the middle of something here and I don’t expect you to understand it.

speaker: EMILY
words: You’re not going to help her?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Can we talk about this later?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, I never thought I’d see the day.

speaker: RICHARD
words: What day?

speaker: EMILY
words: The day Richard Gilmore would disappoint his granddaughter like this.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, Emily, please.

speaker: EMILY
words: So, tell me Richard, is this how it’s going to be from now on?

speaker: RICHARD
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: EMILY
words: I just want to know what to expect from you. Because the bouncing from one thing to another, the moping and silence in your den for days, all of that I accepted. . .but your turning your back on Rory!

speaker: RICHARD
words: I did not turn my back on her.

speaker: EMILY
words: You adore that little girl, she means everything to you, remember?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Emily!

speaker: EMILY
words: Are you that lost? I’m incredibly disappointed in you Richard!
CUT TO SIDEWALK
[Rory and Lane are walking down the street]

speaker: LANE
words: Sales!

speaker: RORY
words: Lane.

speaker: LANE
words: Sales!

speaker: RORY
words: It's just a stupid test.

speaker: LANE
words: Lane Kim, you have shown a genuine aptitude for sales.

speaker: RORY
words: It doesn't mean anything.

speaker: LANE
words: Hello ma'am, I see you're eyeing the Whip-o-Matic, nice choice! This baby's right off the truck, and let me tell you, if you're looking for something to fulfill all your whipping needs, you've come to the right place because as Devo says – if a problem comes along you must whip it, as long as you whip it with a Whip-o-Matic!

speaker: RORY
words: Wow, you are good.

speaker: LANE
words: Stop it.

speaker: RORY
words: I'll take two.

speaker: LANE
words: I don’t wanna be in sales!

speaker: RORY
words: You don’t have to be.

speaker: LANE
words: I wanna do something cool.

speaker: RORY
words: Sell refrigerators.

speaker: LANE
words: You are not funny.

speaker: RORY
words: Look, you are taking this aptitude test way too seriously.

speaker: LANE
words: It’s the fourth time I’ve taken it and it’s the fourth time it’s come up sales.

speaker: RORY
words: Lane, in ten years, we will be having lunch in Paris and we will not be discussing whether or not you made your quota.

speaker: LANE
words: Right, so I’m gonna be a sucky salesman?

speaker: RORY
words: Changing subject now.

speaker: DEAN
words: Hey.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, hey.

speaker: DEAN
words: How are ya, Lane?

speaker: LANE
words: Only as good as my last sale, Dean.

speaker: RORY
words: Ignore her, she’s lost her mind.

speaker: DEAN
words: Got it. So, uh, what are you doing?

speaker: RORY
words: We’re going over to Sissy’s to buy some shoes.

speaker: LANE
words: And pick up a job application.

speaker: RORY
words: You will now face the wall quietly please.

speaker: DEAN
words: Well, after you’re done shoe shopping, come by my softball game.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, well – .

speaker: DEAN
words: You haven’t been to a game in awhile.

speaker: RORY
words: I know, but – .

speaker: DEAN
words: You said you missed seeing them.

speaker: RORY
words: I do, but I thought we were getting together tonight.

speaker: DEAN
words: We are.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, then I should really get my philosophy homework out of the way.

speaker: DEAN
words: Do it at the game.

speaker: RORY
words: My homework?

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah.

speaker: RORY
words: But if I’m doing my homework, doesn’t that defeat the point of going to see you play?

speaker: DEAN
words: You can’t glance up in between nihilistic theories?

speaker: RORY
words: I can, but what’s the point?

speaker: DEAN
words: What?

speaker: RORY
words: Why don’t I do my homework at home and I will go see you play next week.

speaker: DEAN
words: Well, I – .

speaker: RORY
words: I promise I’ll be there.

speaker: DEAN
words: Okay, sure.

speaker: RORY
words: Great, so, tonight?

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, I’ll be by at seven.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. So, have a good game. Do that pointing to the outfield thing, that’s always very popular.

speaker: DEAN
words: I will. Bye Lane.

speaker: LANE
words: Come again soon.
CUT TO INDEPENDENCE INN
[At the front desk, Michel is giving Lorelai some papers to sign.]

speaker: MICHEL
words: Here and here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What – .

speaker: MICHEL
words: Cleaning supply order. Here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s the – .

speaker: MICHEL
words: Staff insurance forms. Initial here, date it here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And I just – .

speaker: MICHEL
words: You just okayed the vaccination of all those filthy ducks in the south pond.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, aren’t I nice.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Yes, a regular Dr. Dolittle.
[Michel’s mother walks into the inn]

speaker: GISELLE
words: Uh! Michel!

speaker: MICHEL
words: Zeelee!

speaker: GISELLE
words: Ah! Mon dieu, you are gorgeous! Come, come! Embrassez maman!

speaker: MICHEL
words: Maman, j’aime ton visite. What are you doing here? I was going to pick you up at the airport, you wicked creature.

speaker: GISELLE
words: I had to come early. I wanted to buy presents before I see you since I know you are a materialistic vulture. All right, back up. Turn turn turn. Thank God I have the perfect son. If you had been ugly, I don’t know what I would’ve done.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Boarding school?

speaker: GISELLE
words: In Switzerland.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Come. Lorelai, this is my mother, Giselle.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, it’s very nice to meet you.

speaker: GISELLE
words: Oh my God, those eyes. Are they real?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, they are.

speaker: GISELLE
words: Well, then, if there’s a God, he is terribly cruel to bestow those eyes and that face to one person.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m sorry, can you be my mom, too?

speaker: MICHEL
words: I’m going to show her around, okay?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, make sure you see Sookie.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Why?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie wants to meet your mom.

speaker: GISELLE
words: Yes, Michel, I must meet your friends. I did not raise you to be rude.

speaker: MICHEL
words: You did, too.

speaker: GISELLE
words: I did, didn’t I? Come, show me off.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Oh, have you been using those free weights I sent you?

speaker: GISELLE
words: Yes, they hold down my papers beautifully.

speaker: MICHEL
words: A lazy, silly woman.

speaker: GISELLE
words: A cruel and vicious boy, I’m so proud.
CUT TO CHILTON
[Rory and Richard walk down the hall toward a classroom]

speaker: RORY
words: I really appreciate you doing this, Grandpa.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, well, of course.

speaker: RORY
words: I mean, I know you weren’t really thrilled with the idea.

speaker: RICHARD
words: No, no, no, no, that’s not true.

speaker: RORY
words: But I told everybody to have their idea pitches prepared so that we can get you in and out of there as quickly as possible.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Rory, this is an assignment. We will give it the time that it requires.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay.

speaker: RICHARD
words: However, efficient is always best.

speaker: RORY
words: I totally understand.
[they walk into the classroom]

speaker: RORY
words: Hey. Everyone, this is my grandfather, Richard Gilmore. This is Louise, Madeline, Paris, Brad, and Chip.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Nice to meet you all.

speaker: RORY
words: So, do you wanna say a few words before we start?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Uh, oh, no no no, I’m here to advise. I’ll uh. . .I’ll sit back here and observe and advise, uh, if necessary.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. So I guess we can start with the idea pitches. Who wants to go first?

speaker: LOUISE
words: I will.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, Louise has the floor.

speaker: LOUISE
words: I couldn’t find my new lip gloss this morning. I had just bought it and it’s the perfect shade of pink. Plus, it has this major shine with minor stickiness, meaning no fear of your hair attaching itself to your face when the wind kicks up.

speaker: MADELINE
words: A coup.

speaker: LOUISE
words: I know. So, of course, fifteen minutes later, tardy and glossless, I left the house and I had to rely on Madeline for my source of lip color for the day. Not an ideal solution.

speaker: MADELINE
words: Major skin tone mismatch.

speaker: PARIS
words: I’m sorry, group leader, could you ask the Pigeon sisters if there is a point to this opus?

speaker: RORY
words: Louise, what’s your idea?

speaker: LOUISE
words: A lipstick Lo-Jack.

speaker: RORY
words: Excuse me?

speaker: LOUISE
words: A lipstick tracking device. You attach it to a tube and you hook it up to a remote and next time you’re searching, you just point and shoot.

speaker: MADELINE
words: I’d buy one.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, um, Louise, that’s a very interesting idea, but I think we should think of something that appeals to both boys and girls. Anyone else?

speaker: MADELINE
words: Okay, I’ve got one – a locker robot. It would talk and tell you facts, help you with your homework, carry your stuff. And you could fit it in your locker until you’re ready to go home.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, but that means that we would actually have to build a robot.

speaker: MADELINE
words: Yes, we would.

speaker: RORY
words: Who knows how to do that?

speaker: MADELINE
words: I don’t know. He looks like he should know.

speaker: BRAD
words: I’ve never built a robot.

speaker: LOUISE
words: But you’ve tried, haven’t you?

speaker: BRAD
words: Yes, I have.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, let’s just try to keep the ideas down to things that we can actually accomplish. And I guess Paris is next.

speaker: PARIS
words: The average teenager spends seven hours a day at school. Seven hours where he or she is busy walking from class to class – indoors, outdoors, in all types of weather. At the same time, that same teenager is going through major physical changes within his or her own body. The combo of the action with the environment in addition to the hormonal imbalance can only lead to one thing – accidents.

speaker: MADELINE
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: PARIS
words: Monday morning, Muffin wakes up and looks in the mirror. ‘Oh no, I have a zit on my face. I’ll just look down when I walk so hunky football player won’t notice.’ And bam – Muffin smacks right into the cafeteria wall. Ouch, that’s gotta hurt.

speaker: MADELINE
words: Who’s Muffin?

speaker: PARIS
words: This is why I’m proposing manufacturing something that no teenager should be without – a first aid kit.

speaker: LOUISE
words: A first aid kit?

speaker: PARIS
words: Specially designed to fit in a locker with minimum space disruption. Bandaids, antiseptic, cotton balls, q-tips, ace bandages, aspirin.

speaker: RORY
words: I don’t know, it’s possible. Does anyone have any questions about it?

speaker: RICHARD
words: They sell these things in every drug store, do they not?

speaker: PARIS
words: Yes, they do.

speaker: RICHARD
words: There’s also a registered nurse on every campus. Her office would contain the products that you’re talking about, correct?

speaker: PARIS
words: Possibly.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, what makes you think you can get a young person to spend good money on something that they could get for free, or at least at a lower cost?

speaker: PARIS
words: Because I know one thing about the modern teenager.

speaker: RICHARD
words: And what is that?

speaker: PARIS
words: That you can get them to buy anything as long as it comes in a leopard print.

speaker: LOUISE
words: True.

speaker: MADELINE
words: Very true.

speaker: PARIS
words: We get them with style. We dress up the kits with sparkles, colors, pictures of bands. Sport themes for the boys, animal pictures for the puppy and unicorn bunch, chess boards for the Bobby Fischer freaks – a style for every taste. Plus, we use neon bandaids, pink or blue gauze for the bandages, anything that seems young or flashy or bright.

speaker: RICHARD
words: And that is how you intend to set the business world on its ear?

speaker: PARIS
words: That’s right.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Tricked out first aid kits?

speaker: PARIS
words: For the locker.

speaker: RICHARD
words: And you really think that’s going to work?

speaker: PARIS
words: Yes, I do.

speaker: RICHARD
words: So do I.

speaker: PARIS
words: Really?

speaker: RICHARD
words: It’s perfect. It’s simple, it’s easy to produce, the possibilities are endless. I love it.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, I think we’ve got our product.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Now, we need to go through this point by point.

speaker: PARIS
words: Okay, let’s do it.

speaker: RICHARD
