words: No. See, everything eventually registers. He'll chime in on this in a couple of days.

speaker: RORY
words: Days?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Days.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, is Jackson in the house? Let me here you say unh.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Unh.

speaker: LORELAI
words: A new toy.

speaker: RORY
words: Shameless.
CUT TO LORELAI’S HOUSE
[Lorelai is studying at the kitchen table as Rory walks out of her bedroom]

speaker: RORY
words: How's it going?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I hate these books, hate them.

speaker: RORY
words: Now now.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Agh! See that? They're trying to escape – they hate me, too.

speaker: RORY
words: Your books don't hate you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ugh, Rory, my brain is full. It has reached capacity. It's Shea Stadium when the Beatles played. It’s cramped and girls are screaming and I think

speaker: George is fighting with Ringo.
words: George is fighting with Ringo.

speaker: RORY
words: You have a very active head.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I simply cannot ingest anymore information.

speaker: RORY
words: So take a break.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't have time.

speaker: RORY
words: Close your eyes, clear your head.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, because clearing my head just means that all the knowledge I have painstakingly stuffed in there will leak out. In order to make room for stuff, I lose stuff. It's a very vicious circle.

speaker: RORY
words: I'll make some coffee.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I hate finals.

speaker: RORY
words: Nobody likes finals.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank God I'm graduating and this is the last time I have to cram like this because my pursuit of higher education has led me to a very interesting discovery about myself. Do you wanna hear it?

speaker: RORY
words: Sure.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I despise academics. Yup, learning, knowledge, it's all worthless. I have no idea in what you see in any of it.

speaker: RORY
words: Learning is fun, plus for me there's that whole "I'm a minor so it's mandatory" thing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That's what kills me – this is self-inflicted. I'm a masochist. I might as well be carrying a switch and periodically lacerating myself with it.

speaker: RORY
words: That diploma hanging on the wall is going to make this all worthwhile, trust me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I guess, unless I turn into John Nash and start drooling on people.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey, you're graduating.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know.

speaker: RORY
words: No, you're graduating – there is gonna be a ceremony.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, I don't know. It's community college.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, community colleges have ceremonies.

speaker: LORELAI
words: My community college doesn't even have a lawn, they won't necessarily have a ceremony

speaker: RORY
words: They must. Did you ask?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No. Well, now that you mention it, I think someone said something about some cheesy ceremony for my business class.

speaker: RORY
words: When is it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't know. . .next Thursday or something.

speaker: RORY
words: That's great, you have to do it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't know.

speaker: RORY
words: You have to do it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Really?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes. You've never been apart of an actual graduation ceremony.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know. That's because my stupid conservative high school wouldn't let me be in the ceremony and nurse you at the same time.

speaker: RORY
words: Don't be gross.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Do you really think I should do it?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes! You've worked hard for this, you've earned it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I guess.

speaker: RORY
words: Come on, you know that deep down you really want to do this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, I'll admit, I've always wanted to wear one of those gowns.

speaker: RORY
words: And the hat?

speaker: LORELAI
words: For the tassel ‘cause you know my thing for fringe.

speaker: RORY
words: And they call out your name and people clap and you get your diploma.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, and then you do that thing where you move the tassel from one side to the other – very symbolic, very dramatic.

speaker: RORY
words: That's it, you're doing it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: All right, if you insist.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, who do you wanna invite?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't know, you.

speaker: RORY
words: And?

speaker: LORELAI
words: That's cool with me.

speaker: RORY
words: Sookie and Jackson?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Aw, that’ll be fun.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. And Grandma and Grandpa?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, no. No no no.

speaker: RORY
words: Come on, it's your graduation. They should be there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Forget it.

speaker: RORY
words: But --

speaker: LORELAI
words: They won't want to be there.

speaker: RORY
words: Of course they will.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory, I was supposed to graduate from high school. Go to Vassar. Marry a Yale man and get myself a proper nickname like Babe or Bunny or Shih Tzu.

speaker: RORY
words: Yes but --

speaker: LORELAI
words: Instead, I got pregnant. I didn't finish high school, I didn't marry your father and I ended up in a career that apparently Jessica Hahn would think was beneath her.

speaker: RORY
words: That's not - .

speaker: LORELAI
words: I humiliated them. The two proudest people in the world and I humiliated them. I spoiled their plans. I took their fine upbringing in a world of comfort and opportunity and I threw it in their faces. I broke their hearts and they'll never forgive me. I guess I can't expect them to.

speaker: RORY
words: Maybe you're wrong about how they feel about all this. It was a long time ago.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory, I don't want them to go. It’ll just hurt them. . .and me, okay?

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. You should get back to your studying.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Fine. Oh, great.

speaker: RORY
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I think I've already forgotten everything I read in the last two hours.

speaker: RORY
words: No, you haven't.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, I have. In fact, I may have forgotten everything that I've ever known. Child, what be your name?

speaker: RORY
words: Study.
CUT TO OUTSIDE
[Lorelai, Rory, and Dean are walking through the center of town]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Just explain the concept one more time.

speaker: DEAN
words: And be mocked again? No, thank you.

speaker: RORY
words: Come on.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, maybe we're missing something.

speaker: DEAN
words: Okay, you go to a special shooting range –

speaker: RORY
words: A skeet shooting range.

speaker: DEAN
words: Right. There's two of you and the guy with the gun yells "Pull!" and then the other guy releases a clay pigeon from a machine into the air and so you try to shoot it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I don't think we're missing anything.

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, I knew it.

speaker: RORY
words: You shoot pigeons?

speaker: DEAN
words: Clay pigeons.

speaker: LORELAI
words: When you hit them, does blood come out?

speaker: DEAN
words: They're clay.

speaker: RORY
words: And why do you like to do this?

speaker: DEAN
words: I don't know. My dad shot skeet when he was my age and so he wants to pass the tradition down.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What if you accidentally hit a real pigeon?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, does that count?

speaker: DEAN
words: That's never happened.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What if a clay pigeon hits a real pigeon, does that count?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, does that count?

speaker: DEAN
words: I've only done this once.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, if you get really good, do you move on to other animals like clay chickens and clay sheep?

speaker: DEAN
words: You know, we didn't go skeet shooting, I just made it all up.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [stops in front of the market] Oh, hey, I gotta go in here.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, what do you need?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Just general stuff. You guys go and be in love.

speaker: RORY
words: I'll see you back at the house.

speaker: DEAN
words: Bye.

speaker: RORY
words: What if you shoot the person who throws the pigeon up in the air? Would that count?
CUT TO INSIDE DOOSE’S MARKET
[Lorelai is shopping and runs into Luke.]

speaker: LUKE
words: Oh.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Dah.

speaker: LUKE
words: Sorry.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, no, I should have signaled or honked or something, my fault.

speaker: LUKE
words: Okay.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, um, I guess it was inevitable us running into each other. It's a very tiny community.

speaker: LUKE
words: Guess so.

speaker: LORELAI
words: How's the diner?

speaker: LUKE
words: It's still there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, I knew that. I'm able to empirically with my eyes, uh. . .Hey Luke, do you think we could –

speaker: LUKE
words: I gotta get back.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, right, right.
CUT TO INSIDE THE ELDER GILMORE RESIDENCE
[The doorbell rings]

speaker: EMILY
words: I'll get it.
[Emily opens the door]

speaker: RORY
words: Hi Grandma.

speaker: EMILY
words: Hello Rory.

speaker: RORY
words: Thanks for seeing me on such short notice.

speaker: EMILY
words: I'm thrilled to see you on no notice. So, tell me, what's this about? You were so mysterious on the phone.

speaker: RORY
words: I just wanted to talk to you about something in person.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, come in, come in.
[Emily leads Rory to a lavishly set table.]

speaker: RORY
words: Wow.

speaker: EMILY
words: It's an English tea service. One the advantages of our having an English maid. That, and the fact that she speaks English.

speaker: RORY
words: You didn't have to do this.

speaker: EMILY
words: But it's tea time and I wanted to. . .oh no! Beatrice, I told you to doily line the plates!

speaker: RORY
words: You don't have to doily line the plates.

speaker: RICHARD
words: [calls from another room] Hello?

speaker: EMILY
words: We're in the dining room.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, oh, Rory, you're already here.

speaker: RORY
words: You're out of breath.

speaker: RICHARD
words: I ran over from the office.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, you didn't have to run.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, your grandmother said you had something to discuss with us. That certainly justifies a run.

speaker: EMILY
words: All right, everybody, sit, sit. Pour the tea, Beatrice.

speaker: RORY
words: Um, actually, Beatrice, could you hold off on pouring the tea for just a minute? Thank you very much. Grandma, Grandpa, I would like to propose an idea to you. Now, you can go for it or not, it's entirely up to you, but I would like for you to promise me that you will not get upset.

speaker: EMILY
words: We won't get upset.

speaker: RORY
words: And that you will try to keep an open mind.

speaker: EMILY
words: All right.

speaker: RORY
words: And that you will let me finish my presentation completely before you respond.

speaker: EMILY
words: [to Richard] She's been hanging around you far too much.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Rory, we accept your terms. Please proceed.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you. First, let me start by saying that Mom doesn't know that I'm here. She’d probably be pretty mad if she knew that I was, but I feel that this is important. As you know, Mom’s been going to business school at the community college out here for three years now.

speaker: EMILY
words: I believe she's mentioned it.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, she's doing very well and she's finishing up. Actually, she's graduating Thursday, and there's going to be a ceremony and I think it would mean a lot to her if you guys were there. It may not seem like it would, but it's true.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, if it would mean so much to her then why didn't she invite us herself?

speaker: RORY
words: Because she didn't think you’d wanna go. And I get that, but I think it's a mistake. I had a school thing once, and I wasn't sure if Mom would want to go so I didn't invite her. It was my kindergarten "Salute to Vegetables" pageant and I was broccoli and I did a tap dance with a guy that was playing beets and the entire number I was just thinking, "Mom's not here" and it was my fault that she wasn't there and, well, it was kind of a life lesson for me. Now, if the thought of going to Mom's graduation upsets you or makes you unhappy or uncomfortable in any way, then, please, don't go because this is an important night for Mom and if you go, you should go under the right circumstances. [pulls an envelope out of her backpack] Those are the tickets. It's Thursday, 7pm. It's indoors so weather's not an issue. You can use them or not, no hard feelings, do what you feel is best. And if you don't mind, I would really appreciate it if you would keep this conversation between the three of

speaker: EMILY
words: Beatrice, the tea, please.

speaker: RORY
words: Emily, these look delicious. So, Richard, how was your day today?
CUT TO LORELAI’S HOUSE
[Lorelai is sitting on the coffee table with a drink as Rory reads on the sofa]

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am feeling so good, sista, because it's over! No more finals, no more studying, no more school, the pressure's off. Do you know how much pressure I felt, do you? All last week I felt like a giant man and his brother were sitting on my chest.

speaker: RORY
words: A giant man?

speaker: LORELAI
words: And his giant brother.

speaker: RORY
words: Did they have names?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Clem and Clem. Huh, same names, which did not reflect well on the imagination of their mothers.

speaker: RORY
words: Mother.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mothers. There were two Clems.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, ‘cause they were brothers.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, so they had mothers.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, you're drawing me into your drunken world.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's not a bad place to be, my friend. Mnh-mnh, tank's empty. [walks into the kitchen to get another drink]

speaker: RORY
words: Hey, what is this?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: RORY
words: This, uh, ‘Life Plan’ book thing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: A little gift for the grads from the happy people at Hartford Community College. Hey, how many margaritas is too many margaritas?

speaker: RORY
words: Um, if you can't remember where the living room is.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ha ha, I'm still good. [walks back into living room]

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, here's an interesting question for you – "Have you given any thought to how children will work into your future plans?"

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, well, uh, they're not gonna stand in my way, that's for sure. I mean, I plan to have some, of course, but I'm just gonna knock 'em out and, uh, have Nanny catch 'em and care for 'em, make sure Mick Jagger doesn't come anywhere near ‘em and then just return ‘em to me when they're twenty-one.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, what about me?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You are my favorite eldest child, you get to stay by my side.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, I feel so privileged.
[Phone rings]

speaker: RORY
words: I'll get it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, now, if that's Mick Jagger, hang up and blow that whistle I gave you.

speaker: RORY
words: [answers phone] Hello?

speaker: JESS
words: Hi. [pause] Hello?

speaker: RORY
words: Hi.

speaker: JESS
words: Is this a bad time?

speaker: RORY
words: Um, no, just hold on a sec? [to Lorelai] Um, the music. . . uh, I'll be right back. [Rory takes the phone to her room and closes the door.] Hi.

speaker: JESS
words: You said that already.

speaker: RORY
words: I did. You're right, sorry.

speaker: JESS
words: So, what's up?

speaker: RORY
words: Nothing. What about you?

speaker: JESS
words: Same.

speaker: RORY
words: So, what have you been doing?

speaker: JESS
words: Nothin' much. Just hanging out. . . in the park, mostly.

speaker: RORY
words: Central Park?

speaker: JESS
words: Washington Square Park.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh.

speaker: JESS
words: It's cooler.

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: JESS
words: It's where David Lee Roth got busted.

speaker: RORY
words: Right, right. I hope he's got it together now.

speaker: JESS
words: Sounds like you got a party going on there.

speaker: RORY
words: No, it's just me and my mom.

speaker: JESS
words: Right. Okay, well, I'm gonna go. This is long distance.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, it is long distance.

speaker: JESS
words: So, see ya.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, see ya.
CUT TO LORELAI’S HOUSE
[On Thursday morning, Rory is getting ready for school in the living room as Lorelai runs around upstairs.]

speaker: RORY
words: Mom?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ahh!

speaker: RORY
words: What's wrong?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm experiencing frustration.

speaker: RORY
words: At the general state of things in the world or at something particular?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What do you wear to a graduation?

speaker: RORY
words: Cap and gown.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Duh, I mean underneath.

speaker: RORY
words: Whatever you want. The gown will cover it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's more complicated than that. I don't want to overdress so that I'm sweating if it's hot in the auditorium but if I don't have enough on and it's cold, then I'll freeze.

speaker: RORY
words: It is complicated, especially if you overthink it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And now I need a helpful comment.

speaker: RORY
words: Take light layers. Wear your turquoise and tan dress that you just got that's cool and it'll look good without your gown on, and wear your turquoise vintagey sweater over it because it’ll look great with the dress and it'll keep you warm if it's cold in the auditorium.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You are a fashion genius.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, you've taught me everything I know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: My brain's not working today.

speaker: RORY
words: You're excited, it's a big day.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What time are you getting there?

speaker: RORY
words: I have a bunch of newspaper stuff after school, but no later than six.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And then we'll go out to eat after?

speaker: RORY
words: Any place you want, and it's on me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You don't have to do that.

speaker: RORY
words: You're the graduate. You get to be pampered.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, then I would like to go to Chateau Jean Georges la Jean Georges in Paris.

speaker: RORY
words: I'll look it up in Zagats and book the Concorde. I gotta go.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, I gotta get ready.

speaker: RORY
words: Wait, wait, I wanna see my little graduate one more time before the big event.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What do you think – do I look ready to make my way in the world?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes, and if all else fails, you can marry rich.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I love that we always have that option.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey, what are you gonna do with your hair?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I got the curling iron warming up.

speaker: RORY
words: Mom, the cap! You put it on, its gonna --

speaker: BOTH
words: - smush the curls down.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You are a genius.

speaker: RORY
words: See you tonight

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, try to seat us next to a celebrity on the Concorde, like Sting or Screech or someone.

speaker: RORY
words: I'll try.
CUT TO FRONT OF CHILTON
[Rory is walking with Paris]

speaker: PARIS
words: So I told her, "Look missy--"

speaker: RORY
words: You called your advisor "Missy"?

speaker: PARIS
words: It was attitudinal. I said I'm not taking AP calculus from Henemen. I'm going with Branch. Branch is a graduate of MIT and Henemen went to Berkley. Berkley! I mean, he may have majored in math but what did he minor in? Bean sprouts? Forget it. And I'm telling my advisor all this, Mrs. Schlosser, and I looked down in her trash can and there’s this half-eaten banana in there. Nothing else. And I pictured her sitting in the shoe box of an office eating a banana all by herself and I almost felt sorry for her, but then she questioned my judgment about Berkley so I eviscerated her. I mean, she was welling up at the end, but she had the decency to hold it in until I was gone. I have enough faculty recommendations to run for student council, so I don't need her anyway. My locker’s this way.
[As Paris walks toward the building, Rory turns and goes back out the gates.]
CUT TO INDEPENDENCE INN KITCHEN
[Sookie carries a cake into the room as Lorelai sits at the counter with her eyes closed]

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Are they closed?

speaker: LORELAI
words: They're closed.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Are you sure?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm sure.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Okay, one second and open, open, open.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Aw, you made me a tassel hat cake!

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Filled with two pounds of crushed chocolate-covered espresso beans.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're evil.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: And you're graduating.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes I am, aren't I?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Here. Oh, hey, I brought those pictures you wanted to see of my high school graduation.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hand them over, lady.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Okay, but don't laugh.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I promise.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I was younger then, not as refined.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ha, and you’re stoned.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Totally.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I thought you hated that.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It was peer pressure. At my school, if Gilbert Garcia offered you a toke, you took it or took off.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, I think Gilbert had a snappy slogan.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, I was nauseous all day.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Your parents?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: For the traditional parents-flanking-their-graduate shot. Don't they look proud?

speaker: LORELAI
words: They do, very proud.
[Michel walks into the kitchen]

speaker: MICHEL
words: What is that?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, it's pictures of Sookie's high school graduation. What was your high school graduation like, Michel?

speaker: MICHEL
words: It was dignified, as most French ceremonies are. Poetry was read, a string quartet played, a ballerina performed.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You drank some Boone's Farm out of a boda bag and knocked a beach ball around?

speaker: MICHEL
words: I don't understand half of what you said.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That's why we work.
[Cell phone rings.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: [answers] Hello?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Hey, Lor, how you doing?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Christopher. I'm good, I'm excited.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: You should be, it's a big day. Did you get my present?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What present?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: A basket. You should've gotten it by now.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, did a basket come for me?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Mm, it came, it was heavy, I felt a twinge so I dropped it for health reasons. It's probably still intact.

speaker: LORELAI
words: My crack staff has just informed me of its arrival. I'm going to find it. [walks into the lobby and sees the basket on a table] Wow!

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: I put it together myself.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And it's all for me?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: All for you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Chris. . wow. [starts looking through the basket] Ha! A twenty-five dollar savings bond.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: That's a long-term investment. Don't touch it for thirty years, you're looking at forty-five dollars.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh, a youth hostel card.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: For the young girl who doesn't mind sharing a bathroom with fifty strangers.

speaker: LORELAI
words: "What Color Is Your Parachute? A Practical Manual for Job Hunters."

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: what do you want to do and where do you want to do it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: A DVD of The Graduate, gotta have that. Ooh, The Portable Nietzsche.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Light, cheery reading.

speaker: LORELAI
words: An application to join the Armed Forces.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Well, if your dreams don't pan out and Nietzsche's no help, it's a viable option.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And something in a nice little velvet box. Ooh, a necklace, and the pearl almost looks real.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Well, it better look very real, because it is.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That's not funny.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: This is not a funny gift.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Christopher, this is extremely not funny. This is totally humorless. It's. . .it's beautiful.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: I think you're awesome, Lor. With everything you do and raising Rory the way you did, you're superwoman.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Have a great day. I wish I could be there. Take lots of pictures for me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ugh, the camera, I forgot the camera.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Look in the basket.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [pulls out a disposable camera] Oh, you thought of everything.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Have a great night.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thanks, you too. Bye.
CUT TO BUS STATION
[Rory gets off the bus and looks around. She walks out of the station and onto the crowded sidewalk.]

speaker: RORY
words: Could you. . .um, excuse me, sir, do you know. . . do you know where Washington. . .excuse me, ma’am. . .Washington Square Park?

speaker: WOMAN
words: End of Fifth.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you! [to someone else] Excuse me, where's Fifth?
CUT TO WASHINGTON SQUARE PARK
[Jess is reading on a bench as Rory walks up behind him]

speaker: RORY
words: Hi.

speaker: JESS
words: How ya doing?

speaker: RORY
words: Good, how about you?

speaker: JESS
words: Good. You hungry?

speaker: RORY
words: Starved.

speaker: JESS
words: I know a place.
[They walk off together.]
CUT TO NEW YORK STREET
[Jess and Rory are walking down the street]

speaker: RORY
words: I feel very urban today.

speaker: JESS
words: Oh yeah, the plaid just screams urban.

speaker: RORY
words: I think I look like a native.

speaker: JESS
words: How well do you know Manhattan?

speaker: RORY
words: I've been here a few times. We saw The Bangles here.

speaker: JESS
words: When was that, twenty years ago?

speaker: RORY
words: It was a reunion and they were great.

speaker: JESS
words: Yeah, they're okay.

speaker: RORY
words: And a couple years ago Mom drove us in to shop, and she couldn't find a good parking place and all of the parking lots were a total rip-off, so she kept making U-turns and cutting off taxis and we were being screamed at in so many different languages that we just turned around and drove home and bought a Hummel at the curio store in Stars Hollow.

speaker: JESS
words: How very adventurous.

speaker: RORY
words: I'm just saying I'm no stranger to the Big Apple.

speaker: JESS
words: You are if you're calling it the Big Apple.

speaker: RORY
words: So I don't have the lingo down yet, but at least I have the attitude.

speaker: JESS
words: You do, huh?

speaker: RORY
words: Oh yeah. When I was getting a locker for my backpack at the bus stop, there was this guy and he was just standing there staring at me and instead of ignoring him I just fixed him with a really withering stare.

speaker: JESS
words: That I've got to see.

speaker: RORY
words: No.

speaker: JESS
words: Oh, come on, let me see your withering stare.

speaker: RORY
words: It's dangerous. I could hurt you.

speaker: JESS
words: I've been hurt before.

speaker: RORY
words: No.

speaker: JESS
words: I'm disappointed. So your arm's okay?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, it looks worse than it is.

speaker: JESS
words: [Looks at Rory's cast.] I like this Emily chick. Friend of yours?

speaker: RORY
words: She's a friend to all of us dispossessed.

speaker: JESS
words: So here's our lunch place.

speaker: RORY
words: A hot dog stand?

speaker: JESS
words: Hey, I eat here everyday. It's nothing fancy, but -

speaker: RORY
words: No, I love it. It's perfect.

speaker: JESS
words: Good. [to hot dog vendor] One with everything on it.

speaker: RORY
words: Make that two, please.

speaker: JESS
words: So, uh. . .how's -

speaker: RORY
words: Luke?

speaker: JESS
words: Yeah.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. He went fishing.

speaker: JESS
words: Fishing?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah. He didn't catch anything though.

speaker: JESS
words: Probably used the wrong bait.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, that's a common fishing blunder.

speaker: JESS
words: So he's good?

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, he's good. I can tell him hello for you if you want.

speaker: JESS
words: Whatever.

speaker: RORY
words: [to hot dog vendor] Thank you. [takes a bite] Oh, my God, this is really good!

speaker: JESS
words: I’m glad you like it. So how much time you got?

speaker: RORY
words: I got a bit.

speaker: JESS
words: There's a record store you should check out. It's run by this insane freak who's like a walking encyclopedia for every punk and garage-band record ever made. Catalog numbers. . .it’s crazy. The place is right out of High Fidelity.

speaker: RORY
words: Let's go.

speaker: JESS
words: Okay.

speaker: RORY
words: Where you going?

speaker: JESS
words: Subway.

speaker: RORY
words: I thought we were gonna walk.

speaker: JESS
words: It's fifteen blocks. Come on, I think you'll like it.

speaker: RORY
words: Do they allow hot dogs in the subway?

speaker: JESS
words: You are so an out-of-towner.
CUT TO THE COMMUNITY COLLEGE
[Lorelai walks into the auditorium, then follows a sign to the graduate check-in room.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Excuse me, hi, I'm one of the graduates.

speaker: MAN
words: Wow, you're hours early.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, well, I just wanted to beat traffic and have time to get ready and relax, and also, I’ve heard the early bird gets the unwrinkled gowns without the mysterious stains in them.

speaker: MAN
words: This is true. Take your pick.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you. This is so exciting. Isn't this exciting?

speaker: MAN
words: This is my eighth year of doing this.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, not so exciting for you, got it.
[As Lorelai looks through a rack of gowns, Emily walks by the open door. Lorelai catches a glimpse of her]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Huh.
[Lorelai thinks for a moment, then goes into the auditorium to see if it was really Emily]

speaker: EMILY
words: [to cameraman] You're being so cryptic. Do you need a power source or not?

speaker: RAUL
words: Look, my batteries are all fully charged. It just depends on how fast they deplete.

speaker: EMILY
words: So, we need one just in case?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai, it's hours before the ceremony. What are you doing here?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Um, I'm just getting. . .I’m sorry, what are you doing here? How do you even know about this?

speaker: EMILY
words: I shouldn't know about this? A mother can't know about this?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I just mean -

speaker: EMILY
words: You're graduating.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know.

speaker: EMILY
words: So, we're here to see you graduate. This is Raul.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey. So, you and Raul are just here to see me graduate?

speaker: EMILY
words: Don't be silly. Your father will be joining me later.

speaker: LORELAI
words: My father?

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, remember him? Tall, bow tie.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I remember Dad, Mom. I just. . .ah, Rory told you.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes. That's okay, isn't it? It's a little late if it's not.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, no, it's perfectly fine that you're here, absolutely. I'm just surprised. [to Raul] Who are you?

speaker: RAUL
words: I'm Raul.

speaker: EMILY
words: I just told you that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, well, did Rory invite Raul, too?

speaker: EMILY
words: Raul is my cameraman.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Cameraman?

speaker: EMILY
words: He's going to be filming the ceremony for us. He's very talented. He screened an independent film of his as an audition, "Welcome to Scab Land."

speaker: It was disgusting, but beautifully photographed.
words: It was disgusting, but beautifully photographed.

speaker: RAUL
words: It was supposed to be disgusting.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm sure it was. Mom, all this stuff. . .

speaker: MAN
words: Excuse me, all of this equipment, it can't be here.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, obviously we're not going to leave all of this equipment here for everybody to trip over. We're not cretins.

speaker: LORELAI
words: She's handling it. Right, Mom? You're handling it.

speaker: RAUL
words: Okay, this lighting sucks!

speaker: EMILY
words: Can we do something about the lighting?

speaker: MAN
words: I don't think so, ma'am. I don't know.

speaker: EMILY
words: [to Raul] It's a community college, we'll just have to cope. Think documentary.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, please. People will be showing up here soon. You can’t --

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai, I am perfectly capable of handling this. No one will be inconvenienced.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, I'm just gonna let everyone deal with all this because I need to relax and get a cup of coffee and maybe hammer a nail into my head.

speaker: EMILY
words: You're not needed here, Lorelai. Go get your coffee, relax. You're going to redo your makeup later, aren't you?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Maybe an Irish coffee.
CUT TO NEW YORK RECORD STORE
[Rory and Jess are looking through the records]

speaker: JESS
words: I haven't even heard of half these bands.

speaker: RORY
words: I love that about this place. God, Lane would wanna live here.

speaker: JESS
words: Who's Slim?

speaker: RORY
words: I don't know.

speaker: OWNER
words: Grunge band out of Kentucky. Two albums, plus a double-A side single, disbanded in '94.

speaker: JESS
words: Thanks.

speaker: RORY
words: [looks through the records] Oh my God!

speaker: JESS
words: What?

speaker: RORY
words: Look! [shows him a record]

speaker: JESS
words: Go-go's. You must have that one.

speaker: RORY
words: No, for my mom. This was her favorite group when she was my age, and it's signed by Belinda. This would be the perfect graduation present. I've been looking for something all week long, and I couldn't find anything and now I have Belinda.

speaker: JESS
words: Graduation?

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, from college, from business classes.

speaker: JESS
words: I'm surprised she has time for anything except lighting darts on fire and throwing them at my picture.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, it's not a lot of time, but . . .

speaker: JESS
words: Uh-huh. Go on, get it. She'll like it.

speaker: RORY
words: Thank you so much for bringing me here. This was fate.

speaker: JESS
words: Yes, it was.

speaker: RORY
words: And in return, I just might show you my withering stare.

speaker: JESS
words: I'm a lucky man.
CUT TO BUS STATION
[Rory and Jess are walking toward her bus]

speaker: RORY
words: I think this one's mine.

speaker: JESS
words: Yup, the sign says Boonesville.

speaker: TOURIST
words: Excuse me, I'm so sorry to bother you. Which way is 44th?

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, um, that way.

speaker: TOURIST
words: Great, thanks.

speaker: RORY
words: I got asked directions.

speaker: JESS
words: I saw.

speaker: RORY
words: He took me for a native. That's so cool.

speaker: JESS
words: That's very impressive. 44th's the other way.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh no.

speaker: JESS
words: Sorry.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, man, I should go find him.

speaker: JESS
words: He'll figure it out when he sees all the numbers getting smaller instead of bigger.

speaker: RORY
words: He still thought I was a native. That's cool.

speaker: JESS
words: I'm your witness.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, I should go.

speaker: JESS
words: Okay.

speaker: RORY
words: I gotta go to my mom's graduation.

speaker: JESS
words: And give her Belinda.

speaker: RORY
words: And give her Belinda.

speaker: JESS
words: Go on. I'll check on the guy, I’ll make sure he's not wandering around looking for 44.
[Rory boards the bus and looks at Jess through the window.]

speaker: JESS
words: Why did you come here?
[Rory opens the window.]

speaker: RORY
words: What?

speaker: JESS
words: I said, why did you come here?

speaker: RORY
words: Well -

speaker: JESS
words: I mean, you ditched school and everything. That's so not you. Why'd you do it?

speaker: RORY
words: Because you didn't say goodbye.

speaker: JESS
words: Oh. Bye, Rory.

speaker: RORY
words: Bye, Jess.
CUT TO GRADUATE CHECK-IN ROOM
[Lorelai is fixing her makeup near the chalkboard. She sneezes and stirs up a cloud of chalk dust.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Great, I'm Woody Allen in Annie Hall.

speaker: LIZA
words: You thought ahead. Smart.

speaker: LORELAI
words: mirror, makeup, picture of Shaun Cassidy. I'm done. Do you want to use it?

speaker: LIZA
words: Thanks. Oh, don't I look charming?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, you look great.

speaker: LIZA
words: I've looked better. I had to run here straight from work -- Kinko's.

speaker: ZACH
words: Hey, Liza, that gets me thinking – maybe you and I oughta do a little reproducing after the ceremony.

speaker: LIZA
words: Clever.

speaker: ZACH
words: Don't be a snot.

speaker: LIZA
words: Shut up! [to Lorelai] That's my boyfriend, Zach.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, sure.

speaker: LIZA
words: Of course, we're breaking up 'cause we're transferring to different schools. He's going to Florida State, I'm going to UMass. . .although I'm kinda going to miss this place.

speaker: ZACH
words: I'm not. This place stunk. It's Bush League.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Why'd you go here?

speaker: ZACH
words: My parents, wise investors that they are, couldn't afford anything else.

speaker: LIZA
words: Yeah, I guess that two-point-zilch grade point average didn't reason into things.

speaker: ZACH
words: Shut up.

speaker: LIZA
words: Between the lines.

speaker: ZACH
words: Go die.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are you sure you two don't wanna give it another go, 'cause you're darling together.

speaker: LIZA
words: Thanks for the mirror.

speaker: LORELAI
words: My pleasure.

speaker: LIZA
words: Hey, a bunch of us are going to Shakey's afterwards for a pizza. You wanna come?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Aw, I'm going out with my daughter after, but it sounds like fun.

speaker: ZACH
words: Okay, you guys are not going to believe this. There's some blue-blooded rich woman out there setting up professional film equipment like she's shooting a movie or something.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're kidding.

speaker: LIZA
words: Whose mother is it?

speaker: ZACH
words: I don't know. Little Precious must be around here somewhere though.

speaker: LIZA
words: I hate people with money.

speaker: ZACH
words: So do I, with every fiber of my being.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Me too. Money people, ugh.
CUT TO BUS
[Rory’s bus is still at the station. She walks up to the bus driver.]

speaker: RORY
words: Excuse me?

speaker: DRIVER
words: Yes?

speaker: RORY
words: Are we leaving soon?

speaker: DRIVER
words: I have no idea.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, should you have an idea?

speaker: DRIVER
words: There was an accident, closed the interstate. All outbound buses were told to stand down.

speaker: RORY
words: Oh. And you don't know when we're going to be allowed to stand up again?

speaker: DRIVER
words: Soon, I hope. I hate missing dinner.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah. . .me, too.
CUT TO GRADUATE CHECK-IN ROOM
[Sookie and Jackson walk over to Lorelai]

speaker: SOOKIE
words: There's our little graduate. Oh, my God, look at that gown. You look just like the Statue of Liberty.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah, all big and stony?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: No, you look amazing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hmm. You look very G.Q.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Oh, thanks to my best new friend Ermenegildo Zegna.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Don't you love how he can pronounce it and all?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Very Cosmopolitan.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: He got it for the rehearsal dinner. It's his first real suit.

speaker: JACKSON
words: And not my last. I look hot!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mmm.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: So, you know that Emily's out there, right?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, shh!

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Why shh?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's a long story. Just do me a favor?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Sure.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Keep an eye on my parents, make sure they don't disrupt anything, my mother doesn't behead anyone, my father doesn't snore too loudly when he falls asleep.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: They're not gonna do anything like that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm sorry, have you not met them?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Why would they come and do that?

speaker: LORELAI
words: They're here because Rory invited them.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: No.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes! They can't say no to that little face. It's like hitting a puppy with a rolled-up newspaper.

speaker: ZACH
words: Hey, you guys are not gonna believe this.

speaker: LIZA
words: You're Mr. Announcement Guy today.

speaker: ZACH
words: What, are you going to pipe in every time I talk?

speaker: LIZA
words: Can it!

speaker: ZACH
words: Stuff it!

speaker: LORELAI
words: They're in love.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Clearly.

speaker: ZACH
words: So, Mrs. Got Bucks out there not only has a cameraman, she's got a sound guy, too.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [quietly] Oh, no.

speaker: ZACH
words: It's like a Baz Luhrmann movie out there.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: [quietly] That's Emily, right?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Shh!

speaker: LIZA
words: Rich people feel so entitled.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, damn them!

speaker: ZACH
words: I swear, I saw her wipe her face with a hundred dollar bill.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We should line ‘em up against a wall, you know what I'm saying?

speaker: WOMAN
words: Is Lorelai Gilmore here?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes.

speaker: WOMAN
words: Oh, good. Have a look at these, will you? [shows her a box of corsages]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow!

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Pretty.

speaker: WOMAN
words: Look them over and take your pick.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What for?

speaker: WOMAN
words: To wear.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are they for sale?

speaker: WOMAN
words: No, they're paid for. These are from your mother, Emily Gilmore.

speaker: LIZA
words: Wow, ritzy.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I really don't want to wear a corsage.

speaker: WOMAN
words: They're all paid for.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Really, it's too much.

speaker: WOMAN
words: Your mother wants you to pick one.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Really, it's okay.

speaker: WOMAN
words: She'll just come back here herself.

speaker: LORELAI
words: This one, thanks.

speaker: WOMAN
words: Good choice. The cameraman said that would look best on film.

speaker: ZACH
words: So you're the rich girl.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Maybe. I'm not rich but . . .my parents have money, but I'm totally self-sufficient. I take nothing from them, except this corsage. . .and my daughter's tuition. So, you gonna stone me?

speaker: ZACH
words: I should have guessed. Look at her friends, they're wearing suits that drip money.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Hey pal, this was thirty percent off!

speaker: LIZA
words: So, that's why you didn't want to get pizza, 'cause it's below you?

speaker: LORELAI
words: candy, popcorn, and pizza – see? It's two of my food groups, that's how much I love pizza.

speaker: LIZA
words: I want to believe you.

speaker: ZACH
words: Enjoy your champagne and caviar at The Ritz, Your Highness.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am not rich! Ugh! [Pager beeps] My pager.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Maybe the suit was a little much.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: You're a fox, now don't start.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [reads pager] Oh, no.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory's running late.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Late from what?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It doesn't say. It says she's definitely going to be here but if she's not here by seven, she'll sneak in the back. That's weird.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: She'll be here, don't worry.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I hope so.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: How 'bout we sit in back, keep an eye out for her, and we'll save her a seat?

speaker: LORELAI
words: That'd be great. Oh, can you hang onto all my stuff for me? I don't want to leave it in here.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Will do.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you. Bye.

speaker: ZACH
words: Oh, you don't trust your valuables around us poor kids, huh?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Knock it off, Zach!
CUT TO BUS
[Rory’s bus makes a stop and some people get off]

speaker: SEATMATE
words: You don't look happy.

speaker: RORY
words: I'm late.

speaker: SEATMATE
words: Buses are the worst.

speaker: RORY
words: Why are we making so many stops? The bus didn't make stops on the way into the city.

speaker: SEATMATE
words: Oh, that was probably an express. This is a local – makes a lot of stops.

speaker: RORY
words: impulsive definitely does not work for me. [notices seatmate holding a soda can to his lips] What are you doing?

speaker: SEATMATE
words: Hmm? Oh, uh, it's for my spit.

speaker: RORY
words: Your what?

speaker: SEATMATE
words: From my smokeless.
CUT TO GRADUATION CEREMONY
[A speaker on stage is calling the graduates up]

speaker: SPEAKER
words: Victor David Fuller. . . Nancy Brenda Gatson. . .
[Zach sees Lorelai looking around the room.]

speaker: ZACH
words: Making sure the camera's getting your best side, princess?

speaker: RICHARD
words: [whispers to Emily] Are you telling me that that is the best commencement speaker they could scrounge up?

speaker: EMILY
words: I hope Raul's getting enough shots of Lorelai. I don't want the whole damn ceremony and none of her.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, no, I disagree. I hope he gets every inspired word articulated by the East Coast Marketing Director of Pup ‘n’ Taco.

speaker: EMILY
words: Raul!
[As Emily points to the stage, Raul and the sound guy rush down the aisle.]

speaker: SPEAKER
words: Joanne Garver...
[Raul shoves the camera in Lorelai's face.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, geez. Oh, we're, oh, we’re going. . .

speaker: SPEAKER
words: John Lawrence Gilfer. . . Lorelai Victoria Gilmore. . . Gretchen Greeman. . .
[Emily and Richard look on proudly as Lorelai accepts her diploma and moves her tassel to the other side of her cap.]
CUT TO AUDITORIUM
[After the ceremony, Lorelai walks up to Emily and Richard]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, Mom, Dad.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, I did it.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Yes.

speaker: EMILY
words: Raul thinks he got some good footage.

speaker: RICHARD
words: I should hope so. He certainly cost enough.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm sure it'll be great.

speaker: EMILY
words: Congratulations, Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you. I'm glad you guys came.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, well, we should get going. I guess we'll see you tomorrow for dinner. [they start to leave]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, wait. Aren't we going to take a picture?

speaker: EMILY
words: Excuse me?

speaker: LORELAI
words: The three of us, me in the middle with the gown, you know – the traditional pose.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, uh, we don't have a camera with us.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hold on. [pulls the disposable camera out of her pocket]

speaker: EMILY
words: That's a camera?

speaker: LORELAI
words: That's a camera.

speaker: RICHARD
words: That looks like a toy.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Um, Raul, would you mind? [they pose together] So. . .

speaker: RAUL
words: Okay, on the count of one, two, three, cheese! [takes picture]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, well, tomorrow then.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Absolutely.

speaker: EMILY
words: Let's go, Richard.

speaker: RICHARD
words: I'll be right there, Emily. [hands Lorelai an envelope] Congratulations.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, you don't have to do this.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Put it towards something fun.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you, Daddy.
[Emily and Richard leave as Sookie and Jackson walk over]

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Hey, we're so proud of you!

speaker: JACKSON
words: Yeah, you were great up there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thanks, you guys. Where's Rory? No Rory?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: She called your cell and I answered and she said she got hung up on something or other and she'll see you at home.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hung up? Hung up where? Is she okay?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: She said she's fine. She's sorry, but fine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh. Well, as long as she's okay, I guess. Um, well, I should probably get the gown back. Thanks for coming, Sook, Marcus Schenkenberg.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: You wanna go out to eat? Celebrate a little?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I think I'll just go home to Rory.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I thought so. See you tomorrow.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thanks.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Wait a minute. . .aspirins instead of Jordan Almonds? But we already bought the almonds.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Wow. Now that's the longest anything's ever taken.

speaker: JACKSON
words: My family's not gonna get the joke. Can't we just use the almonds?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Okay, sweetie, calm down.
CUT TO LORELAI’S HOUSE
[Rory is waiting out front as Lorelai pulls into the driveway.]

speaker: RORY
words: I'm so, so sorry.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're okay, right?

speaker: RORY
words: Yes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Everything's working? Your wrist is okay, nothing new is broken?

speaker: RORY
words: I'm fine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Anyone you know, like Lane or someone, suddenly get sick today or break an arm themselves or get in a car wreck?

speaker: RORY
words: No.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, good. Then I can get past worry and move onto other things.

speaker: RORY
words: I know you're hurt.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, you bet I'm hurt. Rory, I really wanted you there today, more than anything. You're why I did this stupid thing in the first place.

speaker: RORY
words: I know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It was a once in a lifetime thing. You should've been there. My best friend should've been there. Whatever it was that kept you, you should've gotten out of it, at least this once. Was it school?

speaker: RORY
words: It wasn't school.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Was it Paris?

speaker: RORY
words: It wasn't Paris.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, what was it?

speaker: RORY
words: It was so stupid.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, Rory, where were you? What happened?

speaker: RORY
words: I cut school!

speaker: LORELAI
words: You what?

speaker: RORY
words: I cut school and I got on a bus and I don't even know why I did it. I. . .I have no excuse. I was just standing outside of Chilton, and I don't know, I must have had a stroke or something. What does a stroke feel like?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't know. Not good, probably.

speaker: RORY
words: And I left school and I got on a bus and I went to New York. And that's it! I'm grounded for six months, or seven, and no TV, no stereo, no reading. In fact, take all of my books away from me and lock them up.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hold on here. You went to New York?

speaker: RORY
words: And no magazines, either. And I'm going to do all of the housework. Laundry, dishes. . . in fact, we're going to start eating at home so that we have dishes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory.

speaker: RORY
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stop. Why did you go to New York?

speaker: RORY
words: To see Jess.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Boy, do you know how to bury the lead.

speaker: RORY
words: I don't know what happened.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You went to New York to see Jess.

speaker: RORY
words: It was the stroke! It made me someone else, and after his phone call last night -

speaker: LORELAI
words: That was him?

speaker: RORY
words: It did something to me, I don't know what. In fact, you should take the phone away from me, too. That's right, add it to the list. No books, no music, no phone.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, Rory. . .

speaker: RORY
words: I'm a horrible person.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're not a horrible person.

speaker: RORY
words: I am sick, I'm ill, I'm cracked. This is not who I am. If I were to write this down in my diary and I would read it, I would be like, Who is this freak? This isn't me. This isn't my diary. I wouldn't do this. I wouldn't skip school when I have finals coming up to go see a guy that isn't even my guy and end up missing my mother's graduation, which I wanted to be at so badly. That's someone else. That's someone flighty and stupid and dumb and girly. And, I mean, I missed your graduation, which is the worst thing I could have possibly done. I mean, I hurt you and I had to spend hours on a stinky bus next to a guy that was spitting into a can, just thinking about all of the minutes that were going by that I wasn't at your graduation and they were hurting you, and they should have been hurting you because it was so selfish of this person who wasn't me to do what she did.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, my God, take a breath.

speaker: RORY
words: I don't deserve a breath. No breaths. You should add that to the list. You should beat me, ground me, take the phone away and deprive me of air.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, look, nobody wants to say this any less than me, but I - maybe you don't have a medical condition or a mental problem. Maybe, honey, you are falling for Jess.

speaker: RORY
words: No.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well -

speaker: RORY
words: No, I love Dean. Dean is my boyfriend. He will always be my boyfriend. That's it. Forever.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, maybe not forever.

speaker: RORY
words: Yes, forever. I love Dean and Jess is gone now and everything's going to be good again. Everything's going to be all right.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory, you cut school.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, I know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You got on a bus and went to a strange city in your uniform to see Jess.

speaker: RORY
words: I know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, that doesn't mean nothing. That means something. I mean--

speaker: RORY
words: No! I don't want to talk about this anymore. The only thing I want to talk about is the list I made on the bus of all the ways I'm gonna make this up to you. You get total control over the remote and the stereo for as long as you want. Total control over takeout food choices and a special surprise present every day for a month and -- oh my God! I left your present on the bus.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What present?

speaker: RORY
words: It was a vinyl copy of The Go-Gos original album and it was signed by Belinda, but it's not the only copy and I'm gonna find another copy. That's going on the list, too.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, honey, please. Forget about the list until tomorrow.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, I'll just go to bed then and...I'll go to my room.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hold on one second. Does this mean I have to eat alone?

speaker: RORY
words: Well, it's up to you. Sending me to bed without supper, you can't lose with that punishment. It's a classic.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'd rather go out with my daughter tonight.

speaker: RORY
words: I don't deserve it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, but I do.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, just let me take a shower and get the horrible smell of this horrible day off of me, and then we'll go anywhere you want, my treat, and I won't enjoy it. And then we'll come home and I'll go straight to bed and I'll have a terrible night's sleep, okay?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sounds great.

speaker: RORY
words: I'm so, so sorry, Mom.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, really? 'Cause you didn't make that clear.

speaker: RORY
words: I won't be long.
THE END
OPEN AT INDEPENDENCE INN
[Lorelai, Rory, Michel, and Sookie are sitting at a table in the dining room listening to a CD.]

speaker: ELLA FITZGERALD
words: I've flown around the world in a plane. I've settled revolutions in Spain. The North Pole I have charted, but I can't get started with you...."

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Huh?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sookie, you’ve gotta be kidding.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You cannot walk down the aisle to that.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Why?

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s depressing.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It’s Ella.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s morbid.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It’s a classic song.

speaker: LORELAI
words: A classic song with lyrics about a woman who can’t make her relationship work, whose life is filled with emptiness and regret and pain.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, who listens to the lyrics?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Anybody not hanging out with Annie Sullivan by the water pump.

speaker: RORY
words: What are these?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, those are some alternative songs, but I really like this one the best.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Alternative songs, good. Let’s see. Hey Jude.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Paul wrote it for Julian to cheer him up.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Seasons in the Sun?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, a sentimental favorite.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Cat’s in the Cradle?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, it makes you re-examine your priorities.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Don’t Cry Out Loud? Sookie, do you even like Jackson?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Okay, I have a wonderful suggestion.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Great, let’s hear it.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Okay, here we go. How about I leave?

speaker: LORELAI
words: And then do what?

speaker: MICHEL
words: That’s it. I leave and I don’t have to listen to this insanity anymore. What do you think, huh? Because I love it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Michel, I am in the wedding, which means you have to run the wedding all by yourself, something you’ve never done before.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Oh, please.

speaker: RORY
words: I’ll tell you what, Sookie. How about Lane and I come up with a few more suggestions for you? Still melodic, but not quite as Girl, Interrupted.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: All right, fine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Great. Michel, how’s the RSVP list coming?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Well, I must say this has been especially challenging for me. I mean, when you are talking about a wedding with up to forty people all living within a five mile radius, how can one person be expected to keep track of all of that?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Just an answer will do.

speaker: MICHEL
words: I mean, it got a little hairy there for a moment – I almost had to use a second sheet of paper, you know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, I’m not gonna let you annoy me out of making you handle this.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Oh, we’ll see.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Hey, my cousin Carl canceled so I have two empty seats. Anyone else you wanna invite?

speaker: RORY
words: I’ve got Lane, I’ve got Dean, I’m good.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What about Emily and Richard?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Emily and Richard who?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Your Emily and Richard.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, Sookie, you are way too sweet.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: What? She went to all that trouble to help me plan the first phase of the wedding.

speaker: LORELAI
words: The crazy phase of the wedding.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It was still sweet and I appreciated it. I mean, if it wasn’t for your mother, I never would’ve settled on the color pink.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Why is that?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Well, I wanted yellow and she said no.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, with logic like that.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Come on, just ask her. I want you to.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, I’ll ask her.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Good.

speaker: LORELAI
words: What are you doing?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It’s get happier the second time you hear it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Unh.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Huh? Snappier, isn’t it?
[opening credits]
CUT TO ELDER GILMORE RESIDENCE
[Rory, Lorelai, and Emily are sitting in the living room before dinner.]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Huh. You know what I just realized? Oy is the funniest word in the entire world.

speaker: RORY
words: Huh.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I mean, think about it. You never hear the word oy and not smile. Impossible. Funny, funny word.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, dear God.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Poodle is another funny word.

speaker: EMILY
words: Please drink your drink, Lorelai.

speaker: LORELAI
words: In fact, if you put oy and poodle together in the same sentence, you’d have a great new catch phrase, you know? Like, oy with the poodles already. So from now on, when the perfect circumstances arise, we will use our favorite new catch phrase.

speaker: RORY
words: Oy with the poodles already.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m telling you, it’s knocking ‘whatcha talking ‘bout, Willis?’ right out of first place.

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai, for God’s sake, be quiet.

speaker: MAID
words: Dinner’s ready, Mrs. Gilmore.

speaker: EMILY
words: Bless you, Inga. Please go tell Mr. Gilmore. He’s in his den.

speaker: MAID
words: Yes, ma’am.

speaker: EMILY
words: Shall we?

speaker: RORY
words: Okay.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, hey Mom, uh, Sookie wanted to know if you and Dad would like to come to her wedding.

speaker: EMILY
words: Really?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, it’s gonna be great. Small, low key, but fun. She’s catering it herself so the food’ll be fantastic, and you’d get to see me and Rory walk down the aisle in two of the least obnoxious bridesmaid dresses ever created.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, that sounds very nice. When is it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: A week from Sunday.

speaker: EMILY
words: A week from Sunday?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes.

speaker: EMILY
words: The wedding is in one week?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes.

speaker: EMILY
words: So this is a pity invite?

speaker: LORELAI
words: A what?

speaker: EMILY
words: Someone canceled at the last minute and rather than being left with two empty seats, Sookie asked you to ask us. How nice.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s not what happened.

speaker: EMILY
words: No, that’s quite all right. Far be it from me to be invited with the first batch of actual wanted guests. This is just fine.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, it’s not a pity invite. She really wants you to come.

speaker: EMILY
words: Is that so?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, that’s so.

speaker: EMILY
words: Where’s our invitation?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What?

speaker: EMILY
words: Our invitation. I mean, she must’ve at least given you an invitation to give us.

speaker: LORELAI
words: She thought it would be more special coming directly from me.

speaker: EMILY
words: So she was out of invitations. I never felt so special.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, she wants you to come. There’s no reason to be insulted here.

speaker: EMILY
words: I guess I should be thrilled that I didn’t just get a call from the road as you were on your way there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Do not turn this into something that it’s not.

speaker: EMILY
words: Do we have a choice between chicken or fish, or at this point do we just bring our own?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stop.

speaker: EMILY
words: Perhaps she would also like us to pick up some extra ice along the way, or help out parking the cars.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, look, isn’t Rory pretty?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Apologies all around. I could not get Adamson off the phone.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Dad, glad you’re here. We’re just talking about how pretty Rory is. Big eyes, baby. Give him the Bambi face.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, Rory gets lovelier every day.

speaker: RORY
words: Why, thank you, Grandpa.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh Richard?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh my God.

speaker: EMILY
words: Guess what Lorelai just told me?

speaker: RICHARD
words: What?

speaker: EMILY
words: We are invited to Sookie’s wedding.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, how nice. When is it?

speaker: EMILY
words: A week from Sunday.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Oh, so it’s a pity invite.

speaker: EMILY
words: Ha!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oy with the poodles already.
CUT TO LUKE’S DINER
[Rory and Dean are at a table eating breakfast.]

speaker: RORY
words: How are your pancakes?

speaker: DEAN
words: Good.

speaker: RORY
words: Good or really good?

speaker: DEAN
words: Good.

speaker: RORY
words: So, not really good?

speaker: DEAN
words: Fine, really good.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay. But are they great?

speaker: DEAN
words: Rory, uh, would you perhaps like to trade breakfasts?

speaker: RORY
words: You mean, your pancakes for my eggs?

speaker: DEAN
words: Yup.

speaker: RORY
words: Um, okay. Wow, you’re crazy, these pancakes are great.
[Lorelai walks by the window outside]

speaker: DEAN
words: That’s twelve.

speaker: RORY
words: Mm, two more and she’ll come in.

speaker: DEAN
words: I don’t know. She’s been walking back and forth out there for twenty minutes and she still hasn’t made it to the door.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, but look how much closer to the building she’s gotten.

speaker: DEAN
words: Why don’t we just bring her something out?

speaker: RORY
words: No. She and Luke have been in this fight for too long, she’s gotta do this.

speaker: DEAN
words: You’re cruel.

speaker: RORY
words: Tough love, baby. Oops, I think she’s coming in.

speaker: DEAN
words: How can you tell?

speaker: RORY
words: She’s got shoe sale face on.
[Lorelai walks in and sits down]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Okay, I did it, I’m in.

speaker: RORY
words: Good girl.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It wasn’t so bad. Took awhile, but not so bad. Wait, why are you eating?

speaker: RORY
words: You took thirty minutes to come in.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But I’m here now and hey, I’m like cheese.

speaker: DEAN
words: What?

speaker: RORY
words: She gets better with time.

speaker: DEAN
words: Ah.

speaker: RORY
words: Sorry gouda, we’ve got school.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But –

speaker: RORY
words: Order breakfast and I’ll leave you the paper.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, but –

speaker: RORY
words: I’ll see you tonight.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Dean, don’t leave me.

speaker: RORY
words: You’ll do fine. You’ll do fine.
[Rory and Dean leave; Lorelai walks up to Luke at the counter]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey.

speaker: LUKE
words: Hello.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, good donut selection this morning, really. Good variety, good color, good goodness, good . . . Well, so the choices are there. It all comes down to what I’m in the mood for. Sprinkled or chocolate or jelly or glazed, maple or kiki or apple or, uh, raised. Little donut rhyme there. Never mind. Can I have a chocolate and a sprinkled please?

speaker: LUKE
words: Okay.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, this is how it’s gonna be with us now, huh?

speaker: LUKE
words: No idea what you’re talking about.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re pulling a Mr. Freeze on me.

speaker: LUKE
words: I’m not pulling a Mr. Freeze on you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Please. I’m gonna need snow chains just to get out of here.

speaker: LUKE
words: I assume you want coffee with your donuts.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m sorry, Luke. It was a bad night. I completely freaked out. I said some things. . .did you get my note? I wrote you a note.

speaker: LUKE
words: Got your note.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You got my note. Did you read my note?

speaker: LUKE
words: Read your note.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And?

speaker: LUKE
words: It was very well-written

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s it?

speaker: LUKE
words: I also enjoyed the Garfield stationary. That’s one funny cat.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I said I was sorry, Luke.

speaker: LUKE
words: Yes, you did.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I said it like a million times.

speaker: LUKE
words: You said it four times, but I understand you’re embellishing for dramatic effects.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stop.

speaker: LUKE
words: Stop what?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, stop this robot talk. If you’re mad, just act like you’re mad at me.

speaker: LUKE
words: I’m not mad at you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re being really, really unfair. Rory was in the hospital.

speaker: LUKE
words: Lorelai, what is it exactly that you want me to do? I’m not mad, I’m not holding a grudge, I heard your apology, I feel I’m being polite, I listened to your donut bit, I got you your coffee. What would make you happy?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I want Luke back.

speaker: LUKE
words: He’s standing right here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, he’s not.
[Lorelai walks out of the diner]
CUT TO CHILTON AUDITORIUM
[Paris is at a podium on stage addressing a room full of students]

speaker: PARIS
words: Better drinking fountains, updated lockers, clearly marked boys’ and girls’ restrooms, non-dairy and wheat-free alternatives to the cafeteria, a larger voice in the monetary dispersal of charitable funds donated to our institution – because it is our institution, yours and mine. Remember people, if Chilton soars, we soar. If Chilton fails, we fail. It is up to us, we must get involved, we must care. It is not enough to sign a petition to get a Little Debbie machine installed in the senior corridor. Snack cakes will not change the world. Cream filling will not decide our legacy. How will future generations of Chilton students remember the class of 2003? John F. Kennedy once said, ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country. Those eloquent words are just as relevant to here in this hall today. What can you, the future of Chilton, of America, of the world, what can you do for your school? I will tell you what you can do. You can vote for me, Paris Gellar,

speaker: MRS. O’MALLEY
words: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Reese McGinly, Schatzi Leason and Paris Gellar, your presidential candidates for next year. Elections will be held this Friday. Good luck to all of you. This concludes today’s assembly. You are all dismissed.
[As people exit the auditorium, Paris walks over to Rory, who is writing in a notebook]

speaker: PARIS
words: Hey.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey.

speaker: PARIS
words: Did you get the Little Debbie comment?

speaker: RORY
words: Uh huh.

speaker: PARIS
words: All of it? The cream filling, the snack cake?

speaker: RORY
words: Every delicious morsel.

speaker: PARIS
words: Good, good. So, how do you think it went?

speaker: RORY
words: I think it went fine.

speaker: PARIS
words: Fine, as is better than Reese and Schatzi?

speaker: RORY
words: Fine as in fine.

speaker: PARIS
words: Well, how are you skewing the article?

speaker: RORY
words: Well, you’ll have to wait and read about it in the Franklin like everyone else.

speaker: PARIS
words: Fine, write whatever you want.

speaker: RORY
words: I will.

speaker: PARIS
words: Just make sure you mention that Schatzi pulling the Sharon Stone/Basic Instinct bit was a cheap attempt to distract the whole student body from my mandatory recycling program.

speaker: RORY
words: Go away, Randolph.
[Madeline and Paris enter the auditorium]

speaker: MADELINE
words: We got it!

speaker: PARIS
words: [walks over to them] You do? Well, come on, tell me.

speaker: LOUISE
words: Okay, a hundred and fifty students were polled.

speaker: MADELINE
words: A total cross section.

speaker: LOUISE
words: We talked to people that we should never have even had to stand near.

speaker: MADELINE
words: The hairstyles alone proved the Farrelly brothers are not making this stuff up.

speaker: PARIS
words: I’m sorry, have I ever been mistaken for a patient person?

speaker: MADELINE
words: Right, sorry. Okay, so we added the votes up.

speaker: PARIS
words: You added?

speaker: MADELINE
words: She added.

speaker: PARIS
words: Good, continue.

speaker: MADELINE
words: Okay, when asked which of the three candidates is the most qualified for the job of president, ninety percent said you.

speaker: PARIS
words: Really?

speaker: LOUISE
words: And when asked who of the three candidates would be the most competent president, overwhelmingly the answer was once again you.

speaker: PARIS
words: So that’s it, I’m in.

speaker: MADELINE
words: Not quite.

speaker: PARIS
words: How is that not quite? Most competent and most qualified, what else is there?

speaker: LOUISE
words: Well, we also polled likability.

speaker: PARIS
words: And?

speaker: MADELINE
words: And while people think you’re smart. . .

speaker: PARIS
words: And competent.

speaker: LOUISE
words: And competent, they also find you, well, a tad. . .

speaker: MADELINE
words: Scary.

speaker: LOUISE
words: Someone thought a Halloween mask of you would sell big.

speaker: PARIS
words: Well, fine, they don’t like me. Big deal, right? I’m still most competent.

speaker: LOUISE
words: Yes, but when asked if the likability issue would affect their voting choice, almost a hundred percent said yes.

speaker: PARIS
words: That’s crazy. You mean, people would rather vote for a moronic twink who they liked over someone who could actually do the job?

speaker: LOUISE
words: Sad, but true.

speaker: PARIS
words: Well, what do I do?

speaker: MADELINE
words: Hope for a sex scandal?

speaker: PARIS
words: Louise?

speaker: LOUISE
words: Oh, I’m on it.
[Louise and Madeline leave. Paris walks back over to Rory.]

speaker: PARIS
words: Hey.

speaker: RORY
words: Tomorrow with everyone else.

speaker: PARIS
words: So, I have been wracking my brains for weeks trying to figure out exactly who should be my vice presidential candidate, you know? Who would be yin to my yang, Joel to my Ethan, Damon to my Affleck, and then suddenly, it hits me – the perfect person.

speaker: RORY
words: Who?

speaker: PARIS
words: You.

speaker: RORY
words: What?

speaker: PARIS
words: It’s genius. We could announce it in the Franklin tomorrow, Gellar and Gilmore. We even have the g-thing going. Never underestimate the power of alliteration, my friend.

speaker: RORY
words: I don’t wanna be vice president.

speaker: PARIS
words: Oh, come on. Every little girl wants to be vice president.

speaker: RORY
words: Not this one.

speaker: PARIS
words: But you have to. It’s the only way. Please? I’m begging you.

speaker: RORY
words: Paris.

speaker: PARIS
words: They hate me, okay?

speaker: RORY
words: Who hates you?

speaker: PARIS
words: Everyone. Everyone in the whole school hates me. Oh, yeah, they think I’m the best for the job, but they don’t want to go to the mall with me so they won’t vote for me and that means I’m going to lose.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, how is my running with you gonna change anything?

speaker: PARIS
words: Because people think you’re nice. You’re quiet, you say excuse me, you look like little birds help you get dressed in the morning. People don’t fear you.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey, I haven’t been dressed by a bird since I was two.

speaker: PARIS
words: You will soften my image.

speaker: RORY
words: You’re crazy.

speaker: PARIS
words: Please!

speaker: RORY
words: No, I don’t want to be in politics. I just want to write about politics.

speaker: PARIS
words: You wouldn’t have to do anything. I’ll do all the work and make the speeches. You just have to sit there and be nice.

speaker: RORY
words: No.

speaker: PARIS
words: But –

speaker: RORY
words: Bye.

speaker: PARIS
words: Harvard loves this kid of crap. Being vice president is just one more thing to put you ahead of the rest of the hundreds of thousands of straight–A students who are applying for the same spot you are. Think about it. You say no, then comes the day when the letter from Harvard arrives. They’ve turned you down. Enjoy Connecticut State, sucker. Tell me you won’t be thinking, what if I had just run with Paris? What if the one thing that could’ve ensured my place behind those ivy covered walls I just walked away from?

speaker: RORY
words: Fine.

speaker: PARIS
words: Yes! Okay.

speaker: RORY
words: I guess the thought of just being nice to people never occurred to you, huh?

speaker: PARIS
words: See, that is exactly what I need from you, Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm for the new millennium. Hey, wear some braids tomorrow with bows. I mean, hell, let’s sell it, sister!
CUT TO DOCTOR’S OFFICE
[Rory sits on the exam table as Lorelai stands next to her]

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, how do you feel?

speaker: RORY
words: Great.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Not at all sad?

speaker: RORY
words: About getting my arm back? No.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Really? ‘Cause I’ve kind of gotten used to Casty over here. I mean, we decorated him, we talked to him, we protected him from getting wet in the shower.

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, it’s time to wean you off of getting attached to inanimate objects.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Casty, no one understands you like I do. What? No, I did not know Mr. Band-Aid said that to you. Ugh, I will talk to him when we get home.
[The doctor walks into the room]

speaker: DR. SUE
words: How you doing?

speaker: RORY
words: Dr. Sue, thank God.

speaker: DR. SUE
words: Okay. So Rory, let’s get this thing off your arm, huh? What do you say?

speaker: RORY
words: Not a word.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: [from hallway] This one here? Wait, which one? Hey, you in the white, come on, point a finger.

speaker: RORY
words: Dad?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Christopher? [pulls open the door]

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Aha, there you are. Is it still on?

speaker: LORELAI
words: What are you doing?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Oh, great, I didn’t miss it. Hey, doctor, I’m the dad.

speaker: DR. SUE
words: Hey, nice to meet you, Dad.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I can’t believe you’re here.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Why? I told you last week I wanted to come down for the big unveiling.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know, but I didn’t think you would drive all the way from Boston again. You were just here.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: You getting sick of me?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Frankly, yes.

speaker: DR. SUE
words: Okay, is everyone here now?

speaker: RORY
words: I think so.

speaker: DR. SUE
words: Okay, then let’s do it.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Great, and doctor, if at all possible, we’d like to keep the arm.

speaker: DR. SUE
words: Oh, I’ll try my best.
CUT TO SIDEWALK
[Lorelai, Rory, and Christopher walk down the street]

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: So where to next?

speaker: RORY
words: Um, actually, I have to get home. I have to review my campaign platform.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Campaign platform?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, our little Hilary Clinton here is running for student body vice president.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Wow.

speaker: RORY
words: Elections are on Friday, but I can honestly say that I’m very torn about which way I want it to go.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I spent four hours making picture buttons. You wanna win.

speaker: RORY
words: But if I win then I have to be vice president next year. Plus, I’ll have to spend my summer in Washington for some junior leadership program, which means six straight weeks of me and Paris together in a dorm room.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Hey, how about this? I’ll come back here on Thursday night and I’ll take you guys to dinner, and then we’ll break into Chilton and tamper with some votes.

speaker: RORY
words: We can’t.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thursday’s Sookie’s rehearsal dinner.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: Oh well, I guess you’ll just have to put your trust in a democratic system. Good luck with that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But if you’re gonna be in the area Thursday night, you can come with us to the dinner.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER
words: But it’s Sookie’s rehearsal dinner.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, she would love it. She’s cooking for a thousand. It’ll be fun.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, I’m bringing Dean.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I mean, if you can’t do it, then. . .
